componenttext:
This presentation and comments made on the associated conference call today may include forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements include information concerning future results of our operations, expenses, earnings, liquidity, cash flow and capital expenditures, industry or market conditions, AUM, acquisitions and divestitures, debt and our ability to obtain additional financing or make payments, regulatory developments, demand for and pricing of our products and other aspects of our business or general economic conditions. In addition, words such as believes, expects, anticipates, intends, plans, estimates, projects, forecasts and future or conditional verbs such as will, may, could, should and would as well as any other statement that necessarily depends on future events are intended to identify forward-looking statements. 
Forward-looking statements are not guarantees, and they involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions. There can be no assurance that actual results will not differ materially from our expectations. We caution investors not to rely unduly on any forward-looking statements and urge you to carefully consider the risks described in our most recent Form 10-K and subsequent Forms 10-Q filed with the SEC. You may obtain these reports from the SEC's website at www.sec.gov. We expressly disclaim any obligation to update the information in any public disclosure if any forward-looking statements later turns out to be inaccurate.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Invesco's Fourth Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Now I'd like to turn the call over to your speakers for today, Mr. Mart
componenttext: Welcome to Invesco's Fourth Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Now I'd like to turn the call over to your speakers for today, Mr. Martin L. Flanagan, President and CEO of Invesco; and Mr. Loren Starr, Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Flanagan, you may begin.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, and thank you everybody for joining Loren and myself. And I'll briefly review the 2015 highlights before getting into the review the business results for the fourth quarter. And then Loren will go into more depth of the financial resu
componenttext:
Thank you very much, and thank you everybody for joining Loren and myself. And I'll briefly review the 2015 highlights before getting into the review the business results for the fourth quarter. And then Loren will go into more depth of the financial results. And then of course, we'll open up to Q&A as we always do. 
So let me start by providing a brief overview of the operating results for the full year and so inclined, I'm on Page 3 of the presentation. Long-term investment performance remained very strong in 2015, 79% and 85% of actively managed assets were ahead of peers over 3 years and 5 years, respectively at the end of the fourth quarter. 
Strong investment performance combined with a comprehensive range of strategies and solutions we offer, help clients achieve their desired investment objectives contributed to long-term net inflows of $16.2 billion for the year. Our efforts to deliver for clients while taking a disciplined approach to managing our business resulted in an operating margin of 41% for the full year, off just slightly from the very strong prior year. 
The annual dividend totaled $1.08 per share, which represents an 8% increase over the prior year. We also returned more than $1 billion to shareholders during 2015 through dividends and stock buybacks. Assets under management were $775 billion at the end of 2015, down from $792 billion at the end of the prior year, mostly reflecting some later volatility. 
Average assets under management were $794 billion for 2015 versus $790 billion for 2014. Adjusted earnings per share for the year were $2.44 versus $2.51 from the prior year. As you can see on Slide 4, foreign exchange had a significant impact, diluting earnings per share up by $0.15 per share from the prior year. During 2015, Fitch upgraded the firm's credit rating to positive outlook and we repurchased $549 million worth of stock. 
So let me take a moment and look back over the achievements over the past year, which will provide insights into our continued long-range plans. First and foremost, of course, we remained focused on delivering strong long-term investment performance, which continue to grow our business. And as I mentioned, 79% and 85% of the assets were ahead of peers on a 3-year and 5-year basis, respectively at the end of 2015. 
By delivering strong investment performance and focusing on clients needs, we achieved further growth across the business. In the U.S., Invesco was the only firm to appear in the top 5 over 1, 5 and 10 years in the Barents best annual ranking. Our Asia Pacific continues to grow and we saw strong inflows in the range of strategies resulting in net sales of $5.7 billion. The strongest showing in the region since 2011. 
Institutional sales of $14.2 billion nearly doubled the prior year. We also saw continued growth in our EMEA business, driven by a focus on delivering strong investment performance in meeting our client needs. Cross-border and institutional were particularly strong with $7 billion and $4.5 billion in net inflows, respectively. And we remain in a very dominant position in the United Kingdom. 
We continue investing in capabilities where we see strong client demand or future opportunities by hiring world-class talent, upgrading our technology platforms, launching new products and providing additional resources where necessary in 2015. The ability to leverage the capabilities developed by our investment teams to meet client demand across the globe is a significant differentiator for our firm and will continue to bring the best of Invesco to different parts of our business where it makes sense for our clients. 
By delivering strong investment performance, Invesco Global Targeted Return achieved strong flows in its second year of offering with assets under management surpassing $11 billion globally at the end of the year. We continued to invest and strengthened our Fixed Income platform in 2015, which is enhancing our ability to meet our client needs. We also invested in our institutional business in 2015, refining our global strategy, bringing on additional highly regarded talent and more effectively aligning ourselves to the opportunities in the marketplace. 
We are seeing some early successes from this work, institutional flows during the first quarter were amongst the strongest in the past several quarters in spite of the very volatile markets. We're very focused on bringing together the full range of our capabilities to help meet our client investment objectives, Rhode Island mandate of $7.2 billion is an example of the success we're achieving with our Invesco solutions effort. 
Throughout the year, we continue to innovate and expand the range of alternative products we offer, leveraging our strong themes and capabilities for the benefit of our clients globally. Two years ago, we began leveraging our presence in China to explore and better understand the opportunities in digital and mobile technologies in the marketplace. We've also been exploring the possibilities with market-leading firms in Silicon Valley. Our acquisition of Jemstep in mid-January is an outcome of this research. Jemstep is one of the most digital platforms that focused exclusively on advisers and is a market-leading provider adviser-focused digital solutions. 
The Invesco-Jemstep platform enables Wealth Management home offices and their advisors, a full suite of technology solutions that are highly flexible, customizable and easily integrated into their existing systems. This acquisition represents an investment in our partnership with the advise community and highlights our efforts to participate in technology evolution within our industry. 
Turning to the fourth quarter. Let me take a moment to highlight the results, which you'll find on Slide 8. Strong investment performance contributed to long-term net inflows of $3.9 billion in the quarter. Adjusted operating margin for the quarter was 40.1% versus 41.4% in the prior quarter. Quarterly dividend remains at $0.27 per share. We also returned $329 million of shares to shareholders during the quarter, through dividends and stock buybacks. Assets under management were $775 billion at the end of the fourth quarter to $755 billion, we reported in the prior quarter. 
Operating income was $356 million, a quarter down from $373 million in the prior quarter reflecting a very volatile quarter -- the markets that we saw in the quarter. Earnings per share were $0.58 versus $0.61 in the prior quarter. We repurchased $214 million of stock during the quarter, representing 6.5 million shares. Turning to Page 11 and looking at investment performance as I mentioned during the quarter, it continued to be quite strong with 79% of the assets in the top half over 3-year basis and 85% were in the top half on a 5-year basis. 
We also saw improvement in the 1 year number, which was 60% of assets of leading peers. Turning to flows on Page 12. You'll see that active and passive flows were passive during the volatile quarter. Active flows during the quarter, were driven by a variety of capabilities, including Global Targeted Return, investment-grade fixed income, real estate and quantitative equities to name a few. 
Passive flows were positive with renewed strength in Invesco shares ETF were saw net inflows of $2 billion. These flows were offset by $1.2 billion outflows associated with the Invesco mortgage capital deleveraging. This did have an impact across a number of categories. If you look at passive institutional fixed income in the U.S. and if you add $1.2 billion in each of those categories, you'll eliminate the impact of the deleveraging of the Invesco mortgage capital during that quarter. 
Retail flows were relatively flat during the quarter, impacted my macroenvironment as investors weighed their options during the very volatile quarter. Institutional flows were particularly strong, driven by inflows in the Fixed Income real estate and reflecting our continued focus on this part of the business. The pipeline of 1, but not funded mandates remains at near all-time highs and is up more than 28% versus the prior year. Notably, this excludes the previous announced $7.2 billion Rhode Island 5/29 win, which is expected to fund sometime in the third quarter. 
We feel good about the results for the year on the fourth quarter and this puts us in a strong position heading into a volatile year in 2016. Continued strong investment performance, our focus on meeting client needs, contributed solid to operating results despite a very volatile environment. We continue to see strength across the global business, in particular in Asia Pacific and EMEA. Our focus remains on strengthening our efforts to deliver strong long-term results and help clients meet their long-term investment objectives from enhancing our comprehensive range of capabilities. 
But given the very volatile markets, we are taking a disciplined approach to managing our business, balancing our goals of reinvesting the business for the benefit of clients with the need to run our business effectively and efficiently as we have in the past very volatile markets. I'd now like to turn the call over to Loren to go through the financials in more depth.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty. Quarter-over-quarter, our total assets under management increased $19.8 billion or 2.6%, this was driven by market returns of $21 billion [ph], long-term net inflows of $2.9 [ph] billion and inflows from the Qs of $2 billion, offset by nega
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty. Quarter-over-quarter, our total assets under management increased $19.8 billion or 2.6%, this was driven by market returns of $21 billion [ph], long-term net inflows of $2.9 [ph] billion and inflows from the Qs of $2 billion, offset by negative FX translation of $5.3 billion and outflows from money market of $1.8 billion. Our average AUM for the fourth quarter was $783.7 billion years that was down 0.7% versus the third quarter. 
Our net revenue yield came in at 45.2 basis points with a decrease of 0.6 basis points versus Q3. FX translation reduced the yield by 0.4 basis points and change in mix reduced the yield by another 0.4 basis points. These impacts were offset by an increase in performance fees and other revenues in the quarter, which in combination added 0.2 basis points. 
Next let's turn to the operating results. You'll see that net revenues declined by $16.9 million or 1.9% quarter-over-quarter to $886.1 million, which includes a negative FX rate impact of $8.1 million. Within the net revenue number, you'll see that investment management fees fell by $29.3 million or 2.8% to $1.01 billion. This reflects the lower average AUM during the quarter, as well as changes in the AUM product and currency mix. 
Foreign exchange decreased fourth quarter management fees by $10.1 million. Service and distribution revenue decreased by $7.2 million or 3.4%, again reflecting the change in mix and lower average AUM during the quarter. FX reduced service and distribution revenue by $0.1 million. Performance fees came in at $18.8 million in Q4 and this was earned from a variety of different investment capabilities, including $9.8 million from real estate and $3.2 million from U.K. equities. 
Foreign exchange decreased performance fees by $0.1 million. Other revenues in the fourth quarter were $29 million, an increase of $1.4 million, driven by a higher real estate transaction fees. Foreign exchange decreased other revenues by $0.1 million. Distribution service and advisory expense, which we net against across gross revenues fell by $17 million or 4.3%. This movement was in line with our lower retail management fees and source and distribution revenues. 
Foreign exchange decreased these expenses by $2.3 million. Moving on down the slide, you'll see that our adjusted operating expenses at $530.4 million increased by $0.8 million or 0.2% relative to the third quarter. Foreign exchange decreased operating expenses by $3.9 million during the quarter. Employee compensation came in at $338.8 million, a decline of $8.1 million or 2.3%. This was due to lower incentive compensation for the quarter. FX reduced compensation by $2.3 million. 
Marketing expenses increased by $8.8 million or 34% to $34.6 million. This is a function of seasonally higher expenditures for advertising and other marketing costs particularly in EMEA. FX reduced marketing expense by $0.4 million in the quarter. Property, office and technology expenses were $80.4 million in the quarter, an increase of $0.5 million over the third quarter. FX decreasing expenses by $0.5 million. 
General administrative expenses came in at $76.6 million and that fell by $0.4 million or 0.5 percentage point. FX decreased G&A by $0.7 million. Going on further down the slide, you'll see that nonoperating income decreased $2.3 [ph] million compared to the third quarter. Included in the fourth quarter were a $7.3 million loss on the disposition of private equity partnership interest, as well as a $2 million mark to market on feed money investments. These were offset by gains from consolidated sponsored investment products compared to a loss in the prior quarter. 
In terms of effective tax rate. On pretax adjusted net income in Q4 was 26.6%, up slightly from 26.5% in the prior quarter, which then takes us to our adjusted EPS of $0.58 and our adjusted net operating margin of 40.1%. Now before I turn things back to Marty, I'd like to provide a little more detail on the business optimization work that we began implementing in Q4 current and the market volatility and as well as in light of our lower levels. 
We believe this optimization work will make Invesco an even stronger company, further increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of our operating platform. The business optimization work that's underway is primarily focused on our use of shared service centers, outsourcing, automation and office location strategy. In the fourth quarter, U.S. GAAP results, we recognized $16.2 [ph] million of expenses primarily in the form of staff severance costs and we expect costs associated with the optimization initiative to continue through 2016 total costs for 2016 are estimated to be up to $85 million. 
Reducing our run rate operating expenses in 2016 and in future years is an important outcome of this work. And we expect the outgoing benefits of this project will be well in excess of the projected onetime implementation costs that I just discussed. We anticipate the project will achieve cash payback within less than 3 years, and it will add in an estimated 3 -- I'm sorry, $0.06 to $0.08 EPS accretion in fiscal year 2017 and beyond. 
Finally, in terms of reporting and consistent with our past approach to dealing with material one-off expenses, the incremental optimization charges will continue to be adjusted out of our non-GAAP presentation but will be detailed and tracked each quarter in the U.S. gap reconciliation within the earnings press release. Additionally, we'll provide you updated estimates of the implementation costs and benefits of this initiative to the extent that these change in any material way. 
The One additional item for me to note is that new for this quarter, we've included a schedule, detailing the impact that the change in foreign exchange rates had on our non-GAAP operating results and expenses for the quarter. The amounts presented on Slide 17 represent the impact of the change and exchange rate movement in the quarter and the year, and were calculated by applying the prior period FX rates to the current period non-U.S. dollar earnings. Going forward, the schedule will include each quarter and can be found in the appendix of our earnings presentations. And with that, I will now turn it back to Marty.

componenttext: Thank you. And so Loren and I, happy to answer any questions people might have.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from Mr. Michael Carrier of Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from Mr. Michael Carrier of Bank of America.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First on, the flows in the quarter and then I guess, in the outlook, it seems like a lot of the strength, Marty you highlighted, you're coming from the institutional side of the business and then Asia. You even mentioned the pipeline near at all-time high
componenttext: First on, the flows in the quarter and then I guess, in the outlook, it seems like a lot of the strength, Marty you highlighted, you're coming from the institutional side of the business and then Asia. You even mentioned the pipeline near at all-time highs. Just wanted to get a sense from a mix standpoint what's driving may be that pipeline? And then when we think about it maybe for Loren, like from a mix shift on products obviously, the market has a beta side, it's having an impact for everyone. But just wanted to try to get a sense on how that pipeline is relative to the current mix or the fee rate.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll be happy to pick that up, Mike. So the pipeline is being driven really in 4 big buckets. Probably one of the biggest is direct real estate, it's probably 30% of the pipeline. It continues to be a strong driver. Fixed income generally across a broa
componenttext: So I'll be happy to pick that up, Mike. So the pipeline is being driven really in 4 big buckets. Probably one of the biggest is direct real estate, it's probably 30% of the pipeline. It continues to be a strong driver. Fixed income generally across a broad Fixed Income. Alternative Fixed Income stable value, it'll probably be another 30%. And then the remainder is split between asset allocation and multi-asset solutions. And then quantitative and regional equities would be other. So it's fairly well-diversified. And generally high fee. And so when we look at the fee rate of the pipeline, it's actually at one of the highest levels we've ever seen it. It's well above our current net revenue yields for the firm as a whole. And so as these assets come in, it will be accretive to our fee rates, which is great news. Obviously, the negative that we've seen in our fee rate is due to the compression on equities just given what's happened in the market and then foreign exchange has also had an impact as well. But in terms of the mix overall in the pipeline the institutional pipeline we think is very positive for our fee rates.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I don't know if I can add much to it other than, it is a part of the business where we turned our attention. It's really seemingly getting stronger and stronger frankly, in each region of the world in the Americas, in EMEA and in Asia Pacific. And
componenttext: Yes, so I don't know if I can add much to it other than, it is a part of the business where we turned our attention. It's really seemingly getting stronger and stronger frankly, in each region of the world in the Americas, in EMEA and in Asia Pacific. And it is really quite broad based. So it's a very positive.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other thing I would just mention, I mean we would expect our fee rate, I mean given stability in assets and stability in FX to grow across 2016.
componenttext: And the other thing I would just mention, I mean we would expect our fee rate, I mean given stability in assets and stability in FX to grow across 2016.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then just a quick follow-up. Loren, usually or sometime you'll give some guidance on just like the expense lines. And I don't know if it's because of some of the work that you guys are doing, the streamlining the expenses as you
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just a quick follow-up. Loren, usually or sometime you'll give some guidance on just like the expense lines. And I don't know if it's because of some of the work that you guys are doing, the streamlining the expenses as you get into '17. But just any, I guess, color, I think comp you took away -- had the 1Q seasonality but maybe the marketing you have some 4Q seasonality. So any color on the expense outlook, just given the volatility of the markets right now.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say given the volatility, we're probably not going to give any specific guidance on any line items at this stage. There's a lot of work I obviously, discussed being done around some of this optimization work, which will have some impacts on those
componenttext: Yes, I'd say given the volatility, we're probably not going to give any specific guidance on any line items at this stage. There's a lot of work I obviously, discussed being done around some of this optimization work, which will have some impacts on those line items as well. Generally, we're working hard to bring expenses down, right? As you can imagine, year-over-year decline in expenses, our compensation generally moves and in line with operating income, so those will be down. Some of the optimization work especially around -- we just mentioned some of the severance will also help bring some of the compensation line down. But the benefits of the optimization work will probably spread across most of the other categories of the marketing explicitly. We're looking at marketing. That's another interesting topic for us. It is one of these conundrums when you're in this market, given your clients want to hear from you and you want to be out with them. But at the same time, it certainly is a discretionary expense and it's one we'll continue to look at. So I'd say we're obviously, going to be very vigilant to making sure that we manage expenses very smartly in this environment with no presumption of snapback or some reversal. The other thing that I would like to just mention, there is some impact just due to the acquisitions that we discussed in terms of Jemstep and in terms of, after management completing 100% ownership there. It's absolutely immaterial in terms of the earnings impact, so you don't have to worry about EPS impact. But it does add probably roughly $15 million of expense and a little bit more in revenue in 2016. So you'll see some of those line items go up just as a result of those acquisitions. But offset by obviously, higher levels of revenues. So we don't want anyone to be surprised by that. The optimization work that we're doing should have a benefit in 2016 that you'll see. So again, we'll quantify that as we get through it. But that will help drive expenses down year-over-year.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just add to Loren's point. I mean, we feel like we're really quite capable at this and if you look at our history, you see these volatile periods to really take advantage of opportunities as they show up. It is a period where I think '16 for
componenttext: Yes, I would just add to Loren's point. I mean, we feel like we're really quite capable at this and if you look at our history, you see these volatile periods to really take advantage of opportunities as they show up. It is a period where I think '16 for the industry is going to be quite interesting where clients will be looking for those firms that are in a position of strength. And we are one of those firms and we feel we're operating from a position of strength right now. And so we're going to be very responsible on the expense side, but we have some real opportunities where we want to continue to advance at the same time. So that's what we're working through and we'll continue to make sure that we're communicating pretty clearly with everybody.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Daniel Fannon of Jefferies.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: I guess, first can you expand upon the 5/29 mandate, I think $0.72 billion [ph] you mentioned that's going to fund in the third quarter. Is that -- can you talk about the mix of products that's going to be in it and also, that's obviously, very large. Is that something that is a new channel for you guys? Or can you talk about how that evolves and maybe the other opportunities within that subsegment?

componenttext: Yes, so it will fund in January.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: In July.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: January -- July. It's 2 plans. The vast majority of the money is and 1 plan is just for Rhode Island alone, that's ETF's alone, sort of a broad range of ETFs. It was -- it's driven by our solutions team. So they are building a portfolio consistent with wh
componenttext: January -- July. It's 2 plans. The vast majority of the money is and 1 plan is just for Rhode Island alone, that's ETF's alone, sort of a broad range of ETFs. It was -- it's driven by our solutions team. So they are building a portfolio consistent with what Rhode Island, the CIO has set there as a set of investment objectives. The much larger part of the plan, which is probably $6.8 billion of that is a broad range of active and passive capabilities. Again managed by our solutions team. And from my point of view, Rhode Island's been very, very thoughtful and it is a really well constructed approach. And again, it's our solutions team that's managing the capabilities. With regard to the channel, it is a new channel for us from the standpoint of cash as we all know, many, many people use 5/29 [ph] for kids et cetera, et cetera. So it will be available in the advice channels throughout the country. And it's one of the largest 5/29 plans in the marketplace. And we think it's just going to be that much more competitive. It'll be -- our goal is to help Rhode Island meet the needs of the people in the portfolio. But frankly, they also want to grow in their plan too and we work very hard to do that.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then you mentioned a part of the strength in the fourth quarter has been in Asia and Europe. I think that's been for some time. I guess, given the volatility at the start of the year, has those demand changes -- has this demand trends kind of c
componenttext: Great. And then you mentioned a part of the strength in the fourth quarter has been in Asia and Europe. I think that's been for some time. I guess, given the volatility at the start of the year, has those demand changes -- has this demand trends kind of changed at all or kind of how would you characterize that to the start of the year?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really hard to -- I think the psychology day by day, and week by week changes. It does feel like its -- as the markets are seeming a little more calm, you're getting some more clarity. I will say it was in Asia last week and all the business I have w
componenttext: It's really hard to -- I think the psychology day by day, and week by week changes. It does feel like its -- as the markets are seeming a little more calm, you're getting some more clarity. I will say it was in Asia last week and all the business I have were all very, very strong. So I would anticipate continued strength in there. And as Loren said, in EMEA. But it feels like we're starting to see a little bit more positive reaction to the environment. But again, it's so early to say anything.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the point that you made before Marty, is it's institution. I mean the strength on the institutional side is actually strong in every region. Great pipeline. The retail behavior has been sort of hard to gauge sort of in and out, responders go off.
componenttext: I think the point that you made before Marty, is it's institution. I mean the strength on the institutional side is actually strong in every region. Great pipeline. The retail behavior has been sort of hard to gauge sort of in and out, responders go off. But generally I'd say in EMEA, we feel very, very comfortable and confident that the retail side is going to be quite strong. The GTR product is doing very, very well. Performance has been quite, quite strong. And we think that will help continue to allow us to grow both in the U.K. and in Europe on the retail side. The other thing is the quantitative product as well, it's unbelievable. Off the charts performance. So also very, very strong performance and demand.

componenttextpreview: Got it. That's cool. And then a question on Jemstep. I saw your details and rationale for growth in the slides. I just had a follow-up question, how do you expect the distributors to use it? And then more importantly, how do you differentiate? Because I'm
componenttext: Got it. That's cool. And then a question on Jemstep. I saw your details and rationale for growth in the slides. I just had a follow-up question, how do you expect the distributors to use it? And then more importantly, how do you differentiate? Because I'm assuming this is going to be many large asset managers having their version and maybe even the distributors doing their own version. I'm just curious, is this an early mover advantage that you make their lives easier? I'm just curious how you expect that to shape up.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a great question. So I think you're going to -- and we are expecting a large distributors will have some version of their own. That's historically what they've done in the past. We still contacted them and that would be our -- what we would an
componenttext: Yes, that's a great question. So I think you're going to -- and we are expecting a large distributors will have some version of their own. That's historically what they've done in the past. We still contacted them and that would be our -- what we would anticipate. It's really just sort of the other channels though, there's a high degree of interest in this. And really what it is, it's just us partnering up with our distribution partners and the more effective we can be with them at the end of the day. That's a good thing for their clients and for us also. I don't believe that they're going to be -- let me say the other way. I believe strongly that there is a first mover advantage do this because quite frankly, multiple distribution partners are not [indiscernible] multiples 3, 4, 5, 6, 10 of these within the system, they don't need it. And it's like any other application, it's education and investment to move that forward. So that is our other core belief.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: To that end, is that your point that we have 300 people on the ground, selling and educating as we speak?
componenttext: To that end, is that your point that we have 300 people on the ground, selling and educating as we speak?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes.

componenttext: Okay, good. Last one, Loren. With the cash balances hitting your internal hurdles and the valuation, in my words at a ridiculous level, how do you think about the payout ratio relative to the past? Like can we start seeing 100% payouts even though you have a lot of things going on?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you saw something probably very close to that, this last quarter. So again, we certainly have demonstrated our willingness to respond when the stock has, as you call, ridiculously low. And we would tend to agree with you on that one, just gi
componenttext: Well, I think you saw something probably very close to that, this last quarter. So again, we certainly have demonstrated our willingness to respond when the stock has, as you call, ridiculously low. And we would tend to agree with you on that one, just given our sense of optimism around our ability to grow over the long-term. So you should expect us to continue to pay a lot of attention. Our needs for internal organic growth, seedings and so forth are still pretty sizable. A lot of opportunities and we need to balance those against returning capital. But we should similarly expect us to be operating in the stock buyback from -- in a nonbusiness as usual approach, which is somewhat similar to what you've seen in the fourth quarter. Maybe not at that full level, but maybe something between business as usual and what you've seen us do.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Next, we have Mr. Bill Katz from Citi.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just trying to reconcile some of the numbers on the optimization program you delineated a bit Loren, you mentioned I guess roughly $100 million between the charge in the fourth quarter, and then what you expect for this year and that sort of the 3-year pa
componenttext: Just trying to reconcile some of the numbers on the optimization program you delineated a bit Loren, you mentioned I guess roughly $100 million between the charge in the fourth quarter, and then what you expect for this year and that sort of the 3-year payback. $0.06 to $0.08 accretion in '17. Is it accretive to non-GAAP earnings for '16? The reason I'm asking is I guess, you got to run the expenses through the GAAP line. I presume if it's a 3-year recovery, either you're really back ended in '18 or you would get some pretty sizable savings as well. I'm just trying to figure out the cash flows.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the execution of the optimization is going to happen all through 2016. So the 3-year payback is really going to be in full throttle in 2017 and beyond. We will get savings in 2016 probably somewhere around $15 million is what our non-GAAP run rate, pos
componenttext: So the execution of the optimization is going to happen all through 2016. So the 3-year payback is really going to be in full throttle in 2017 and beyond. We will get savings in 2016 probably somewhere around $15 million is what our non-GAAP run rate, positive impact would be or it is what you would expect, and that would certainly ramp up significantly in 2017 and on. So again, our estimate is based on what we know today, based on the activities that we're engaged in today. But we're going to be pretty -- we do believe that it will be no more than $85 million in terms of what is required for us to implement that long-term run rate savings, which again, is somewhere $30 million to $45 million in run rate cost savings post 2017.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then Marty, or maybe both of you guys, you gave a nice delineation also, by region and by product. But the one area that seem to sort of not be within that list was more the traditional equity mandates. What are you hearing from c
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then Marty, or maybe both of you guys, you gave a nice delineation also, by region and by product. But the one area that seem to sort of not be within that list was more the traditional equity mandates. What are you hearing from clients on the institutional side? Is there still more of this bar build notion? Or is there any sort of interest in more traditional plain vanilla type of [indiscernible]?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So there are actually. I mean again, I'll just use the age trip just because I was there, but I was limited to that. You're actually seeing institutional clients recognize this is probably the time to increase our exposure to the equity market. So yo
componenttext: Yes. So there are actually. I mean again, I'll just use the age trip just because I was there, but I was limited to that. You're actually seeing institutional clients recognize this is probably the time to increase our exposure to the equity market. So you're actually hearing very constructive things and also you're starting the year -- by the way, this is a time where active management can really start to add value in a way that was harder from sort of the beta run from 2009 on. So yes, I think you're at a point you're actually going to see, if you're a high conviction manager, you're going to continue to start to do well. So I don't know what you're putting in traditional. But clearly, international equities are high, we're seeing a lot of regional capabilities our people are interested in. So I think it's just where we are in the market cycle. And I think you're going to continue to see -- excuse me, you will begin to see much more commitment to active management.

componenttext: Yes. Look, I guess to think of it is the typical institutional beauty show. And obviously, you have a choice of anybody they wanted to work within the country. And it was very competitive. And as best we know, this is the largest 5/29 transfer that's happened in the industry.

componenttext: First, any early read into quarter to date flow trends, particularly given the seasonal step up we typically see in retirement accounts in the first quarter? And then related to that, I think in the past, you sort of targeted maybe 3% to 5% organic growth rate. So just assuming a more cooperative market backdrop going forward which I realize is a big assumption these days, but in that sort of environment, is that still a sort of reasonable range to expect?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll make a couple of comments and Loren can -- just so we look at that 3% to 5% organic growth rate as very achievable. And again, as Loren and I have been talking about not just the previously, we just continue to see the ongoing strength throughou
componenttext: Yes, I'll make a couple of comments and Loren can -- just so we look at that 3% to 5% organic growth rate as very achievable. And again, as Loren and I have been talking about not just the previously, we just continue to see the ongoing strength throughout the regions both retail and institutional. So we think that is fully in place. You're now talking about a few weeks into January very, very hard to anticipate the quarter, quite frankly. And this week's a whole lot better than the first week in January. So I wish I could give you some great insights, I really can't. That said, I do know and more made this point very clear the institutional investors are continuing to move forward. The retail investors tend to be more risk on, risk off, depending on the daily movement in the markets. Although it feels like that's calming down. It's probably the best I could describe at the moment.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then sort of, if we focus on the kind of alternatives bucket net flows have been consistently positive for a number of years. I know the real estate business represents a big chunk of those assets. But there's also a number of different strategies that are in there. So just wondering if you could sort of give us a sense of where you're seeing the best growth opportunities. And then as it relates to fee rates, any sort of color there? Because I think the range and the respective the rates in that bucket can be pretty wide.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Michael I think probably in terms of what we're seeing, probably in the fourth quarter is GTR. I mean, it just continues to grow. I think it's at -- brought in about $1.5 billion in net flows in the fourth quarter. It's about $11 billion in total, size
componenttext: So Michael I think probably in terms of what we're seeing, probably in the fourth quarter is GTR. I mean, it just continues to grow. I think it's at -- brought in about $1.5 billion in net flows in the fourth quarter. It's about $11 billion in total, size to date. So that is one certainly outside the U.S. that's really taken on a lot of good momentum. And I think the product that it competes with in the marketplace had some issues around its performance. And so the position is even better, probably now than it's ever been. Still early days in the U.S. for us. And so we'd like nothing more to see GTR sort of reach its appropriate timeframe and sort of get through all the hurdles that it needed to get through to be on that platform. I think that and real estate, and then perhaps as well alternative fixed income assets is still an area where we believe we can play at a much more significant level than we had in the past. And there are a lot of products that are still sort of early days in terms of their track record. So I think it's really GTR and real estate right now are the primary drivers for us and where the demand is.

componenttext: Yes, so that was a period of time where we were warehousing partners of interest before they were put into a vehicle for our clients. But there was just again some exposure to a pretty volatile market. And that's what you saw.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think you'll see that we had about $1.85 billion in total, cash at the end of the quarter. The amount that is required from a regulatory perspective in the U.K. and continental Europe is around $550 million. So we're at [ph] $1.3 billion in excess of
componenttext: So I think you'll see that we had about $1.85 billion in total, cash at the end of the quarter. The amount that is required from a regulatory perspective in the U.K. and continental Europe is around $550 million. So we're at [ph] $1.3 billion in excess of our rig capital requirements. We talked about it in the past that we want to be at least $1 billion. So again, we're feeling strong in terms of our cash position and our ability to use our capital to benefit our clients. Probably better than we have in the long time. With that said, assets of drought the little bit and so cash flow is definitely having some -- there's some impact our operating cash they are. But overall, we're feeling very, very strong and optimistic about our ability to deploy our capital for the benefit of our shareholders in terms of return of capital.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very helpful, Loren. And just a follow-up on Jemstep. I just want to how this business will function? How it will generate profits and sort of what really attracted you this business?
componenttext: Very helpful, Loren. And just a follow-up on Jemstep. I just want to how this business will function? How it will generate profits and sort of what really attracted you this business?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well what's the attraction and as I said, we -- our view is it's a mistake not to pay attention to what's going on in the digital world. It's really easy to just ignore it. We think that's a mistake. That's why we went and spent some really good time
componenttext: Yes, well what's the attraction and as I said, we -- our view is it's a mistake not to pay attention to what's going on in the digital world. It's really easy to just ignore it. We think that's a mistake. That's why we went and spent some really good time researching what is happening. And we came to the conclusion that a digital mobile tool that could help us with our distribution partners would be a very wise thing to do. It's a simple thought of that. And it'll be a combination of, and I don't want to get into pricing on Jemstep or there'll be a combination of banks that be thinkable be accretive if you want to call it in the organization. First of all, the most important thing is we'll deepen our relationships with our clients, we'll be able to do better jobs with our clients. We'll be able to offer more effectively the broader range of investment capabilities we have to our clients. And those at the end of that they will ultimately result in increased assets under management if we again -- if you have outperforming et cetera all the obvious. But we think that's the fundamental thoughts of why we thought Jemstep was very important development for us.

componenttext: First also on capital management. We're getting to the point in the year where I think you'll be recommending to the Board the dividend increase for the coming year. In recent years the dividend increase has been particularly big. But given where the stock price is, how are you thinking about the kind of the mix of capital returns between dividend and buyback as we look forward to the next year?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Ken. I think it's probably not great for us to be talking about this in advance before our discussion with our board. But generally I think our sense is a little bit more modest. A modest dividend could be appropriate. In light of the fact that, that
componenttext: Hey, Ken. I think it's probably not great for us to be talking about this in advance before our discussion with our board. But generally I think our sense is a little bit more modest. A modest dividend could be appropriate. In light of the fact that, that would free up more capital for buybacks, which I think that given the market pricing of our stock may be the better way to use that cash. But again, we need to wait before we get in front of our board before we get the signal or anything quite honestly.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And I guess, just little ones. The pound hedge, the pound obviously, fell a lot in 2015. I can't really tell how much you made at the end of the day on that. It only said in your release are hedged up to March. I thought you were actually hedge
componenttext: Thank you. And I guess, just little ones. The pound hedge, the pound obviously, fell a lot in 2015. I can't really tell how much you made at the end of the day on that. It only said in your release are hedged up to March. I thought you were actually hedged up to may. How are you thinking about the currency asked you think about 2016. And actually what they do end up making in 2016 on it?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, great question. So the hedges you know is instructed, the hedges were such a 1.93 that is reflective of the average rate for the quarter. And so there was no quarter in 2015 that had a rate that averaged below 1.493. So we made nothing this year or l
componenttext: Yes, great question. So the hedges you know is instructed, the hedges were such a 1.93 that is reflective of the average rate for the quarter. And so there was no quarter in 2015 that had a rate that averaged below 1.493. So we made nothing this year or last year in 2015. The current quarter hedge is definitely in the money. And again -- so again, more to come on what the value there is. It's moving around. But that's certainly something you would see at this noticeable number. We are expecting to hedge our currency going forward around the pound in particular. We believe that the pound is potentially going to be still a little volatile in light -- especially with the bright discussions that are going on. And so those are -- again, as we've done in the past the hedges we put in place that would be out of the money puts that really would protect us from the downside allow upside to occur. And again, would protect our cash flow in particular as opposed to our operating results which we can freely protect against.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A few questions on PowerShares. Are you guys seeing any fee pressure at all in that business? And then sort of related to that, given how competitive smart data and that it keeps getting more and more competitive, do you think ultimately, we might see pre
componenttext: A few questions on PowerShares. Are you guys seeing any fee pressure at all in that business? And then sort of related to that, given how competitive smart data and that it keeps getting more and more competitive, do you think ultimately, we might see pressure in that area? So a couple of things. I think when you want to think about us, think about it beyond smart beta. It's really factor investing. So one of the delivery mechanisms are PowerShares ETFs. But factor investment team, but really the Quad T we're seeing real demand for factor investing both outside of the United States both retail and institutional. Institutional in particular in Europe institutional particular in Asia. And we've been doing it for 20 years. And I think the other thing if you look at the PowerShares lineup, what is important is that differently than mutual funds, you really can't have more than maybe 3 in a category. So there is this first mover advantage topic within ETFs. It's something very, very real. And if you look at the length of the time that our smartbeta ETFs have done in the market, they have liquidity. They have real track records. And when you're the incumbent then denier in a really strong position. We think other people coming to the smart beta area. It's some confirmation that it's a better way to create exposure to passive. And again, we're seeing continued strength within power share and in particular investing outside the United States.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My one follow up would be on the cost optimization plan. Can you guys give us a little bit more detail about what those costs really are. I mean, is it a combination of project spending and layoff comp? Or is it something else? And then sort of rela
componenttext: Okay. My one follow up would be on the cost optimization plan. Can you guys give us a little bit more detail about what those costs really are. I mean, is it a combination of project spending and layoff comp? Or is it something else? And then sort of related to that, I'm wondering why the spending is taking sort of a -- it's sort of back end loaded, if you will. headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Invesco's Fourth Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Now I'd like to turn the call over to your speakers for today, Mr. Mart
componenttext: Welcome to Invesco's Fourth Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Now I'd like to turn the call over to your speakers for today, Mr. Martin L. Flanagan, President and CEO of Invesco; and Mr. Loren Starr, Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Flanagan, you may begin.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, and thank you everybody for joining Loren and myself. And I'll briefly review the 2015 highlights before getting into the review of the business results for the fourth quarter. And then Loren will go into more depth of the financial r
componenttext:
Thank you very much, and thank you everybody for joining Loren and myself. And I'll briefly review the 2015 highlights before getting into the review of the business results for the fourth quarter. And then Loren will go into more depth of the financial results. And then of course, we'll open up to Q&A as we always do.
So let me start by providing a brief overview of the operating results for the full year and if you're so inclined, I'm on Page 3 of the presentation. Long-term investment performance remained very strong in 2015. 79% and 85% of actively managed assets were ahead of peers over 3 years and 5 years, respectively, at the end of the fourth quarter.
Strong investment performance, combined with a comprehensive range of strategies and solutions we offer, help clients achieve their desired investment objectives, contributed to long-term net inflows of $16.2 billion for the year. Our efforts to deliver for clients while taking a disciplined approach to managing our business resulted in an operating margin of 41% for the full year, off just slightly from the very strong prior year.
The annual dividend totaled $1.08 per share, which represents an 8% increase over the prior year. We also returned more than $1 billion to shareholders during 2015 through dividends and stock buybacks. Assets under management were $775 billion at the end of 2015, down from $792 billion at the end of the prior year, mostly reflecting some late year volatility.
Average assets under management were $794 billion for 2015 versus $790 billion for 2014. Adjusted earnings per share for the year were $2.44 versus $2.51 in the prior year. As you can see on Slide 4, foreign exchange had a significant impact, diluting earnings per share by $0.15 per share from the prior year. During 2015, Fitch upgraded the firm's credit rating to positive outlook, and we repurchased $549 million worth of stock.
So let me take a moment and look back over the achievements over the past year, which will provide insights into our continued long-range plans. First and foremost, of course, we remained focused on delivering strong long-term investment performance, which continue the drive to grow our business. And as I mentioned, 79% and 85% of the assets were ahead of peers on a 3-year and 5-year basis, respectively, at the end of 2015.
By delivering strong investment performance and focusing on clients' needs, we achieved further growth across the business. In the U.S., Invesco was the only firm to appear in the top 5 over 1, 5 and 10 years in the Barron's Best Fund Families annual ranking. Our Asia Pacific business continued to grow, and we saw strong inflows in the range of strategies resulting in net sales of $5.7 billion, the strongest showing in the region since 2011.
Institutional sales of $14.2 billion nearly doubled the prior year. We also saw continued growth in our EMEA business, driven by a focus on delivering strong investment performance in meeting our client needs. Cross-border and institutional were particularly strong with $7 billion and $4.5 billion in net inflows, respectively. And we remain in a very dominant position in the United Kingdom.
We continue to invest in capabilities where we see strong client demand or future opportunities by hiring world-class talent, upgrading our technology platforms, launching new products and providing additional resources where necessary in 2015. The ability to leverage the capabilities developed by our investment teams to meet client demand across the globe is a significant differentiator for our firm and will continue to bring the best of Invesco to different parts of our business where it makes sense for our clients.
By delivering strong investment performance, Invesco Global Targeted Return achieved strong flows in its second year of offering with assets under management surpassing $11 billion globally at the end of the year. We continued to invest and strengthen our Fixed Income platform in 2015, which is enhancing our ability to meet our client needs. We also invested in our institutional business in 2015, refining our global strategy, bringing on additional highly regarded talent and more effectively aligning ourselves to the opportunities in the marketplace.
We are seeing some early successes from this work. Institutional flows during the first quarter were amongst the strongest in the past several quarters in spite of the very volatile markets. We're very focused on bringing together the full range of our capabilities to help meet our client investment objectives. Rhode Island mandate of $7.2 billion is an example of the success we're achieving with our Invesco solutions effort.
Throughout the year, we continue to innovate and expand the range of alternative products we offer, leveraging our strong themes and capabilities for the benefit of our clients globally. 2 years ago, we began leveraging our presence in China to explore and better understand the opportunities in digital and mobile technologies in the marketplace. We've also been exploring the possibilities with market-leading firms in Silicon Valley. Our acquisition of Jemstep in mid-January is an outcome of this research. Jemstep is one of the first digital platforms to focus exclusively on advisers and is a market-leading provider of adviser-focused digital solutions.
The Invesco-Jemstep platform enables Wealth Management home offices and their advisers with a full suite of technology solutions that are highly flexible, customizable and easily integrated into their existing systems. This acquisition represents an investment in our partnership with the advice community and highlights our efforts to participate in technology evolution within our industry.
Turning to the fourth quarter. Let me take a moment to highlight the results, which you'll find on Slide 8. Strong investment performance contributed to long-term net inflows of $3.9 billion for the quarter. Adjusted operating margin for the quarter was 40.1% versus 41.4% in the prior quarter. Quarterly dividend remained at $0.27 per share. We also returned $329 million to shareholders during the quarter through dividends and stock buybacks. Assets under management were $775 billion at the end of the fourth quarter compared to $755 billion we reported in the prior quarter.
Operating income was $356 million in the quarter, down from $373 million in the prior quarter, reflecting a very volatile quarter -- markets we saw in the quarter. Earnings per share were $0.58 versus $0.61 in the prior quarter. We repurchased $214 million of stock during the quarter, representing 6.5 million shares. Turning to Page 11 and looking at investment performance. As I mentioned, during the quarter, it continued to be quite strong with 79% of the assets in the top half over 3-year basis and 85% were in the top half on a 5-year basis.
We also saw improvement in the 1 year number, which was 60% of assets leading peers. Turning to flows on Page 12. You'll see that active and passive flows were positive during the volatile quarter. Active flows during the quarter were driven by a variety of capabilities, including Global Targeted Return, investment-grade fixed income, real estate and quantitative equities to name a few.
Passive flows were positive with renewed strength in Invesco PowerShares ETF which saw net inflows of $2 billion. These flows were offset by $1.2 billion outflows associated with the Invesco mortgage capital deleveraging. This did have an impact across a number of categories. If you look at passive institutional fixed income in the U.S. and if you add $1.2 billion in each of those categories, you'll eliminate the impact of the deleveraging of the Invesco mortgage capital during that quarter.
Retail flows were relatively flat during the quarter, impacted by the macroenvironment as investors weighed their options during the very volatile quarter. Institutional flows were particularly strong, driven by inflows in the fixed income, real estate and reflecting our continued focus on this part of the business. The pipeline of one but not funded mandate remains at near all-time highs and is up more than 28% versus the prior year. Notably, this excludes the previous announced $7.2 billion Rhode Island 529 win, which is expected to fund sometime in the third quarter.
We feel good about the results for the year on the fourth quarter, and it puts us in a strong position heading into a volatile year, 2016. Continued strong investment performance, our focus on meeting client needs contributed solid operating results despite a very volatile environment. We continue to see strength across the global business, in particular in Asia Pacific and EMEA. Our focus remains on strengthening our efforts to deliver strong long-term results and help clients meet their investment objectives and enhancing our comprehensive range of capabilities.
But given the very volatile markets, we are taking a disciplined approach to managing our business, balancing our goals of reinvesting the business for the benefit of clients with the need to run our business effectively and efficiently as we have in past very volatile markets. I'd now like to turn the call over to Loren to go through the financials in more depth.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty. Quarter-over-quarter, our total assets under management increased $19.8 billion or 2.6%. This was driven by market returns of $21 billion, long-term net inflows of $3.9 billion and inflows from the Qs of $2 billion, offset by negative FX tr
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty. Quarter-over-quarter, our total assets under management increased $19.8 billion or 2.6%. This was driven by market returns of $21 billion, long-term net inflows of $3.9 billion and inflows from the Qs of $2 billion, offset by negative FX translation of $5.3 billion and outflows from money market of $1.8 billion. Our average AUM for the fourth quarter was $783.7 billion, that was down 0.7% versus the third quarter.
Our net revenue yield came in at 45.2 basis points with a decrease of 0.6 basis points versus Q3. FX translation reduced the yield by 0.4 basis points and change in mix reduced the yield by another 0.4 basis points. These impacts were offset by an increase in performance fees and other revenues in the quarter, which in combination added 0.2 basis points.
Next, let's turn to the operating results. You'll see that net revenues declined by $16.9 million or 1.9% quarter-over-quarter to $886.1 million, which includes a negative FX rate impact of $8.1 million. Within the net revenue number, you'll see that investment management fees fell by $29.3 million or 2.8% to $1.01 billion. This reflects the lower average AUM during the quarter as well as changes in the AUM product and currency mix.
Foreign exchange decreased fourth quarter management fees by $10.1 million. Service and distribution revenue decreased by $7.2 million or 3.4%, again, reflecting the change in mix and lower average AUM during the quarter. FX reduced service and distribution revenue by $0.1 million. Performance fees came in at $18.8 million in Q4, and this was earned from a variety of different investment capabilities, including $9.8 million from real estate and $3.2 million from U.K. equities.
Foreign exchange decreased performance fees by $0.1 million. Other revenues in the fourth quarter were $29 million, an increase of $1.4 million, driven by higher real estate transaction fees. Foreign exchange decreased other revenues by $0.1 million. Reported distribution service and advisory expense, which we net against gross revenues, fell by $17 million or 4.3%. This movement was in line with our lower retail management fees and service and distribution revenues.
Foreign exchange decreased these expenses by $2.3 million. Moving on down the slide, you'll see that our adjusted operating expenses at $530.4 million increased by $0.8 million or 0.2% relative to the third quarter. Foreign exchange decreased operating expenses by $3.9 million during the quarter. Employee compensation came in at $338.8 million, a decline of $8.1 million or 2.3%. This was due to lower incentive compensation for the quarter. FX reduced compensation by $2.3 million.
Marketing expenses increased by $8.8 million or 34% to $34.6 million. This is a function of seasonally higher expenditures for advertising and other marketing costs particularly in EMEA. FX reduced marketing expense by $0.4 million in the quarter. Property, office and technology expenses were $80.4 million in the quarter, an increase of $0.5 million over the third quarter. FX decreasing expenses by $0.5 million.
General, administrative expenses came in at $76.6 million, and that fell by $0.4 million or 0.5 percentage point. FX decreased G&A by $0.7 million. Going on further down the slide, you'll see that nonoperating income decreased $2.3 million compared to the third quarter. Included in the fourth quarter were a $7.3 million loss on the disposition of private equity partnership interest as well as a $2 million mark to market on seed money investments. These were offset by gains from consolidated sponsored investment products compared to a loss in the prior quarter.
In terms of effective tax rate. Our pretax adjusted net income in Q4 was 26.6%, up slightly from 26.5% in the prior quarter, which then takes us to our adjusted EPS of $0.58 and our adjusted net operating margin of 40.1%. Now before I turn things back to Marty, I'd like to provide a little more detail on the business optimization work that we began implementing in Q4 in light of the current market volatility and as well as in light of our lower AUM levels.
We believe this optimization work will make Invesco an even stronger company, further increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of our operating platform. The business optimization work that's underway is primarily focused on our use of shared service centers, outsourcing, automation and office location strategy. In the fourth quarter U.S. GAAP results, we recognized $16.2 million of expenses primarily in the form of staff severance costs, and we expect costs associated with the optimization initiative to continue through 2016. Total costs for 2016 are estimated to be up to $85 million.
Reducing our run rate operating expenses in 2016 and in future years is an important outcome of this work. And we expect the outgoing benefits of this project will be well in excess of the projected onetime implementation costs I just discussed. We anticipate the project will achieve cash payback within less than 3 years, and it will add an estimated 3 to -- I'm sorry, $0.06 to $0.08 EPS accretion in fiscal year 2017 and beyond. 
Finally, in terms of reporting and consistent with our past approach to dealing with material one-off expenses, the incremental optimization charges will continue to be adjusted out of our non-GAAP presentation but will be detailed and tracked each quarter in the U.S. GAAP reconciliation table within the earnings release. Additionally, we'll provide you updated estimates of the implementation costs and benefits of this initiative to the extent that these change in any material way.
The one additional item for me to note is that new for this quarter, we've included a schedule detailing the impact that the change in foreign exchange rates had on our non-GAAP operating results and expenses for the quarter. The amounts presented on Slide 17 represent the impact of the change and exchange rate movement in the quarter and the year and were calculated by applying the prior period FX rates to the current period's non-U.S. dollar earnings. Going forward, the schedule will be included each quarter and can be found in the appendix of our earnings presentations. And with that, I will now turn it back to Marty.

componenttextpreview: Maybe just first on the flows in the quarter and then I guess, the outlook, it seems like a lot of the strength, Marty, you highlighted, you're coming from the institutional side of the business and then Asia. You mentioned the pipeline near at all-time h
componenttext: Maybe just first on the flows in the quarter and then I guess, the outlook, it seems like a lot of the strength, Marty, you highlighted, you're coming from the institutional side of the business and then Asia. You mentioned the pipeline near at all-time highs. Just wanted to get a sense from a mix standpoint, what's driving maybe that pipeline? And then when we think about it, maybe for Loren, like from a mix shift on products, obviously, the market or the beta side is having an impact for everyone. But just wanted to try to get a sense on how that pipeline is relative to the current mix or the fee rate.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll be happy to pick that up, Mike. So the pipeline is being driven really in 4 big buckets. Probably one of the biggest is direct real estate. It's probably 30% of the pipeline. It continues to be a strong driver. Fixed income generally across a broa
componenttext: So I'll be happy to pick that up, Mike. So the pipeline is being driven really in 4 big buckets. Probably one of the biggest is direct real estate. It's probably 30% of the pipeline. It continues to be a strong driver. Fixed income generally across a broad Fixed Income. Alternative Fixed Income, stable value. It's probably another 30%. And then the remainder is split between asset allocation and multi-asset solutions. And then the quantitative and regional equities would be others. So it's fairly well diversified and generally high fee. And so when we look at the fee rate of the pipeline, it's actually at one of the highest levels we've ever seen it. It's well above our current net revenue yields for the firm as a whole. And so as these assets come in, it will be accretive to our fee rates, which is great news. Obviously, the negative that we've seen in our fee rate is due to the compression on equities just given what's happened in the market and then foreign exchange has also had an impact as well. But in terms of the mix overall in the pipeline, the institutional pipeline, we think it's very positive for our fee rates.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I don't know if I could add much to it other than it is a part of the business where we've turned our attention. It's really seemingly getting stronger and stronger, frankly, in each region of the world: in the Americas, in EMEA and in Asia Pacifi
componenttext: Yes. So I don't know if I could add much to it other than it is a part of the business where we've turned our attention. It's really seemingly getting stronger and stronger, frankly, in each region of the world: in the Americas, in EMEA and in Asia Pacific. And it is really quite broad-based. So it's a very positive.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other thing I would just mention, I mean we would expect our fee rate, I mean, given stability in assets and stability in FX to grow across 2016.
componenttext: And the other thing I would just mention, I mean we would expect our fee rate, I mean, given stability in assets and stability in FX to grow across 2016.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then just a quick follow-up. Loren, usually or sometimes you'll give some guidance just on like the expense lines. And I don't know if it's because of some of the work that you guys are doing, the streamlining expenses as you get
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just a quick follow-up. Loren, usually or sometimes you'll give some guidance just on like the expense lines. And I don't know if it's because of some of the work that you guys are doing, the streamlining expenses as you get into '17. But just any, I guess, color, I think comp, you typically had the 1Q seasonality, but maybe the marketing, you have some 4Q seasonality. So any color on the expense outlook, just given the volatility of the markets right now.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'd say given the volatility, we're probably going to not give any explicit guidance around line items at this stage. There's a lot of work, obviously, that I discussed being done around some of this optimization work, which will have some impacts on
componenttext: Yes. I'd say given the volatility, we're probably going to not give any explicit guidance around line items at this stage. There's a lot of work, obviously, that I discussed being done around some of this optimization work, which will have some impacts on those line items as well. Generally, we're working hard to bring expenses down, right? As you can imagine, year-over-year decline in expenses, our compensation generally moves and flexes in line with operating income, so those will be down. Some of the optimization work especially around -- we just mentioned some of the severance will also help bring some of the compensation line down. But the benefits of the optimization work will probably spread across most of the other categories of the marketing explicitly. We're looking at marketing. That's another interesting topic for us. It is one of these conundrums, when you're in this market, your clients want to hear from you and you want to be out with them. But at the same time, it certainly is a discretionary expense, and it's one that we're continuing to look at. So I'd say we're obviously going to be very vigilant to making sure that we manage expenses very smartly in this environment with no presumption of snapback or some reversal. The other thing I would like to just mention, there is some impact just due to the acquisitions that we discussed in terms of Jemstep and in terms of Religare, after management completing our 100% ownership there. It's absolutely immaterial in terms of the earnings impact, so you don't have to worry about EPS impacts. But it does add probably roughly $15 million of expense and a little bit more in revenue in 2016. So you'll see some of those line items go up just as a result of those acquisitions but offset by, obviously, higher levels of revenues. So we don't want anyone to be surprised by that. The optimization work that we're doing should have a benefit in 2016 that you'll see. So again, we'll quantify that as we get through it. But that will help drive expenses down year-over-year.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just add to Loren's point. I mean, we feel like we're really quite capable at this, and if you look at our history, we use these volatile periods to really take advantage of opportunities as they show up. It is a period where I think '16 for
componenttext: Yes, I would just add to Loren's point. I mean, we feel like we're really quite capable at this, and if you look at our history, we use these volatile periods to really take advantage of opportunities as they show up. It is a period where I think '16 for the industry is going to be quite interesting, where clients will be looking for those firms that are in a position of strength. And we are one of those firms, and we feel we're operating from a position of strength right now. And so we're going to be very responsible on the expense side, but we have some real opportunities that we want to continue to advance at the same time. So that's what we're working through, and we'll continue to make sure that we're communicating very clearly with everybody.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Daniel Fannon of Jefferies.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
