headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's cool. And then a question on Jemstep. I saw your details and rationale for growth in the slides. I just had a follow-up question. How do you expect the distributors to use it? And then more importantly, how do you differentiate? Because I'm
componenttext: Got it. That's cool. And then a question on Jemstep. I saw your details and rationale for growth in the slides. I just had a follow-up question. How do you expect the distributors to use it? And then more importantly, how do you differentiate? Because I'm assuming there's going to be many large asset managers having their version and maybe even the distributors doing their own version. I'm just curious. Is this an early mover advantage that you make their lives easier? Just curious how you expect that to shape up.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a great question. So I think you're going to -- and we are expecting the large distributors will have some version of their own. That's historically what they've done in the past. We've still contacted them and -- but that would be our -- what
componenttext: Yes, that's a great question. So I think you're going to -- and we are expecting the large distributors will have some version of their own. That's historically what they've done in the past. We've still contacted them and -- but that would be our -- what we would anticipate. It's really just sort of the other channels, though, there's a high degree of interest in this. And really, what it is, it's just us partnering up with our distribution partners. And the more effective we can be with them at the end of the day, that's a good thing for their clients and for us also. I don't believe that they're going to be -- let me say it the other way. I believe strongly there is a first-mover advantage to this because, quite frankly, multiple distribution partners are not going to have multiple, 3, 4, 5, 6, 10 of these within the system; they don't need it. And it's like any other application; it's education and investment to move that forward. So that is our other core belief.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: To that end, is that your point with the -- we have 300 people on the ground, selling and educating as we speak?
componenttext: To that end, is that your point with the -- we have 300 people on the ground, selling and educating as we speak?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. Last one, Loren. With the cash balances hitting your internal hurdles and the valuation, in my words, at a ridiculous level, how do you think about the payout ratio relative to the past? Like, can we start seeing 100% payouts even though you h
componenttext: Okay, good. Last one, Loren. With the cash balances hitting your internal hurdles and the valuation, in my words, at a ridiculous level, how do you think about the payout ratio relative to the past? Like, can we start seeing 100% payouts even though you have a lot of things going on?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you saw something probably very close to that this last quarter. So again, we certainly have demonstrated our willingness to respond when the stock is, as you call, ridiculously low. And we would tend to agree with you on that one, just give
componenttext: Well, I think you saw something probably very close to that this last quarter. So again, we certainly have demonstrated our willingness to respond when the stock is, as you call, ridiculously low. And we would tend to agree with you on that one, just given our sense of optimism around our ability to grow over the long term. So you should expect us to continue to pay a lot of attention. Our needs for internal organic growth, seedings and so forth, are still pretty sizable. A lot of opportunities, so we need to balance those against returning capital. But you should certainly expect us to be operating in the stock buyback realm in a nonbusiness as usual approach, which is somewhat similar to what you've seen in the fourth quarter. Maybe not at that full level but something between business as usual and what you've seen us do.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we have Mr. Bill Katz of Citi.
componenttext: Next, we have Mr. Bill Katz of Citi.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just trying to reconcile some of the numbers on the optimization program you delineated a bit, Loren. You mentioned that you're spending, I guess, roughly $100 million between the charge in the fourth quarter and then what you expect for this year and sor
componenttext: Just trying to reconcile some of the numbers on the optimization program you delineated a bit, Loren. You mentioned that you're spending, I guess, roughly $100 million between the charge in the fourth quarter and then what you expect for this year and sort of within a 3-year payback. $0.06 to $0.08 accretion in '17. Is it accretive to non-GAAP earnings for '16? And the reason I'm asking is I guess you're going to run the expenses through the GAAP line. And I presume if it's a 3-year recovery, either you're really back-ended in '18 or you would get some pretty sizable savings this year as well. I'm just trying to figure out the cash flows.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the execution of the optimization is going to happen all through 2016. So the 3-year payback is really going to be in -- at full throttle in 2017 and beyond. We will get savings in 2016 probably somewhere around $15 million is what our non-GAAP run rat
componenttext: So the execution of the optimization is going to happen all through 2016. So the 3-year payback is really going to be in -- at full throttle in 2017 and beyond. We will get savings in 2016 probably somewhere around $15 million is what our non-GAAP run rate, positive impact would be or is what we expect, and that would certainly ramp up significantly into 2017 and on. So again, our estimate is based on what we know today, based on the activities that we're engaged in today. But we're going to be pretty -- we do believe that it will be no more than $85 million in terms of what is required for us to implement that long-term run rate savings, which, again, is somewhere $30 million to $45 million in run rate cost savings post 2017.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then, Marty, or maybe both of you guys, you gave a nice delineation also, by region and by product. But the one area that seemed to sort of not be within that list was more traditional equity mandates. What are you hearing from cl
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then, Marty, or maybe both of you guys, you gave a nice delineation also, by region and by product. But the one area that seemed to sort of not be within that list was more traditional equity mandates. What are you hearing from clients on the institutional side? Is there still more of this barbell notion? Or is there any sort of interest in more traditional plain vanilla type of mandates?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So there are actually. I mean, again, I'll just use the Asia trip just because I was there, but I wouldn't limit it to there. I mean, you're actually seeing institutional clients recognize that this is probably the time to increase their exposure to
componenttext: Yes. So there are actually. I mean, again, I'll just use the Asia trip just because I was there, but I wouldn't limit it to there. I mean, you're actually seeing institutional clients recognize that this is probably the time to increase their exposure to the equity market. So you're actually hearing very constructive things, and also you're starting to hear, by the way, this is a time where active management can really start to add value in a way that was harder from sort of the beta run from 2009 on. So yes, I think you're at a point where you're actually going to see, if you're a high-conviction manager, you're going to continue to start to do well. So I don't know what you put in traditional. But clearly, international equities are high. We're seeing a lot of the regional capabilities people are interested in. So I think it's just where we are in the market cycle. And I think you're going to continue to see -- excuse me, you will begin to see much more commitment to active management.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we have Mr. Patrick Davitt of Autonomous.
componenttext: Next, we have Mr. Patrick Davitt of Autonomous.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then two, I imagine that a pool of capital like this has a pretty sticky inflow stream. Is that the case? And if so, can you kind of help us frame what the organic growth of it has been kind of over the last few years?
componenttext: Yes. And then two, I imagine that a pool of capital like this has a pretty sticky inflow stream. Is that the case? And if so, can you kind of help us frame what the organic growth of it has been kind of over the last few years?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a very good question. I don't think I'll have a satisfactory answer. What I would say is that their first decision was to engage us to meet the program of the investment objective they had in place. That was their first desire. Secondly, they recogni
componenttext: It's a very good question. I don't think I'll have a satisfactory answer. What I would say is that their first decision was to engage us to meet the program of the investment objective they had in place. That was their first desire. Secondly, they recognize the depth and breadth of our retail distribution capability with some very important distribution partners throughout the country. And so their anticipation of growth in the plan is part of what their decision was. And obviously, we're very interested in it. And we think it will be a new channel for us, and we think we'll be quite successful with it. And I guess, the other way to put it in context, and again, I don't have the -- they were successful enough to become, I think it's the third largest 529 plan in the country. And we would look for growth to be stronger than what it had been in the past.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would agree with your characterization about it being sticky, as long as performance and everything else continues, right?
componenttext: Yes. And I would agree with your characterization about it being sticky, as long as performance and everything else continues, right?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And finally, I guess just on that, again, was this kind of a broad kind of beauty show? What was kind of the decision process in terms of...
componenttext: And finally, I guess just on that, again, was this kind of a broad kind of beauty show? What was kind of the decision process in terms of...

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, look, you have to think of it as a typical institutional beauty show. And obviously, you -- they had the choice of anybody they wanted to work with in the country, and it was very competitive. And as best we know, this is the largest 529 transfer
componenttext: Yes. No, look, you have to think of it as a typical institutional beauty show. And obviously, you -- they had the choice of anybody they wanted to work with in the country, and it was very competitive. And as best we know, this is the largest 529 transfer that's happened in the industry.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Michael Kim of Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question is from Michael Kim of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, any early read into quarter-to-date flow trends, particularly given the seasonal step up we typically see in retirement accounts in the first quarter? And then related to that, I think in the past, you sort of targeted maybe a 3% to 5% organic grow
componenttext: First, any early read into quarter-to-date flow trends, particularly given the seasonal step up we typically see in retirement accounts in the first quarter? And then related to that, I think in the past, you sort of targeted maybe a 3% to 5% organic growth rate. So just assuming a more cooperative market backdrop going forward, which I realize is a big assumption these days, but in that sort of environment, is that still sort of a reasonable range to expect?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll make a couple of comments and Loren can  -- so we still look at that 3% to 5% organic growth rate as very achievable. And again, as Loren and I have been talking about not just this, but previously, we just continue to see ongoing strength throu
componenttext: Yes. I'll make a couple of comments and Loren can  -- so we still look at that 3% to 5% organic growth rate as very achievable. And again, as Loren and I have been talking about not just this, but previously, we just continue to see ongoing strength throughout the regions, both retail and institutional. So we think that is fully in place. You're now talking about a few weeks into January, very, very hard to anticipate the quarter, quite frankly. And this week's a whole lot better than the first week in January. So I wish I could give you some great insights; I really can't. That said, I do know, and Loren made this point very clear, the institutional investors are continuing to move forward. The retail investors tend to be more risk on, risk off, depending on the daily movement in the markets. Although it feels like that's calming down, is probably the best I could describe at the moment.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I think that's about right. I would say there was a lot of risk off behavior in the early part of January, so it's getting healthier.
componenttext: Yes. No, I think that's about right. I would say there was a lot of risk off behavior in the early part of January, so it's getting healthier.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then so if we focus on kind of the alternatives bucket, net flows have been consistently positive for a number of years. I know the real estate business represents a big chunk of those assets. But there's also a number of different
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then so if we focus on kind of the alternatives bucket, net flows have been consistently positive for a number of years. I know the real estate business represents a big chunk of those assets. But there's also a number of different strategies that are in there. So just wondering if you could sort of give us a sense of where you're seeing the best growth opportunities. And then as it relates to fee rates, any sort of color there? Because I think the range of the respective fee rates within that bucket can be pretty wide.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Michael, I think the other probably even larger in terms of what we're seeing, certainly in the fourth quarter, is GTR. I mean, it just continues to grow. I think it brought in about $1.5 billion in net flows in the fourth quarter. It's about $11 billi
componenttext: So Michael, I think the other probably even larger in terms of what we're seeing, certainly in the fourth quarter, is GTR. I mean, it just continues to grow. I think it brought in about $1.5 billion in net flows in the fourth quarter. It's about $11 billion in total size to date. So that is one that, certainly outside the U.S., has really taken on a lot of good momentum. And I think the product that it competes with in the marketplace has had some issues around its performance. And so the positioning is even better probably now than it's ever been. Still early days in the U.S. for us. And so we'd like nothing more to see GTR sort of reach its appropriate time frame and sort of get through all the hurdles that we need to get through for it to be on the platform. But I think that and real estate, and then perhaps as well, alternative fixed income is still an area where we believe we can play at a much more significant level than we have in the past. And there are a lot of products that are still sort of early days in terms of their track record. So I think it's really GTR and real estate right now are the primary drivers for us and where the demand is.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then just one quick one. You mentioned or you called out the $7.3 million realized loss related to the disposition of private equity partnership interests. Can you just sort of give us some more color on exactly what that related to?
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then just one quick one. You mentioned or you called out the $7.3 million realized loss related to the disposition of private equity partnership interests. Can you just sort of give us some more color on exactly what that related to?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so that was a period of time where we were warehousing partnership interest before they were put into a vehicle for our clients. And unfortunately, the mark-to-market on that really hit us before it got into the vehicle. And so that's what that is. N
componenttext: Yes, so that was a period of time where we were warehousing partnership interest before they were put into a vehicle for our clients. And unfortunately, the mark-to-market on that really hit us before it got into the vehicle. And so that's what that is. Normally, we'd be able to get it in there faster. But there was just, again, some exposure to a pretty volatile market. And that's what you saw.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we have Mr. Craig Siegenthaler of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Next, we have Mr. Craig Siegenthaler of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was looking for a little more color in excess capital. I think, historically, you like to provide a sort of guidance here in terms of cash and investments versus long-term debt. And they're pretty close here. So could you just provide an update here? An
componenttext: I was looking for a little more color in excess capital. I think, historically, you like to provide a sort of guidance here in terms of cash and investments versus long-term debt. And they're pretty close here. So could you just provide an update here? And maybe you're pretty comfortable where it is right now.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think you'll see that we had about $1.85 billion in total cash at the end of the quarter. The amount that is required from a regulatory perspective in the U.K. and continental Europe is around $550 million. So we're about $1.3 billion in excess of ou
componenttext: So I think you'll see that we had about $1.85 billion in total cash at the end of the quarter. The amount that is required from a regulatory perspective in the U.K. and continental Europe is around $550 million. So we're about $1.3 billion in excess of our reg capital requirements. We talked about in the past that we want to be at least $1 billion. So again, we're feeling strong in terms of our cash position and our ability to use our capital to the benefit of our clients, probably better than we have in a long time. Now with that said, assets have dropped a little bit, and so our cash flow is definitely having some -- there's some impact to our operating cash there. But overall, we're feeling very, very strong and optimistic about our ability to deploy our capital for the benefit of our shareholders in terms of return of capital.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very helpful, Loren. And then just my follow-up on Jemstep. I just wanted to get a better understanding for how this business will function, how it will generate profits and sort of what really attracted you to this business.
componenttext: Very helpful, Loren. And then just my follow-up on Jemstep. I just wanted to get a better understanding for how this business will function, how it will generate profits and sort of what really attracted you to this business.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I'd probably say, what's the attraction? As I said, we -- our view is it's a mistake not to pay attention to what's going on in the digital world, and it's really easy to just ignore it. We think that's a mistake. That's why we went and spent s
componenttext: Yes, well, I'd probably say, what's the attraction? As I said, we -- our view is it's a mistake not to pay attention to what's going on in the digital world, and it's really easy to just ignore it. We think that's a mistake. That's why we went and spent some real good time researching what is happening. And we came to the conclusion that a digital mobile tool that could help us with our distribution partners would be a very wise thing to do. It's a simple a thought as that. And there will be a combination of -- and I don't want to get into the pricing on Jemstep, but there'll be a combination of things that we think will be accretive, if you want to call it, to the organization. First of all, the most important thing is we'll have deeper relationships with our clients. We'll be able to do a better job with our clients. We'll be able to offer more effectively the broader range of investment capabilities we have to our clients. And those, at the end of the day, will ultimately result in increased assets under management if we, again, -- you have to be performing, et cetera, all the obvious. But we think that's the fundamental thoughts of why we thought Jemstep was very important development for us.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we have Mr. Ken Worthington of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Next, we have Mr. Ken Worthington of JPMorgan.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, also on capital management. We're getting to the point in the year where I think you'll be recommending to the board the dividend increase for the coming year. In recent years, the dividend increase has been particularly big. But given where the st
componenttext: First, also on capital management. We're getting to the point in the year where I think you'll be recommending to the board the dividend increase for the coming year. In recent years, the dividend increase has been particularly big. But given where the stock price is, how are you thinking about the kind of the mix of capital return between dividend and buyback as we look forward to the next year?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, I think it's probably not great for us to be talking about this in advance of our discussion with our board. But generally, it's -- I think our sense is a bit more modest. A modest dividend could be appropriate, right, in light of the fact that, that
componenttext: Ken, I think it's probably not great for us to be talking about this in advance of our discussion with our board. But generally, it's -- I think our sense is a bit more modest. A modest dividend could be appropriate, right, in light of the fact that, that would free up more capital for buybacks, which I think, given the market pricing of our stock, may be the better way to use that cash. But again, we need to wait before we get in front of our board before we put a signal anything, quite honestly.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just little ones. The pound hedge. The pound, obviously, fell a lot in 2015. I couldn't really tell how much you made at the end of the day on that. It also said in your release you're hedged out to March. I thought you were actually hedged out t
componenttext: And then just little ones. The pound hedge. The pound, obviously, fell a lot in 2015. I couldn't really tell how much you made at the end of the day on that. It also said in your release you're hedged out to March. I thought you were actually hedged out to May. How are you thinking about hedging out the currency as we think about 2016? And actually, what did you actually end up making in 2015 on it?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, great question. So the hedge, as you know, is -- those hedges were structured at 1.493. That is reflective to the average rate for the quarter. And so there was no quarter in 2015 that had a rate that averaged below 1.493. So we made nothing this yea
componenttext: Yes, great question. So the hedge, as you know, is -- those hedges were structured at 1.493. That is reflective to the average rate for the quarter. And so there was no quarter in 2015 that had a rate that averaged below 1.493. So we made nothing this year -- or last year, in 2015. The current quarter hedge is definitely in the money. And again -- so again, more to come on what the value there is. It's moving around. But it's certainly something you would see at this rate as noticeably -- noticeable number. We are expecting to hedge our currency going forward, around the pound in particular. And we believe that the pound is potentially going to be still a little volatile in light -- especially with the Brexit discussions that are going on. And so those are, again, as we've done in the past, the hedges we'd put in place, that would be out-of-the-money puts, that really would protect us from the downside, allow upside to occur and, again, would protect our cash flow in particular as opposed to our operating results, which we can't really protect against.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we have Brennan Hawken of UBS.
componenttext: Next, we have Brennan Hawken of UBS.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been asked and answered. Just one left. As far as the U.S. equity performance, we saw some deterioration here this quarter. Could you speak to that? And I think that you referenced last quarter that there was some loading up in e
componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked and answered. Just one left. As far as the U.S. equity performance, we saw some deterioration here this quarter. Could you speak to that? And I think that you referenced last quarter that there was some loading up in energy stocks. Did that play a part here?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It did. And again, my perspective on that is overall, the performance is still very, very strong and is very short term in nature. And frankly, it did improve last quarter to this quarter. But it's, then again, it's all very short term. But moving into th
componenttext: It did. And again, my perspective on that is overall, the performance is still very, very strong and is very short term in nature. And frankly, it did improve last quarter to this quarter. But it's, then again, it's all very short term. But moving into this year, it just continued to strengthen. So those portfolios that have the energy exposure, we think they're placed very, very well, and they're going to do -- ultimately do very, very well for clients.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, the one thing I would say is that the improvement that we saw in the 1-year numbers relative to Q3 were due to our small cap growth equity team as well as our growth and income product. So there were definitely some equity capabilities that saw im
componenttext: I mean, the one thing I would say is that the improvement that we saw in the 1-year numbers relative to Q3 were due to our small cap growth equity team as well as our growth and income product. So there were definitely some equity capabilities that saw improvement in the quarter relative to the last quarter.

componenttext: A few questions on PowerShares. Are you guys seeing any fee pressure at all in that business? And then sort of related to that, given how competitive smart beta is, and it just keeps getting more and more competitive, do you think, ultimately, we might see fee pressure in that area?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of things. I think when you want to think about us, think about it beyond smart beta. It's really factor investing. So one of the delivery mechanisms are PowerShares ETFs. But our factor investment team, really the quant team, you're seeing re
componenttext: So a couple of things. I think when you want to think about us, think about it beyond smart beta. It's really factor investing. So one of the delivery mechanisms are PowerShares ETFs. But our factor investment team, really the quant team, you're seeing real demand for factor investing outside of the United States, both retail and institutional. Institutional in particular in Europe, institutional in particular in Asia. And we've been doing it for 20 years. And I think the other thing, if you look at the PowerShares lineup, what is important is that differently than mutual funds, you really can't have more than maybe 3 in a category. So there is this first-mover advantage topic within ETFs. It's something very, very real. And if you look at the length of the time that our smart beta ETFs have been in the market, they have liquidity, they have real track records. And when you're the incumbent, you're in a really strong position. So we think other people coming into the smart beta area is confirmation that it's a better way to create exposure and -- to passive. And again, we're just seeing continued strength within PowerShares in particular and factor investing outside the United States.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. My one follow-up would be on the cost optimization plan. Can you guys give us a little bit more detail about what those costs really are? I mean, is this a combination of project spending and layoff comp? Or is it something else? And then sort of related to that, I'm wondering why the spending is taking sort of -- is sort of back-end loaded, if you will. You would think if it was layoffs or something of that nature, the benefits would be pretty immediate.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. That's a good question. Thank you. So we'll make sure it's clear. These are long-dated infrastructure-type programs. So many years ago, the low-hanging fruit, as we called it, that's long gone. It's been long gone for a long time. So these are efficiency-related undertakings, hard-core system upgrades, process improvement type things. So it's large projects probably happen in all of our institutions, but they're pretty broad right now.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In many ways, they're transformational around processes and the way we do things. So it's not just trimming people, that kind of behavior. You're right. That could be done very quickly. This is very thoughtful, that will make us a stronger, better co
componenttext: Yes. In many ways, they're transformational around processes and the way we do things. So it's not just trimming people, that kind of behavior. You're right. That could be done very quickly. This is very thoughtful, that will make us a stronger, better company at the end of the day. And again, in an environment like this, as we move more quickly to get those things done, they've been on our list, and we have all these things that we'd like to do to continue to make ourselves a better company. But we're absolutely accelerating a lot of these activities right now. But they do take time to implement thoughtfully.

componenttext: So on U.S. and global fixed income, you have really terrific performance, over $10 billion of active flows in '15. Can you maybe just talk about that area with rates maybe rising a little bit here? With changes in the credit markets, how do you see the pipeline shaping up for '16 and beyond?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'd say the effort that we started 3 years ago of broadening our fixed income capability, that's probably almost 4 years ago now, is really proving to bear real fruit and, as you say, if you just look across the fixed income performance, it is ver
componenttext: Yes. So I'd say the effort that we started 3 years ago of broadening our fixed income capability, that's probably almost 4 years ago now, is really proving to bear real fruit and, as you say, if you just look across the fixed income performance, it is very, very strong. And we're seeing growing demand, all channels, all regions in -- within fixed income. And some of it is still not at the level that we anticipate because some of the capabilities don't have 3-year track records. They're getting close, but we're starting to get commitments on them simply because of their performance and, quite frankly, institutions in particular are looking for another high-quality provider of fixed income capability. So not just good performance, but we do think it's -- we're not seeing the highest level of contribution yet from that area. So we're very positive on it.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then maybe a little less fun topic, the DOL fiduciary standard. Just given the increasing thought that that's going to go through, just wanted to get your latest take there on -- realizing it's -- the final rule is not out, what could be th
componenttext: All right. And then maybe a little less fun topic, the DOL fiduciary standard. Just given the increasing thought that that's going to go through, just wanted to get your latest take there on -- realizing it's -- the final rule is not out, what could be the impact to Invesco's strategy and maybe any impact on expenses that we should think about?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question. And again, I think we're all -- we're imagining, right, so it's hard to imagine. But what I can say, and this probably gets back to some of these other topics that we've talked about, breadth of capability, depth of capability m
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question. And again, I think we're all -- we're imagining, right, so it's hard to imagine. But what I can say, and this probably gets back to some of these other topics that we've talked about, breadth of capability, depth of capability matters a lot. We think, quite frankly, high-conviction managers and fundamental investing and factor investing is really important. We think we're, obviously, one of very few firms that has -- can do the range of those types of things. And quite frankly, the other thing that Jemstep does, it's an enabling tool for our advisory clients to get broader, deeper relationships with their clients and serve clients that may -- individuals that could ultimately be totally disadvantaged by the fiduciary rule that's being put in place. So that's part of what we're thinking of how Jemstep can help us and our clients with a rule that we don't know exactly what it's going to be at the moment. But -- so that's how we've been thinking about it. And so hopefully, that's helpful.

componenttext:
,
We're just leveraging, in many ways, capabilities that are, in our view, sort of not -- can be scaled much more than they are today and taking capabilities that are somewhat focused in a particular region and unlocking them on a global basis. We can use existing salespeople. We can use, obviously, existing teams. So there is now sort of new infrastructure that we necessarily need to put in place to support that activity. It's more a matter of coordination and education and sort of making sure that our teams, our sales teams in particular, understand these products and can articulate the benefits to their clients.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, I guess, along those lines, when you think about the product dynamic and the sources of organic growth we've seen in the industry this quarter and, frankly, for the last couple of quarters, European retail and U.K. retail has been a sour
componenttext: Got it. And then, I guess, along those lines, when you think about the product dynamic and the sources of organic growth we've seen in the industry this quarter and, frankly, for the last couple of quarters, European retail and U.K. retail has been a source of strength for you guys, for BlackRock to some extent, for Threadneedle to some extent, so some of the bigger U.S. players. What -- when you take a step back, how has the competitive dynamic evolved in that market? And I guess, more importantly, are you seeing share gains from other firms? Or is the pie kind of still growing from whether it's bank deposits coming into the investment products or some of the cap divestment managers just continuously losing market share?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So is this in particular in the U.K.?
componenttext: So is this in particular in the U.K.?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: U.K. and the European region.
componenttext: U.K. and the European region.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you look over the last few years, and let's do kind of all Europe first. It has been really the independent global asset managers, largely U.S., that have been continuing to take greater share on the Continent. Now there's some other very good
componenttext: Yes. So if you look over the last few years, and let's do kind of all Europe first. It has been really the independent global asset managers, largely U.S., that have been continuing to take greater share on the Continent. Now there's some other very good competitors that participate, but that has been the fact for whatever reason. And over the last number of years, as you've seen, I mean, we just continued to make stronger and stronger inroads on the continent, and we still think that is the case. We still have, we think, quite a way to go to penetrate the market, and that continues for us. In the U.K., it's really quite different. I mean, it is a really competitive market. Very few, very few non-U.K. firms are successful in the U.K. And it is really that the heritage of our presence in the U.K. is why we're so strong there. And again, it just continues to be competitive. But we're very well placed there, and we think we'll continue to do well. But that would probably be another market that is largely driven by regulatory developments and, really, I would say, what's starting to happen here in the United States, it's very difficult to be a smaller firm. And I think the strong are just going to get stronger in the U.K. That's going to be the case in the United States, too.

componenttext: Yes. So Rhode Island would be the highest profile in the United States, I would say. But again, we're seeing -- what are the components of being able to do that? I mean, it is really those combination of broad range capabilities and, from our point of view, it's high-conviction factor and fundamentals. We have both of those, and I think that is actually really important if you're going to be successful in solutions. And it's continuing to carry on for us in each of the regions. So the U.S., Asia Pacific, frankly, China in particular, and on the continent in particular. And so we'll just continue to go down that path. And there is growing opportunity in the area. And again, I think it's -- you really have to be a broad-gauged set of offerings to be successful. And that's where we start, and then the overlay of some very talented people that can do the solutions work for the clients.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Invesco's fourth quarter results conference call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Now I'd like to turn the call over to your speakers for today, Mr. Mart
componenttext:
Welcome to Invesco's fourth quarter results conference call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. Now I'd like to turn the call over to your speakers for today, Mr. Martin L. Flanagan, President and CEO of Invesco; and Mr. Loren Starr, Chief Financial Officer. 
Mr. Flanagan, you may begin.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, and thank you everybody for joining Loren and myself. And I'll briefly review the 2015 highlights before getting into the review of the business results for the fourth quarter. And then Loren will go into more depth of the financial r
componenttext:
Thank you very much, and thank you everybody for joining Loren and myself. And I'll briefly review the 2015 highlights before getting into the review of the business results for the fourth quarter. And then Loren will go into more depth of the financial results. And then of course, we'll open up to Q&A as we always do.
So let me start by providing a brief overview of the operating results for the full year and if you're so inclined, I'm on Page 3 of the presentation. Long-term investment performance remained very strong in 2015. 79% and 85% of actively managed assets were ahead of peers over 3 years and 5 years, respectively, at the end of the fourth quarter.
Strong investment performance, combined with a comprehensive range of strategies and solutions we offer to help clients achieve their desired investment objectives, contributed to long-term net inflows of $16.2 billion for the year. Our efforts to deliver for clients while taking a disciplined approach to managing our business resulted in an operating margin of 41% for the full year, off just slightly from the very strong prior year.
The annual dividend totaled $1.08 per share, which represents an 8% increase over the prior year. We also returned more than $1 billion to shareholders during 2015 through dividends and stock buybacks. Assets under management were $775 billion at the end of 2015, down from $792 billion at the end of the prior year, mostly reflecting some late year volatility.
Average assets under management were $794 billion for 2015 versus $790 billion for 2014. Adjusted earnings per share for the year were $2.44 versus $2.51 in the prior year. As you can see on Slide 4, foreign exchange had a significant impact, diluting earnings per share by $0.15 per share from the prior year. During 2015, Fitch upgraded the firm's credit rating to positive outlook, and we repurchased $549 million worth of stock.
So let me take a moment and look back over the achievements over the past year, which will provide insights into our continued long-range plans. First and foremost, of course, we remained focused on delivering strong long-term investment performance, which continue to drive to grow our business. And as I mentioned, 79% and 85% of the assets were ahead of peers on a 3-year and 5-year basis, respectively, at the end of 2015.
By delivering strong investment performance and focusing on clients' needs, we achieved further growth across the business. In the U.S., Invesco was the only firm to appear in the top 5 over 1, 5 and 10 years in the Barron's Best Fund Families annual ranking. Our Asia Pacific business continued to grow, and we saw strong inflows in a range of strategies, resulting in net sales of $5.7 billion, the strongest showing in the region since 2011.
Institutional sales of $14.2 billion nearly doubled the prior year. We also saw continued growth in our EMEA business, driven by a focus on delivering strong investment performance in meeting our client needs. Cross-border and institutional were particularly strong with $7 billion and $4.5 billion in net inflows, respectively. And we remain in a very dominant position in the United Kingdom.
We continue to invest in capabilities where we see strong client demand or future opportunities by hiring world-class talent, upgrading our technology platforms, launching new products and providing additional resources where necessary in 2015. The ability to leverage the capabilities developed by our investment teams to meet client demand across the globe is a significant differentiator for our firm and will continue to bring the best of Invesco to different parts of our business where it makes sense for our clients.
By delivering strong investment performance, Invesco Global Targeted Return achieved strong flows in its second year of offering with assets under management surpassing $11 billion globally at the end of the year. We continued to invest and strengthen our Fixed Income platform in 2015, which is enhancing our ability to meet our client needs. We also invested in our institutional business in 2015, refining our global strategy, bringing on additional highly regarded talent and more effectively aligning ourselves to the opportunities in the marketplace.
We are seeing some early successes from this work. Institutional flows during the first quarter were amongst the strongest in the past several quarters in spite of the very volatile markets. We're very focused on bringing together the full range of our capabilities to help meet our client investment objectives. Rhode Island mandate of $7.2 billion is an example of the success we're achieving with our Invesco solutions effort.
Throughout the year, we continue to innovate and expand the range of alternative products we offer, leveraging our strong teams and capabilities for the benefit of our clients globally. 2 years ago, we began leveraging our presence in China to explore and better understand the opportunities in digital and mobile technologies in the marketplace. We've also been exploring the possibilities with market-leading firms in Silicon Valley. Our acquisition of Jemstep in mid-January is an outcome of this research. Jemstep is one of the first digital platforms to focus exclusively on advisers and is a market-leading provider of adviser-focused digital solutions.
The Invesco-Jemstep platform enables wealth management home offices and their advisers with a full suite of technology solutions that are highly flexible, customizable and easily integrated into their existing systems. This acquisition represents an investment in our partnership with the advice community and highlights our efforts to participate in the technology evolution within our industry.
Turning to the fourth quarter, let me take a moment to highlight the results, which you'll find on Slide 8. Strong investment performance contributed long-term net inflows of $3.9 billion for the quarter. Adjusted operating margin for the quarter was 40.1% versus 41.4% in the prior quarter. Quarterly dividend remained at $0.27 per share. We also returned $329 million to shareholders during the quarter through dividends and stock buybacks. Assets under management were $775 billion at the end of the fourth quarter compared to $755 billion we reported in the prior quarter.
Operating income was $356 million in the quarter, down from $373 million in the prior quarter, reflecting a very volatile quarter -- markets we saw in the quarter. Earnings per share were $0.58 versus $0.61 in the prior quarter. We repurchased $214 million of stock during the quarter, representing 6.5 million shares. Turning to Page 11 and looking at investment performance. As I mentioned, during the quarter, it continued to be quite strong with 79% of the assets in the top half over a 3-year basis and 85% were in the top half on a 5-year basis.
We also saw improvement in the 1 year number, which was 60% of assets leading peers. Turning to flows on Page 12. You'll see that active and passive flows were positive during the volatile quarter. Active flows during the quarter were driven by a variety of capabilities, including Global Targeted Return, investment-grade fixed income, real estate and quantitative equities, to name a few.
Passive flows were positive with renewed strength in Invesco PowerShares ETF, which saw net inflows of $2 billion. These flows were offset by $1.2 billion outflows associated with the Invesco mortgage capital deleveraging. This did have an impact across a number of categories. If you look at passive institutional fixed income in the U.S. and if you add $1.2 billion in each of those categories, you'll eliminate the impact of the deleveraging of the Invesco mortgage capital during that quarter.
Retail flows were relatively flat during the quarter, impacted by the macro environment as investors weighed their options during the very volatile quarter. Institutional flows were particularly strong, driven by inflows in the fixed income, real estate and reflecting our continued focus on this part of the business. The pipeline of won but not funded mandate remains at near all-time highs and is up more than 28% versus the prior year. Notably, this excludes the previous announced $7.2 billion Rhode Island 529 win, which is expected to fund sometime in the third quarter.
We feel good about the results for the year and the fourth quarter, and it puts us in a strong position heading into a volatile year, 2016. Continued strong investment performance, our focus on meeting client needs contributed solid operating results despite a very volatile environment. We continue to see strength across the global business, in particular in Asia Pacific and EMEA. Our focus remains on strengthening our efforts to deliver strong long-term results and help clients meet their investment objectives and enhancing our comprehensive range of capabilities.
But given the very volatile markets, we are taking a disciplined approach to managing our business, balancing our goals of reinvesting the business for the benefit of clients with the need to run our business effectively and efficiently as we have in past very volatile markets. I'd now like to turn the call over to Loren to go through the financials in more depth.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty. Quarter-over-quarter, our total assets under management increased $19.8 billion or 2.6%. This was driven by market returns of $21 billion, long-term net inflows of $3.9 billion and inflows from the Qs of $2 billion, offset by negative FX tr
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty. Quarter-over-quarter, our total assets under management increased $19.8 billion or 2.6%. This was driven by market returns of $21 billion, long-term net inflows of $3.9 billion and inflows from the Qs of $2 billion, offset by negative FX translation of $5.3 billion and outflows from money market of $1.8 billion. Our average AUM for the fourth quarter was $783.7 billion; that was down 0.7% versus the third quarter.
Our net revenue yield came in at 45.2 basis points with a decrease of 0.6 basis points versus Q3. FX translation reduced the yield by 0.4 basis points and change in mix reduced the yield by another 0.4 basis points. These impacts were offset by an increase in performance fees and other revenues in the quarter, which in combination added 0.2 basis points.
Next, let's turn to the operating results. You'll see that net revenues declined by $16.9 million or 1.9% quarter-over-quarter to $886.1 million, which includes a negative FX rate impact of $8.1 million. Within the net revenue number, you'll see that investment management fees fell by $29.3 million or 2.8% to $1.01 billion. This reflects the lower average AUM during the quarter as well as changes in the AUM product and currency mix.
Foreign exchange decreased fourth quarter management fees by $10.1 million. Service and distribution revenues decreased by $7.2 million or 3.4%, again, reflecting the change in mix and lower average AUM during the quarter. FX reduced service and distribution revenues by $0.1 million. Performance fees came in at $18.8 million in Q4, and this was earned from a variety of different investment capabilities, including $9.8 million from real estate and $3.2 million from U.K. equities.
Foreign exchange decreased performance fees by $0.1 million. Other revenues in the fourth quarter were $29 million, an increase of $1.4 million, driven by higher real estate transaction fees. Foreign exchange decreased other revenues by $0.1 million. Reported distribution service and advisory expense, which we net against gross revenues, fell by $17 million or 4.3%. This movement was in line with our lower retail management fees and service and distribution revenues.
Foreign exchange decreased these expenses by $2.3 million. Moving on down the slide, you'll see that our adjusted operating expenses at $530.4 million increased by $0.8 million or 0.2% relative to the third quarter. Foreign exchange decreased operating expenses by $3.9 million during the quarter. Employee compensation came in at $338.8 million, a decline of $8.1 million or 2.3%. This was due to lower incentive compensation for the quarter. FX reduced compensation by $2.3 million.
Marketing expenses increased by $8.8 million or 34% to $34.6 million. This was a function of seasonally higher expenditures for advertising and other marketing costs, particularly in EMEA. FX reduced marketing expense by $0.4 million in the quarter. Property, office and technology expenses were $80.4 million in the quarter, an increase of $0.5 million over the third quarter. FX decreased these expenses by $0.5 million.
General, administrative expenses came in at $76.6 million, and that fell by $0.4 million or 0.5 percentage point. FX decreased G&A by $0.7 million. Going on further down the slide, you'll see that nonoperating income decreased $2.3 million compared to the third quarter. Included in the fourth quarter were a $7.3 million loss on the disposition of private equity partnership interest as well as a $2 million mark-to-market on seed money investments. These were offset by gains from consolidated sponsored investment products compared to a loss in the prior quarter.
In terms of effective tax rate. Our pretax adjusted net income in Q4 was 26.6%, up slightly from 26.5% in the prior quarter, which then takes us to our adjusted EPS of $0.58 and our adjusted net operating margin of 40.1%. Now before I turn things back to Marty, I'd like to provide a little more detail on the business optimization work that we began to implement in Q4 in light of the current market volatility and as well as in light of our lower AUM levels.
We believe this optimization work will make Invesco an even stronger company, further increasing the efficiency and effectiveness of our operating platform. The business optimization work that's underway is primarily focused on our use of shared service centers, outsourcing, automation and office location strategy. In the fourth quarter U.S. GAAP results, we recognized $16.2 million of expenses, primarily in the form of staff severance costs, and we expect costs associated with the optimization initiative to continue through 2016. Total costs for 2016 are estimated to be up to $85 million.
Reducing our run rate operating expenses in 2016 and in future years is an important outcome of this work. And we expect the outgoing benefits of this project will be well in excess of the projected onetime implementation costs I just discussed. We anticipate the project will achieve cash payback within less than 3 years, and it will add an estimated 3 to -- I'm sorry, $0.06 to $0.08 EPS accretion in fiscal year 2017 and beyond. 
Finally, in terms of reporting and consistent with our past approach to dealing with material one-off expenses, the incremental optimization charges will continue to be adjusted out of our non-GAAP presentation but will be detailed and tracked each quarter in the U.S. GAAP reconciliation table within the earnings release. Additionally, we'll provide you updated estimates of the implementation costs and benefits of this initiative to the extent that these change in any material way.
The one additional item for me to note is that new for this quarter, we've included a schedule detailing the impact that the change in foreign exchange rates had on our non-GAAP operating results and expenses for the quarter. The amounts presented on Slide 17 represent the impact of the change in exchange rate movement in the quarter and the year and were calculated by applying the prior period FX rates to the current period's non-U.S. dollar earnings. Going forward, the schedule will be included each quarter and can be found in the appendix of our earnings presentations. 
And with that, I will now turn it back to Marty.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. So Loren and I are happy to answer any questions people might have.
componenttext: Thank you. So Loren and I are happy to answer any questions people might have.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from Mr. Michael Carrier of Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from Mr. Michael Carrier of Bank of America.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just first on the flows in the quarter and then I guess, the outlook, it seems like a lot of the strength, Marty, you highlighted, coming from the institutional side of the business and in Asia. You mentioned the pipeline near or at all-time highs.
componenttext: Maybe just first on the flows in the quarter and then I guess, the outlook, it seems like a lot of the strength, Marty, you highlighted, coming from the institutional side of the business and in Asia. You mentioned the pipeline near or at all-time highs. Just wanted to get a sense from a mix standpoint, what's driving maybe that pipeline. And then when we think about it, maybe for Loren, like from a mix shift on products, obviously, the market or the beta side is having an impact for everyone. But just wanted to try to get a sense on how that pipeline is relative to the current mix or the fee rate.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll be happy to pick that up, Mike. So the pipeline is being driven really in 4 big buckets. Probably one of the biggest is direct real estate, probably 30% of the pipeline. It continues to be a strong driver. Fixed income generally, across broad Fixe
componenttext: So I'll be happy to pick that up, Mike. So the pipeline is being driven really in 4 big buckets. Probably one of the biggest is direct real estate, probably 30% of the pipeline. It continues to be a strong driver. Fixed income generally, across broad Fixed Income, alternative Fixed Income, stable value, is probably another 30%. And then the remainder is split between asset allocation and multi-asset solutions. And then quantitative and regional equities would be others. So it's fairly well diversified and generally high fee. And so when we look at the fee rate of the pipeline, it's actually at one of the highest levels we've ever seen it. It's well above our current net revenue yields for the firm as a whole. And so as these assets come in, it will be accretive to our fee rates, which is great news. Obviously, the negative that we've seen in our fee rate is due to the compression on equities, just given what's happened in the market and then foreign exchange has also had an impact as well. But in terms of the mix overall on the pipeline, the institutional pipeline, we think it's very positive for our fee rates.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I don't know if I could add much to it other than it is a part of the business where we've turned our attention. It's really seemingly getting stronger and stronger, frankly, in each region of the world: in the Americas, in EMEA and in Asia Pacifi
componenttext: Yes. So I don't know if I could add much to it other than it is a part of the business where we've turned our attention. It's really seemingly getting stronger and stronger, frankly, in each region of the world: in the Americas, in EMEA and in Asia Pacific. And it is really quite broad-based. So it's a very positive.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other thing I would just mention, we would expect our fee rate, given stability in assets and stability in FX, to grow across 2016.
componenttext: And the other thing I would just mention, we would expect our fee rate, given stability in assets and stability in FX, to grow across 2016.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then just a quick follow-up. Loren, usually or sometimes you'll give some guidance just on like the expense lines. And I don't know if it's because of some of the work that you guys are doing to streamline the expenses as you get
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just a quick follow-up. Loren, usually or sometimes you'll give some guidance just on like the expense lines. And I don't know if it's because of some of the work that you guys are doing to streamline the expenses as you get into '17. But just any, I guess, color, I think comp, you typically had the 1Q seasonality, but maybe the marketing, you have some 4Q seasonality. So any color on the expense outlook, just given the volatility in the markets right now.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'd say given the volatility, we're probably going to not give any explicit guidance around line items at this stage. There's a lot of work, obviously, that I discussed being done around some of this optimization work, which will have some impacts on
componenttext: Yes. I'd say given the volatility, we're probably going to not give any explicit guidance around line items at this stage. There's a lot of work, obviously, that I discussed being done around some of this optimization work, which will have some impacts on those line items as well. Generally, we're working hard to bring expenses down, right? As you can imagine, year-over-year decline in expenses, our compensation generally moves and flexes in line with operating income, so those will be down. Some of the optimization work especially around -- we just mentioned some of the severance will also help bring some of the compensation line down. But the benefits of the optimization work will probably spread across most of the other categories other than marketing explicitly. We're looking at marketing. That's another interesting topic for us. It is one of these conundrums when you're in this market. Your clients want to hear from you and you want to be out with them. But at the same time, it certainly is a discretionary expense, and it's one that we're continuing to look at. So I'd say we're obviously going to be very vigilant to making sure that we manage expenses very smartly in this environment with no presumption of a snapback or some reversal. The other thing I would like to just mention, there is some impact just due to the acquisitions that we discussed in terms of Jemstep and in terms of Religare Asset Management, completing our 100% ownership there. It's absolutely immaterial in terms of the earnings impact, so you don't have to worry about EPS impacts. But it does add probably roughly $15 million of expense and a little bit more in revenue in 2016. So you'll see some of those line items go up just as a result of those acquisitions but offset by, obviously, higher levels of revenues. So we don't want anyone to be surprised by that. The optimization work that we're doing should have a benefit in 2016 that you'll see. So again, we'll quantify that as we get through it. But that will help drive expenses down year-over-year.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just add to Loren's point. I mean, we feel like we're really quite capable at this, and if you look at our history, we use these volatile periods to really take advantage of opportunities as they show up. It is a period where I think '16 for
componenttext: Yes, I would just add to Loren's point. I mean, we feel like we're really quite capable at this, and if you look at our history, we use these volatile periods to really take advantage of opportunities as they show up. It is a period where I think '16 for the industry is going to be quite interesting, where clients will be looking for those firms that are in a position of strength. And we are one of those firms, and we feel we're operating from a position of strength right now. And so we're going to be very responsible on the expense side, but we have some real opportunities that we want to continue to advance at the same time. So that's what we're working through, and we'll continue to make sure that we're communicating very clearly with everybody.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Daniel Fannon of Jefferies.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: I guess, first, can you expand upon the 529 mandate? I think it's $7.2 billion you mentioned that's going to fund in the third quarter. Is that -- can you talk about the mix of products that's going to be in? And then also, that's obviously very large. Is that something that is a new channel for you guys? Or can you talk about how that evolved and maybe the other opportunities within that subsegment?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it will fund in January and there's...
componenttext: Yes, so it will fund in January and there's...

componenttext: July.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excuse me, not January. July, excuse me. July. It's 2 plans. The vast majority of the money is in -- one plan is just for Rhode Island alone, that's ETFs alone, sort of a broad range of ETFs. It was -- it's driven by our solutions team. So they are buildi
componenttext: Excuse me, not January. July, excuse me. July. It's 2 plans. The vast majority of the money is in -- one plan is just for Rhode Island alone, that's ETFs alone, sort of a broad range of ETFs. It was -- it's driven by our solutions team. So they are building a portfolio consistent with what Rhode Island, the CIO has set there as a set of investment objectives. The much larger part of the plan, which is probably $6.8 billion of that, is a broad range of active and passive capabilities, again, managed by our solutions team. And from my point of view, Rhode Island's been very, very thoughtful, and it is a really well-constructed approach. And again, it's our solutions team that's managing the capabilities. With regard to the channel, it is a new channel for us from the standpoint of as we all know, many, many people use 529s for their kids, and et cetera, et cetera. And so it will be available in the advice channel throughout the country. And it's one of the largest 529 plans in the marketplace. And we just think it's going to be that much more competitive. And it will be -- our goal is to help Rhode Island meet the needs of the people in the portfolio. But frankly, they also want to grow their plan, too, and we will work very hard to do that.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then you mentioned part of the strength in the fourth quarter has been in Asia and Europe, and I think that's been for some time. I guess, given the volatility to start the year, has those demand changes -- has these demand kind of trends chang
componenttext: Great. And then you mentioned part of the strength in the fourth quarter has been in Asia and Europe, and I think that's been for some time. I guess, given the volatility to start the year, has those demand changes -- has these demand kind of trends changed at all? Or kind of how would you characterize the start of the year?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really hard to -- I think the psychology day-by-day, week-by-week changes. It does feel like it's -- the markets are seeming a little more calm; you're getting some more clarity. I will say I was just in Asia last week, and all the visits I had were
componenttext: It's really hard to -- I think the psychology day-by-day, week-by-week changes. It does feel like it's -- the markets are seeming a little more calm; you're getting some more clarity. I will say I was just in Asia last week, and all the visits I had were all very, very strong. So I would anticipate continued strength there, as Loren said in EMEA. But it feels like we're starting to see a little bit more positive reaction to the environment. But again, it's so early to say anything.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think your point that you made before, Marty, is good. I mean, institutional, the strength on the institutional side is actually strong across every region. Great pipeline. The retail behavior has been sort of hard to gauge sort of in and out, risk on,
componenttext: I think your point that you made before, Marty, is good. I mean, institutional, the strength on the institutional side is actually strong across every region. Great pipeline. The retail behavior has been sort of hard to gauge sort of in and out, risk on, risk off. But generally, I'd say, in EMEA, we feel very, very comfortable and confident that the retail side is going to be quite strong. The GTR product is doing very, very well. Performance has been quite, quite strong. And we think that will help continue to allow us to grow both in the U.K. and in Europe on the retail side. The other thing is the quantitative product as well, it's unbelievable. Off the charts performance. So also very, very strong performance and demand.

componenttextpreview: Got it. That's cool. And then a question on Jemstep. I saw your details and rationale for growth in the slides. I just had a follow-up question. How do you expect the distributors to use it? And then more importantly, how do you differentiate? Because I'm
componenttext: Got it. That's cool. And then a question on Jemstep. I saw your details and rationale for growth in the slides. I just had a follow-up question. How do you expect the distributors to use it? And then more importantly, how do you differentiate? Because I'm assuming there's going to be many large asset managers having their version and maybe even the distributors doing their own version. I'm just curious. Is this an early mover advantage that you make their lives easier? Just curious how you expect that to shape up.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a great question. So I think you're going to -- and we are expecting the large distributors will have some version of their own. That's historically what they've done in the past. We've still contacted them and -- but that would be our -- what
componenttext: Yes, that's a great question. So I think you're going to -- and we are expecting the large distributors will have some version of their own. That's historically what they've done in the past. We've still contacted them and -- but that would be our -- what we would anticipate. It's really just sort of the other channels, though, there's a high degree of interest in this. And really, what it is, it's just us partnering up with our distribution partners. And the more effective we can be with them at the end of the day, that's a good thing for their clients and for us also. I don't believe that they're going to be -- let me say it the other way. I believe strongly there is a first-mover advantage to this because, quite frankly, multiple distribution partners are not going to have multiple, 3, 4, 5, 6, 10 of these within the system; they don't need it. And it's like any other application; it's education and investment to move that forward. So that is our other core belief.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: To that end, is that your point with the -- we have 300 people on the ground, selling and educating as we speak?
componenttext: To that end, is that your point with the -- we have 300 people on the ground, selling and educating as we speak?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. Last one, Loren. With the cash balances hitting your internal hurdles and the valuation, in my words, at a ridiculous level, how do you think about the payout ratio relative to the past? Like, can we start seeing 100% payouts even though you h
componenttext: Okay, good. Last one, Loren. With the cash balances hitting your internal hurdles and the valuation, in my words, at a ridiculous level, how do you think about the payout ratio relative to the past? Like, can we start seeing 100% payouts even though you have a lot of things going on?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you saw something probably very close to that this last quarter. So again, we certainly have demonstrated our willingness to respond when the stock is, as you call, ridiculously low. And we would tend to agree with you on that one, just give
componenttext: Well, I think you saw something probably very close to that this last quarter. So again, we certainly have demonstrated our willingness to respond when the stock is, as you call, ridiculously low. And we would tend to agree with you on that one, just given our sense of optimism around our ability to grow over the long term. So you should expect us to continue to pay a lot of attention. Our needs for internal organic growth, seedings and so forth, are still pretty sizable. A lot of opportunities, so we need to balance those against returning capital. But you should certainly expect us to be operating in the stock buyback realm in a nonbusiness as usual approach, which is somewhat similar to what you've seen in the fourth quarter. Maybe not at that full level but something between business as usual and what you've seen us do.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
