componenttext: Next, we have Mr. Bill Katz of Citi.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just trying to reconcile some of the numbers on the optimization program you delineated a bit, Loren. You mentioned that you're spending, I guess, roughly $100 million between the charge in the fourth quarter and then what you expect for this year and sor
componenttext: Just trying to reconcile some of the numbers on the optimization program you delineated a bit, Loren. You mentioned that you're spending, I guess, roughly $100 million between the charge in the fourth quarter and then what you expect for this year and sort of within a 3-year payback. $0.06 to $0.08 accretion in '17. Is it accretive to non-GAAP earnings for '16? And the reason I'm asking is I guess you're going to run the expenses through the GAAP line. And I presume if it's a 3-year recovery, either you're really back-ended in '18 or you would get some pretty sizable savings this year as well. I'm just trying to figure out the cash flows.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the execution of the optimization is going to happen all through 2016. So the 3-year payback is really going to be in -- at full throttle in 2017 and beyond. We will get savings in 2016 probably somewhere around $15 million is what our non-GAAP run rat
componenttext: So the execution of the optimization is going to happen all through 2016. So the 3-year payback is really going to be in -- at full throttle in 2017 and beyond. We will get savings in 2016 probably somewhere around $15 million is what our non-GAAP run rate, positive impact would be or is what we expect, and that would certainly ramp up significantly into 2017 and on. So again, our estimate is based on what we know today, based on the activities that we're engaged in today. But we're going to be pretty -- we do believe that it will be no more than $85 million in terms of what is required for us to implement that long-term run rate savings, which, again, is somewhere $30 million to $45 million in run rate cost savings post 2017.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then, Marty, or maybe both of you guys, you gave a nice delineation also, by region and by product. But the one area that seemed to sort of not be within that list was more traditional equity mandates. What are you hearing from cl
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then, Marty, or maybe both of you guys, you gave a nice delineation also, by region and by product. But the one area that seemed to sort of not be within that list was more traditional equity mandates. What are you hearing from clients on the institutional side? Is there still more of this barbell notion? Or is there any sort of interest in more traditional plain vanilla type of mandates?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So there are actually. I mean, again, I'll just use the Asia trip just because I was there, but I wouldn't limit it to there. I mean, you're actually seeing institutional clients recognize that this is probably the time to increase their exposure to
componenttext: Yes. So there are actually. I mean, again, I'll just use the Asia trip just because I was there, but I wouldn't limit it to there. I mean, you're actually seeing institutional clients recognize that this is probably the time to increase their exposure to the equity market. So you're actually hearing very constructive things, and also you're starting to hear, by the way, this is a time where active management can really start to add value in a way that was harder from sort of the beta run from 2009 on. So yes, I think you're at a point where you're actually going to see, if you're a high-conviction manager, you're going to continue to start to do well. So I don't know what you put in traditional. But clearly, international equities are high. We're seeing a lot of the regional capabilities people are interested in. So I think it's just where we are in the market cycle. And I think you're going to continue to see -- excuse me, you will begin to see much more commitment to active management.

componenttext: It's a very good question. I don't think I'll have a satisfactory answer. What I would say is that their first decision was to engage us to meet the program of the investment objective they had in place. That was their first desire. Secondly, they recognize the depth and breadth of our retail distribution capability with some very important distribution partners throughout the country. And so their anticipation of growth in the plan is part of what their decision was. And obviously, we're very interested in it. And we think it will be a new channel for us, and we think we'll be quite successful with it. And I guess, the other way to put it in context, and again, I don't have the -- they were successful enough to become, I think it's the third largest 529 plan in the country. And we would look for growth to be stronger than what it had been in the past.

componenttext: Yes. And I would agree with your characterization about it being sticky, as long as performance and everything else continues, right?

componenttext: And finally, I guess just on that, again, was this kind of a broad kind of beauty show? What was kind of the decision process in terms of...

componenttext: Yes. No, look, you have to think of it as a typical institutional beauty show. And obviously, you -- they had the choice of anybody they wanted to work with in the country, and it was very competitive. And as best we know, this is the largest 529 transfer that's happened in the industry.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Michael Kim of Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Our next question is from Michael Kim of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, any early read into quarter-to-date flow trends, particularly given the seasonal step up we typically see in retirement accounts in the first quarter? And then related to that, I think in the past, you sort of targeted maybe a 3% to 5% organic grow
componenttext: First, any early read into quarter-to-date flow trends, particularly given the seasonal step up we typically see in retirement accounts in the first quarter? And then related to that, I think in the past, you sort of targeted maybe a 3% to 5% organic growth rate. So just assuming a more cooperative market backdrop going forward, which I realize is a big assumption these days, but in that sort of environment, is that still sort of a reasonable range to expect?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll make a couple of comments and Loren can -- so we still look at that 3% to 5% organic growth rate as very achievable. And again, as Loren and I have been talking about not just this, but previously, we just continue to see ongoing strength throug
componenttext: Yes. I'll make a couple of comments and Loren can -- so we still look at that 3% to 5% organic growth rate as very achievable. And again, as Loren and I have been talking about not just this, but previously, we just continue to see ongoing strength throughout the regions, both retail and institutional. So we think that is fully in place. You're now talking about a few weeks into January, very, very hard to anticipate the quarter, quite frankly. And this week's a whole lot better than the first week in January. So I wish I could give you some great insights; I really can't. That said, I do know, and Loren made this point very clear, the institutional investors are continuing to move forward. The retail investors tend to be more risk on, risk off, depending on the daily movement in the markets. Although it feels like that's calming down, is probably the best I could describe at the moment.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I think that's about right. I would say there was a lot of risk off behavior in the early part of January, so it's getting healthier.
componenttext: Yes. No, I think that's about right. I would say there was a lot of risk off behavior in the early part of January, so it's getting healthier.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And then so if we focus on kind of the alternatives bucket, net flows have been consistently positive for a number of years. I know the real estate business represents a big chunk of those assets. But there's also a number of different
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And then so if we focus on kind of the alternatives bucket, net flows have been consistently positive for a number of years. I know the real estate business represents a big chunk of those assets. But there's also a number of different strategies that are in there. So just wondering if you could sort of give us a sense of where you're seeing the best growth opportunities. And then as it relates to fee rates, any sort of color there? Because I think the range of the respective fee rates within that bucket can be pretty wide.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Michael, I think the other probably even larger in terms of what we're seeing, certainly in the fourth quarter, is GTR. I mean, it just continues to grow. I think it brought in about $1.5 billion in net flows in the fourth quarter. It's about $11 billi
componenttext: So Michael, I think the other probably even larger in terms of what we're seeing, certainly in the fourth quarter, is GTR. I mean, it just continues to grow. I think it brought in about $1.5 billion in net flows in the fourth quarter. It's about $11 billion in total size to date. So that is one that, certainly outside the U.S., has really taken on a lot of good momentum. And I think the product that it competes with in the marketplace has had some issues around its performance. And so the positioning is even better probably now than it's ever been. Still early days in the U.S. for us. And so we'd like nothing more to see GTR sort of reach its appropriate time frame and sort of get through all the hurdles that we need to get through for it to be on the platform. But I think that and real estate, and then perhaps as well, alternative fixed income is still an area where we believe we can play at a much more significant level than we have in the past. And there are a lot of products that are still sort of early days in terms of their track record. So I think it's really GTR and real estate right now are the primary drivers for us and where the demand is.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then just one quick one. You mentioned or you called out the $7.3 million realized loss related to the disposition of private equity partnership interests. Can you just sort of give us some more color on exactly what that related to?
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then just one quick one. You mentioned or you called out the $7.3 million realized loss related to the disposition of private equity partnership interests. Can you just sort of give us some more color on exactly what that related to?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so that was a period of time where we were warehousing partnership interest before they were put into a vehicle for our clients. And unfortunately, the mark-to-market on that really hit us before it got into the vehicle. And so that's what that is. N
componenttext: Yes, so that was a period of time where we were warehousing partnership interest before they were put into a vehicle for our clients. And unfortunately, the mark-to-market on that really hit us before it got into the vehicle. And so that's what that is. Normally, we'd be able to get it in there faster. But there was just, again, some exposure to a pretty volatile market. And that's what you saw.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we have Mr. Craig Siegenthaler of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Next, we have Mr. Craig Siegenthaler of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was looking for a little more color in excess capital. I think, historically, you like to provide a sort of guidance here in terms of cash and investments versus long-term debt. And they're pretty close here. So could you just provide an update here? An
componenttext: I was looking for a little more color in excess capital. I think, historically, you like to provide a sort of guidance here in terms of cash and investments versus long-term debt. And they're pretty close here. So could you just provide an update here? And maybe you're pretty comfortable where it is right now.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think you'll see that we had about $1.85 billion in total cash at the end of the quarter. The amount that is required from a regulatory perspective in the U.K. and continental Europe is around $550 million. So we're about $1.3 billion in excess of ou
componenttext: So I think you'll see that we had about $1.85 billion in total cash at the end of the quarter. The amount that is required from a regulatory perspective in the U.K. and continental Europe is around $550 million. So we're about $1.3 billion in excess of our reg capital requirements. We talked about in the past that we want to be at least $1 billion. So again, we're feeling strong in terms of our cash position and our ability to use our capital to the benefit of our clients, probably better than we have in a long time. Now with that said, assets have dropped a little bit, and so our cash flow is definitely having some -- there's some impact to our operating cash there. But overall, we're feeling very, very strong and optimistic about our ability to deploy our capital for the benefit of our shareholders in terms of return of capital.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very helpful, Loren. And then just my follow-up on Jemstep. I just wanted to get a better understanding for how this business will function, how it will generate profits and sort of what really attracted you to this business.
componenttext: Very helpful, Loren. And then just my follow-up on Jemstep. I just wanted to get a better understanding for how this business will function, how it will generate profits and sort of what really attracted you to this business.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I'd probably say, what's the attraction? As I said, we -- our view is it's a mistake not to pay attention to what's going on in the digital world, and it's really easy to just ignore it. We think that's a mistake. That's why we went and spent s
componenttext: Yes, well, I'd probably say, what's the attraction? As I said, we -- our view is it's a mistake not to pay attention to what's going on in the digital world, and it's really easy to just ignore it. We think that's a mistake. That's why we went and spent some real good time researching what is happening. And we came to the conclusion that a digital mobile tool that could help us with our distribution partners would be a very wise thing to do. It's a simple a thought as that. And there will be a combination of -- and I don't want to get into the pricing on Jemstep, but there'll be a combination of things that we think will be accretive, if you want to call it, to the organization. First of all, the most important thing is we'll have deeper relationships with our clients. We'll be able to do a better job with our clients. We'll be able to offer more effectively the broader range of investment capabilities we have to our clients. And those, at the end of the day, will ultimately result in increased assets under management if we, again, -- you have to be performing, et cetera, all the obvious. But we think that's the fundamental thoughts of why we thought Jemstep was very important development for us.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we have Mr. Ken Worthington of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Next, we have Mr. Ken Worthington of JPMorgan.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, also on capital management. We're getting to the point in the year where I think you'll be recommending to the board the dividend increase for the coming year. In recent years, the dividend increase has been particularly big. But given where the st
componenttext: First, also on capital management. We're getting to the point in the year where I think you'll be recommending to the board the dividend increase for the coming year. In recent years, the dividend increase has been particularly big. But given where the stock price is, how are you thinking about the kind of the mix of capital return between dividend and buyback as we look forward to the next year?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, I think it's probably not great for us to be talking about this in advance of our discussion with our board. But generally, it's -- I think our sense is a bit more modest. A modest dividend could be appropriate, right, in light of the fact that, that
componenttext: Ken, I think it's probably not great for us to be talking about this in advance of our discussion with our board. But generally, it's -- I think our sense is a bit more modest. A modest dividend could be appropriate, right, in light of the fact that, that would free up more capital for buybacks, which I think, given the market pricing of our stock, may be the better way to use that cash. But again, we need to wait before we get in front of our board before we put a signal anything, quite honestly.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just little ones. The pound hedge. The pound, obviously, fell a lot in 2015. I couldn't really tell how much you made at the end of the day on that. It also said in your release you're hedged out to March. I thought you were actually hedged out t
componenttext: And then just little ones. The pound hedge. The pound, obviously, fell a lot in 2015. I couldn't really tell how much you made at the end of the day on that. It also said in your release you're hedged out to March. I thought you were actually hedged out to May. How are you thinking about hedging out the currency as we think about 2016? And actually, what did you actually end up making in 2015 on it?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, great question. So the hedge, as you know, is -- those hedges were structured at 1.493. That is reflective to the average rate for the quarter. And so there was no quarter in 2015 that had a rate that averaged below 1.493. So we made nothing this yea
componenttext: Yes, great question. So the hedge, as you know, is -- those hedges were structured at 1.493. That is reflective to the average rate for the quarter. And so there was no quarter in 2015 that had a rate that averaged below 1.493. So we made nothing this year -- or last year, in 2015. The current quarter hedge is definitely in the money. And again -- so again, more to come on what the value there is. It's moving around. But it's certainly something you would see at this rate as noticeably -- noticeable number. We are expecting to hedge our currency going forward, around the pound in particular. And we believe that the pound is potentially going to be still a little volatile in light -- especially with the Brexit discussions that are going on. And so those are, again, as we've done in the past, the hedges we'd put in place, that would be out-of-the-money puts, that really would protect us from the downside, allow upside to occur and, again, would protect our cash flow in particular as opposed to our operating results, which we can't really protect against.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked and answered. Just one left. As far as the U.S. equity performance, we saw some deterioration here this quarter. Could you speak to that? headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It did. And again, my perspective on that is overall, the performance is still very, very strong and is very short term in nature. And frankly, it did improve last quarter to this quarter. But it's, then again, it's all very short term. But moving into th
componenttext: It did. And again, my perspective on that is overall, the performance is still very, very strong and is very short term in nature. And frankly, it did improve last quarter to this quarter. But it's, then again, it's all very short term. But moving into this year, it just continued to strengthen. So those portfolios that have the energy exposure, we think they're placed very, very well, and they're going to do -- ultimately do very, very well for clients.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, the one thing I would say is that the improvement that we saw in the 1-year numbers relative to Q3 were due to our small cap growth equity team as well as our growth and income product. So there were definitely some equity capabilities that saw im
componenttext: I mean, the one thing I would say is that the improvement that we saw in the 1-year numbers relative to Q3 were due to our small cap growth equity team as well as our growth and income product. So there were definitely some equity capabilities that saw improvement in the quarter relative to the last quarter.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A few questions on PowerShares. Are you guys seeing any fee pressure at all in that business? And then sort of related to that, given how competitive smart beta is, and it just keeps getting more and more competitive, do you think, ultimately, we might se
componenttext: A few questions on PowerShares. Are you guys seeing any fee pressure at all in that business? And then sort of related to that, given how competitive smart beta is, and it just keeps getting more and more competitive, do you think, ultimately, we might see fee pressure in that area?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of things. I think when you want to think about us, think about it beyond smart beta. It's really factor investing. So one of the delivery mechanisms are PowerShares ETFs. But our factor investment team, really the quant team, you're seeing re
componenttext: So a couple of things. I think when you want to think about us, think about it beyond smart beta. It's really factor investing. So one of the delivery mechanisms are PowerShares ETFs. But our factor investment team, really the quant team, you're seeing real demand for factor investing outside of the United States, both retail and institutional. Institutional in particular in Europe, institutional in particular in Asia. And we've been doing it for 20 years. And I think the other thing, if you look at the PowerShares lineup, what is important is that differently than mutual funds, you really can't have more than maybe 3 in a category. So there is this first-mover advantage topic within ETFs. It's something very, very real. And if you look at the length of the time that our smart beta ETFs have been in the market, they have liquidity, they have real track records. And when you're the incumbent, you're in a really strong position. So we think other people coming into the smart beta area is confirmation that it's a better way to create exposure and -- to passive. And again, we're just seeing continued strength within PowerShares in particular and factor investing outside the United States.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My one follow-up would be on the cost optimization plan. Can you guys give us a little bit more detail about what those costs really are? I mean, is this a combination of project spending and layoff comp? Or is it something else? And then sort of re
componenttext: Okay. My one follow-up would be on the cost optimization plan. Can you guys give us a little bit more detail about what those costs really are? I mean, is this a combination of project spending and layoff comp? Or is it something else? And then sort of related to that, I'm wondering why the spending is taking sort of -- is sort of back-end loaded, if you will. You would think if it was layoffs or something of that nature, the benefits would be pretty immediate.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's a good question. Thank you. So we'll make sure it's clear. These are long-dated infrastructure-type programs. So many years ago, the low-hanging fruit, as we called it, that's long gone. It's been long gone for a long time. So these are effic
componenttext: Okay. That's a good question. Thank you. So we'll make sure it's clear. These are long-dated infrastructure-type programs. So many years ago, the low-hanging fruit, as we called it, that's long gone. It's been long gone for a long time. So these are efficiency-related undertakings, hard-core system upgrades, process improvement type things. So it's large projects probably happen in all of our institutions, but they're pretty broad right now.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In many ways, they're transformational around processes and the way we do things. So it's not just trimming people, that kind of behavior. You're right. That could be done very quickly. This is very thoughtful, that will make us a stronger, better co
componenttext: Yes. In many ways, they're transformational around processes and the way we do things. So it's not just trimming people, that kind of behavior. You're right. That could be done very quickly. This is very thoughtful, that will make us a stronger, better company at the end of the day. And again, in an environment like this, as we move more quickly to get those things done, they've been on our list, and we have all these things that we'd like to do to continue to make ourselves a better company. But we're absolutely accelerating a lot of these activities right now. But they do take time to implement thoughtfully.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we have Mr. Chris Shutler of William Blair.
componenttext: Next, we have Mr. Chris Shutler of William Blair.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on U.S. and global fixed income, you have really terrific performance, over $10 billion of active flows in '15. Can you maybe just talk about that area with rates maybe rising a little bit here? With changes in the credit markets, how do you see the pi
componenttext: So on U.S. and global fixed income, you have really terrific performance, over $10 billion of active flows in '15. Can you maybe just talk about that area with rates maybe rising a little bit here? With changes in the credit markets, how do you see the pipeline shaping up for '16 and beyond?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'd say the effort that we started 3 years ago of broadening our fixed income capability, that's probably almost 4 years ago now, is really proving to bear real fruit and, as you say, if you just look across the fixed income performance, it is ver
componenttext: Yes. So I'd say the effort that we started 3 years ago of broadening our fixed income capability, that's probably almost 4 years ago now, is really proving to bear real fruit and, as you say, if you just look across the fixed income performance, it is very, very strong. And we're seeing growing demand, all channels, all regions in -- within fixed income. And some of it is still not at the level that we anticipate because some of the capabilities don't have 3-year track records. They're getting close, but we're starting to get commitments on them simply because of their performance and, quite frankly, institutions in particular are looking for another high-quality provider of fixed income capability. So not just good performance, but we do think it's -- we're not seeing the highest level of contribution yet from that area. So we're very positive on it.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean it's only growing for us. I mean it's such a big market, and we're so under-penetrated that our opportunity to continue to grow even if there are some rate impacts, I think, is significant.
componenttext: Yes. I mean it's only growing for us. I mean it's such a big market, and we're so under-penetrated that our opportunity to continue to grow even if there are some rate impacts, I think, is significant.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then maybe a little less fun topic, the DOL fiduciary standard. Just given the increasing thought that that's going to go through, just wanted to get your latest take there on -- realizing it's -- the final rule is not out, what could be th
componenttext: All right. And then maybe a little less fun topic, the DOL fiduciary standard. Just given the increasing thought that that's going to go through, just wanted to get your latest take there on -- realizing it's -- the final rule is not out, what could be the impact to Invesco's strategy and maybe any impact on expenses that we should think about?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question. And again, I think we're all -- we're imagining, right, so it's hard to imagine. But what I can say, and this probably gets back to some of these other topics that we've talked about, breadth of capability, depth of capability m
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question. And again, I think we're all -- we're imagining, right, so it's hard to imagine. But what I can say, and this probably gets back to some of these other topics that we've talked about, breadth of capability, depth of capability matters a lot. We think, quite frankly, high-conviction managers and fundamental investing and factor investing is really important. We think we're, obviously, one of very few firms that has -- can do the range of those types of things. And quite frankly, the other thing that Jemstep does, it's an enabling tool for our advisory clients to get broader, deeper relationships with their clients and serve clients that may -- individuals that could ultimately be totally disadvantaged by the fiduciary rule that's being put in place. So that's part of what we're thinking of how Jemstep can help us and our clients with a rule that we don't know exactly what it's going to be at the moment. But -- so that's how we've been thinking about it. And so hopefully, that's helpful.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we have Alex Blostein of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Next, we have Alex Blostein of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bigger picture on expenses. So when you take a step back, and I understand that the initiative might have been in the works for some time, but the revenue environment probably accelerated some of that, but when you take a step back and you look at your fi
componenttext: Bigger picture on expenses. So when you take a step back, and I understand that the initiative might have been in the works for some time, but the revenue environment probably accelerated some of that, but when you take a step back and you look at your fixed expense base versus the variable expense base, to achieve that kind of 3% to 5% organic growth, what kind of inflation and investment do you need to see in your fixed portion of the expense base to achieve that target?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing more than what we have, quite frankly, so...
componenttext: Nothing more than what we have, quite frankly, so...

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: ,We're just leveraging, in many ways, capabilities that are, in our view, sort of not -- can be scaled much more than they are today and taking capabilities that are somewhat focused in a particular region and unlocking them on a global basis. We can us
componenttext:
,
We're just leveraging, in many ways, capabilities that are, in our view, sort of not -- can be scaled much more than they are today and taking capabilities that are somewhat focused in a particular region and unlocking them on a global basis. We can use existing salespeople. We can use, obviously, existing teams. So there is now sort of new infrastructure that we necessarily need to put in place to support that activity. It's more a matter of coordination and education and sort of making sure that our teams, our sales teams in particular, understand these products and can articulate the benefits to their clients.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, I guess, along those lines, when you think about the product dynamic and the sources of organic growth we've seen in the industry this quarter and, frankly, for the last couple of quarters, European retail and U.K. retail has been a sour
componenttext: Got it. And then, I guess, along those lines, when you think about the product dynamic and the sources of organic growth we've seen in the industry this quarter and, frankly, for the last couple of quarters, European retail and U.K. retail has been a source of strength for you guys, for BlackRock to some extent, for Threadneedle to some extent, so some of the bigger U.S. players. What -- when you take a step back, how has the competitive dynamic evolved in that market? And I guess, more importantly, are you seeing share gains from other firms? Or is the pie kind of still growing from whether it's bank deposits coming into the investment products or some of the cap divestment managers just continuously losing market share?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So is this in particular in the U.K.?
componenttext: So is this in particular in the U.K.?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: U.K. and the European region.
componenttext: U.K. and the European region.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you look over the last few years, and let's do kind of all Europe first. It has been really the independent global asset managers, largely U.S., that have been continuing to take greater share on the Continent. Now there's some other very good
componenttext: Yes. So if you look over the last few years, and let's do kind of all Europe first. It has been really the independent global asset managers, largely U.S., that have been continuing to take greater share on the Continent. Now there's some other very good competitors that participate, but that has been the fact for whatever reason. And over the last number of years, as you've seen, I mean, we just continued to make stronger and stronger inroads on the continent, and we still think that is the case. We still have, we think, quite a way to go to penetrate the market, and that continues for us. In the U.K., it's really quite different. I mean, it is a really competitive market. Very few, very few non-U.K. firms are successful in the U.K. And it is really that the heritage of our presence in the U.K. is why we're so strong there. And again, it just continues to be competitive. But we're very well placed there, and we think we'll continue to do well. But that would probably be another market that is largely driven by regulatory developments and, really, I would say, what's starting to happen here in the United States, it's very difficult to be a smaller firm. And I think the strong are just going to get stronger in the U.K. That's going to be the case in the United States, too.

componenttext: Yes. So Rhode Island would be the highest profile in the United States, I would say. But again, we're seeing -- what are the components of being able to do that? I mean, it is really those combination of broad range capabilities and, from our point of view, it's high-conviction factor and fundamentals. We have both of those, and I think that is actually really important if you're going to be successful in solutions. And it's continuing to carry on for us in each of the regions. So the U.S., Asia Pacific, frankly, China in particular, and on the continent in particular. And so we'll just continue to go down that path. And there is growing opportunity in the area. And again, I think it's -- you really have to be a broad-gauged set of offerings to be successful. And that's where we start, and then the overlay of some very talented people that can do the solutions work for the clients.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. This is Marty Flanagan, and thank you for joining us today. On the call with me today is Loren Starr, Invesco's CFO, and we'll be speaking from the presentation that's available on the website if you're so inclined to follow. Today, I'll review
componenttext:
Thank you. This is Marty Flanagan, and thank you for joining us today. On the call with me today is Loren Starr, Invesco's CFO, and we'll be speaking from the presentation that's available on the website if you're so inclined to follow. Today, I'll review the business results for the first quarter. Loren will go into greater details on the financials and we'll open it up to questions. But let me begin by highlighting the firm's operating results for the first quarter, which you'll find on Slide 3. 
Long-term investment performance remains strong during the quarter 72% and 76% of active managed assets were ahead of peers on a 3 to 5-year basis, respectively. Strong investment performance and our continued focus on meeting clients needs were not enough to offset the impact of the volatile markets particularly in January and February. Strong institutional and active demand were offset by volatility among retail and passive capabilities, which led to long-term net outflows of $1.3 billion during the quarter. Market volatility and net outflows put pressure on the operating margin during the quarter, which was 37.5%. During the quarter, we returned $238 million of shareholders through dividends and stock buybacks. 
In addition, reflecting continued confidence in the fundamentals of our business over the long-term, we are raising our quarterly dividends to $0.28 per share, up 4% from the prior year. Assets under management were $771 billion at the end of the first quarter, down slightly from $775 billion at the end of last year. More indicative of the results during the quarter were the average assets under management, which are down $36 billion [ph] during the first quarter, as compared to $738 billion at year-end. Operating income was $307 million in the quarter versus $356 million in the prior quarter. Earnings per share were $0.49 versus $0.58 in the prior quarter. And as noted earlier, we increased the dividend $0.28 per share. We also purchased 125 million of stock during the quarter. 
Before Loren goes into detail on the company financials, let me take a moment to review the investment performance and flows in the quarter. Turning to Slide 6 now. You'll note investment performance is strong in the quarter with 72% of assets in this top half on a 3-year basis and 76% were on the top half on a 5-year basis. One year results partially reflect the underperformance of energy and financial sectors earlier in the year, which impacted some of our value portfolios. We'd seen both of these sectors beginning to recover somewhat largely in April and consequently, positively impacted the performance year-to-date. In fact, some very strong performance.
On Page 7 you'll see positive active flows were experienced during the quarter were not from passive capabilities. Active flows were driven primarily by alternative capabilities as we saw strong growth in real estate, including both direct and REITs and Global Targeted Return. Both in the passive capabilities declined during the market volatility in January and February, that were covered in March but not enough to return to positive territory for the quarter. It's important to note that although passive flows were negative, they were reduced by $1.5 billion of deleveraging from investor mortgage capital. As a reminder, there's no revenue impact related to those flows. 
Again, we saw strong institutional flows during the quarter, in spite of the volatility which continues a series of positive institutional flows or back nearly 2 years. Line demand trends remain consistent with particular strong interest in fixed income, real estate and GTR. Retail flows were impacted by the macro environment as investors weighed their options during the volatile quarter despite seeing outflows in many equity mutual funds in the U.S. and EMEA. We saw continued strength in retail alternative capabilities specifically GTR or real estate securities. As noted, our global target insurance capability continues to track strong flows globally achieving to $.3 billion in that flows during the quarter, across EMEA institutional and across borders since the U.K., retail, Asia Pacific and North America. 
Despite some challenges in the first 2 months of the year, we feel good about the momentum of our business. Flows in March were much better than January and February, and we experienced solid flows in April. We continue to see strength across our global business and in particular within Asia Pacific and EMEA. 
Before I hand the call over to Loren, let me say a few rules about the fiduciary rule, released by the U.S. Department of Labor in April. Ultimately, we believe the fiduciary role is good for investors. That said, we continue to be concerned about the potential for unintended consequences of a rule that proposes such dramatic changes within the industry. It's well known that many investors aren't saving enough to maintain their standard of living during retirement. That deal house rule is intended to ensure that retirement savers get better advice by expanding the types of retirement investment advice covered by the fiduciary protections. We've said all along investors are best served by using advisors who can help them assist -- help them assess their risk tolerance, savings, and other factors to develop a portfolio that help them achieve their investment objectives. The key outcome of the new rule could be greater confidence in the advice investors are receiving. Investors have been through a lot in the last 7 years since the financial crisis. Anything that build confidence could encourage more for retirement and seek advice that helps them achieve their investment objectives. 
That's good for investors and will also benefit the industry as well. The DOL rule is long and complex. The rule and its related documents were more than 1,000 pages. It's important to understand how are partners are intending -- how are partners are interpreting the rule, which will help us support and assist them. We believe the recent acquisition of Jemstep, a market leader adviser focused digital solutions opens up further opportunities to provide meaningful support to our clients as we engage with our clients and seek to understand how they will approach adopting the new rules we'll look for opportunities for Jemstep to assist our distribution partners. We believe that it's very well positioned to help our clients as the overall rule is implemented because Invesco puts our clients first in everything we do and has transparent experience in addressing topics, we review this as an opportunity to further deepen our relationship, provide new capabilities and enhance our business. I'd like to turn over to Loren to review the financials in more detail

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty. So quarter-over-quarter, our total AUM decreased $4.1 million or 4.5% and that was driven by dispositions of $3.6 billion, negative market returns of $3 billion, outflows from [indiscernible] of $2.6 billion and long-term net outflows of $1
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty. So quarter-over-quarter, our total AUM decreased $4.1 million or 4.5% and that was driven by dispositions of $3.6 billion, negative market returns of $3 billion, outflows from [indiscernible] of $2.6 billion and long-term net outflows of $1.3 billion. These were partially offset by inflows from the money market of $3.8 million and positive FX translation of $2.6 billion. Our average AUM for the first quarter was $747.5 billion, which was down 4.6% versus the fourth quarter. Our net revenue yield came in at 43.8 basis points and that was a decrease of 1.4 basis points versus Q4. Currency mix reduced the yield by 0.7 basis points, 1 less day in the period reduced the yield by 0.4 basis points, a decrease in performance fees and other revenues together attend and for the remainder of 0.3 basis points. Now I'm going to turn to the operating results. Our net revenues declined by $68 million or 7.7% quarter-over-quarter to $818.1 million, which includes the negative FX rate impact of $12.6 million. Within the net revenue number, you'll see that investment management fees fell by $78.5 million or 7.8% to $930.3 million, this reflects the lower average AUM, the changes in the AUM product and currency mix and 1 less day in the quarter. FX reduced fourth quarter management fees by $16.1 million. 
Service and distribution revenues declined by $9.9 million or 4.8%, reflecting lower average AUM during the quarter. FX decreased service and distribution revenues by $0.2 million. Performance fees came in at $15.5 million in Q1 and they were earned from a variety of different investment capabilities, including $9.1 million from U.K. equities, foreign exchange reduced performance fees by $0.6 million. Other revenues in the first quarter were $24 million. That was a drop of $5 million lower due to lower transaction fees from real estate as well as a decline in UIT rollovers. Foreign exchange decreased revenues by $0.1 million. Third-party distribution, service and advisory expense between net against gross revenues fall by $28.7 million or 0.6% [ph] this movement was in line with lower revenues derived from retail AUM, our [indiscernible] decrease the expenses by $4.4 million. Moving on down the slide, you'll see that our adjusted operating expenses at $511 million decreased by $19.4 million or 3.7% relative to the prior quarter. Foreign exchange decreased operating expenses by $6.5 million during the quarter. Employee compensation came in at $340.3 million, an increase of $1.5 million or 0.4%. This is driven by a normal seasonal increase in payroll taxes, which was largely offset by reduction and variable compensation. FX reduced compensation by $4.3 million. Marketing expense decreased $9.2 million or 26.2% to $25.4 million. The drop was due to a lower level of advertising, literature, travel and client events during the quarter. These expenditures for deferred in light of the volatile market conditions that we're in. Foreign exchange reduced marketing expense by $0.2 million in the quarter. Property office and technology expenses came in at $81.1 million in the quarter, that was an increase of $0.7 million over the fourth quarter, driven by additional outsource administrative expenses. FX decreased these expenses by $0.9 million. 
General and administrative expenses at $64.2 million, decreased $12.2 million or 16.2%, this decline was a result of focused expense management during the quarter as nonessential perceptional services and other nonessential discretionary spending was reduced or postponed. FX decreased G&A by $1.1 million. Continuing on down the slide. You'll see that nonoperating income decreased $2.9 million compared to the fourth quarter. Included in the first quarter were noncash negative marks to -- March markets on each company loans of $7.1 million and $1.4 million on trading investments. These were slightly offset by a $3.4 million gain, which is realized on our pound sterling U.S. dollar hedge. 
Just to remind people as we've done in the past, we haven't placed a hedge through the end of Q1 2017 with a strike price of USD 1.4355. This is a pound that we put in place. The firms effective tax rate on pretax adjusted net income in Q1 was 26.5%. That was down from than 26.6% in the prior quarter, which then brings us to our adjusted EPS of $0.49 and adjusted net operating margin of 37.5%. 
Before turning things back to over to Marty, I just want to provide a quick update on the business optimization work that we began to implement in Q4 last year. As a reminder, we -- as we stated, we expect to incur up to $85 million in expenses during 2016 related to these activities with an expected run rate savings, however, of $30 million to $45 million through -- the beginning of 2017. 
In the first quarter, we incurred $6.8 million of the $85 million optimization costs. That was primarily in the form of staff severance cost and as discussed in our expenses do impact our U.S. GAAP P&L and they are being excluded from our non-GAAP results. And also just to finalize the, point. We did generate a profit approximately $2 million in permanent run rate savings in Q1 as a result of the optimization efforts to date, which was in line with our plans. 
And so with that I'm going to turn it over back to Marty.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just a follow-up question for Loren and Loren, I know there's a lot of moving pieces here and it's always tough to anticipate data, but the operating margin is always depressed in the first quarter due to a few items that we don't know ab
componenttext: Got it. And then just a follow-up question for Loren and Loren, I know there's a lot of moving pieces here and it's always tough to anticipate data, but the operating margin is always depressed in the first quarter due to a few items that we don't know about. But AUM finished the quarter much stronger and you have this initiatives in place. So I'm wondering, do we have a shot at getting the margin back to the 40% range with the stable markets here?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, great question. I mean we certainly would've hope to see margins improve through the course of the year. Obviously, there is a lot of moving parts, a lot of volatility. We got the pound and currency topics, which has been bouncing around a little bit
componenttext: Yes, great question. I mean we certainly would've hope to see margins improve through the course of the year. Obviously, there is a lot of moving parts, a lot of volatility. We got the pound and currency topics, which has been bouncing around a little bit. So I'm not going to put out a number in terms of what I think margins could be. Obviously, the inherent strength of the business is there. And as markets stabilize, currency stabilizes. We should continue to see a very positive trend of incremental margins working in our favor to pull up our overall rate of margin overall. But it will depend ultimately on what the markets do for the rest of the year. We are, as you know, still at the level of assets below where we were our average for last year. And so I'd say we're still catching up to where we were last year in terms of overall margin potential.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I may just add, there is actually nothing in the way of us exceeding 40% margins here where they were again. And I think that the issues -- it's a timing issue more than anything else with the markets. But I think also very importantly, regardless even
componenttext: So I may just add, there is actually nothing in the way of us exceeding 40% margins here where they were again. And I think that the issues -- it's a timing issue more than anything else with the markets. But I think also very importantly, regardless even though the market has come back some and those are near picking up again, we continue with the optimization programs and we're going to finish those and again, we'll just be net better of because of all those activities.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and just to remind people, I mean these optimization -- the optimization program is operating through the course of 2016 and we don't really get to the full run rate benefit until we get to the end of the year, which we talked about that $30 million
componenttext: Yes, and just to remind people, I mean these optimization -- the optimization program is operating through the course of 2016 and we don't really get to the full run rate benefit until we get to the end of the year, which we talked about that $30 million to $45 million potential. We are going to see some continued benefit through the course of this year. But again, sort of $2 million here, $3.5 million, $4.5 million, it's going to bend the scale through the course of the year. But it's still not at a level that, that's going to dramatically move the margin picture.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Next question is from Glenn of Evercore.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A 2-parter on a follow up there, with ending AUM over 3% better than average and April positive, and your positive comments on outflows. I look at the revenue decline in the quarter, year-on-year and half of that is on performance fees. So first question
componenttext: A 2-parter on a follow up there, with ending AUM over 3% better than average and April positive, and your positive comments on outflows. I look at the revenue decline in the quarter, year-on-year and half of that is on performance fees. So first question is, if you could talk through what we should expect from here over the progression of the year on performance is another tough to predict, but it was half the decline in revenues in the quarter so I think that might have a big influence on the margin question.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So you get into one of my favorite topics, Glenn, and predicting performance fees, which again, I will continue to profess, I'm not very able to do that. Generally, our performance fees are lighter during the last half of the year. They're the heavie
componenttext: Yes. So you get into one of my favorite topics, Glenn, and predicting performance fees, which again, I will continue to profess, I'm not very able to do that. Generally, our performance fees are lighter during the last half of the year. They're the heaviest in the first quarter and so you've sort of seen the heavy performance fee quarter already. So my expectation of performance fees through the remainder of the year as I often said is sort of place March [indiscernible] when we're thinking about our planning and we're around that $5 million a quarter, which is an estimate that assumes a lot of different things kicking in across the globe, but no 1 thing driving it. So I'd say that's one thing. I mean we would hope to see the other revenue line improved somewhat because the volatility in the first quarter was pretty extreme. And so as I mentioned, your transaction fees and real estate rollovers in the UIT business were really slowed down by that degree of volatility. If we get to a more stable, and that's a big if, if we get to a more stable market environment, that line item should be closer to $30 million to $35 million number through each quarter.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on the expense side, if you look at, I think it was comp marketing and G&A all declines, in line with nonperformance revenues or better. How much of that, I know that's a softy question, but how much of that is response to the weak revenue envir
componenttext: Okay. And on the expense side, if you look at, I think it was comp marketing and G&A all declines, in line with nonperformance revenues or better. How much of that, I know that's a softy question, but how much of that is response to the weak revenue environment in 1Q versus more run rate-ish type levels?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the optimization work is what's going to drive a permanent reduction. And so that stuff is, I don't want to say real. I mean, there's work that we can do and we have done it in the first quarter and we're going to continue to do through the rest o
componenttext: Yes. So the optimization work is what's going to drive a permanent reduction. And so that stuff is, I don't want to say real. I mean, there's work that we can do and we have done it in the first quarter and we're going to continue to do through the rest of the year in terms of trying to manage our discretionary expenses to lower levels. Some of that you can defer for a reasonable period of time. Some of it you can't defer forever. And so we do have some seasonal cost related to marketing that will be a little bit heavier in the first and fourth quarters as they always are.. So I think it's just good to know that we want to continue to be present and continue to be able to work with our clients and have client events as we've always had. That's important. It helps the business. It helps the growth of the business and we don't want to defer further expenses for a year, for example. So I think the other thing that we see in the second quarter versus the first quarter would be some of the impact around salary increases and deferred compensation which are typically -- you get a differential of about 2 months worth of impact in the second quarter versus the first quarter and between those 2 items, that's probably somewhere around an increase of $5 million to $6 million. So again, there is some things that we're going to manage and we're going to apply very thoughtful and disciplined approach to our hiring and to our discretionary expense management. But I don't want to sort of give guidance explicitly quarter-over-quarter because just given the volatility of markets and FX, it really becomes quite difficult for us to use for information.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, we think obviously, we're very excited about it and we look at it. It's definitely been the other I'm going to call it technology it was actually developed for the advisors themselves. And it's an open platform. And it contains everything all vehicles from ETFs to mutual funds and those are limitations to some of the others. And ours is to be supportive of the advisors not to compete with them. So there is no direct-to-consumer element to it and that was by design. And so we're able to able to just have a much deeper relationship with our clients all the thought leadership's capabilities to very recent clients through that so another very good venue there. And also again the combination of the high conviction fundamental and factor base capabilities where the mutual funds and so you think it's also going to broaden our channel and our exposure in the RIA market. And that's been sort of a early indicator and quite frankly, the level of interest has been quite surprising and I think that's frankly, somewhat, driven by the DOL also because they are looking for technologies to help serve their clients, and it's a market that really needs tools like this.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: To my first, I guess, would be on regulation and Marti, you mentioned unrelated circumstances, which is fair as a risk here. So may be could you -- do you have an estimate that you could size of how much of your AUM is in retirement accounts currently at least at this stage, given what we know the most clearly impacted by this DOL final rule? And then based on what you saw happened in the U.K. that just went through RDR, what lessons did you learn by going through that? And I'm guessing that had something to do with the unintended consequence comment and how does that put you in a position to be better prepared here in the U.S.?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So very good questions and really right on the mark. So look, we are all in the advice business. And being good fiduciaries is critical thing and putting clients versus us is essential. And being in the industry of trust matters a lot. And so at that
componenttext: Yes. So very good questions and really right on the mark. So look, we are all in the advice business. And being good fiduciaries is critical thing and putting clients versus us is essential. And being in the industry of trust matters a lot. And so at that level, the notion of fiduciary rule and having better outcomes for and clients, that's a great thing. I think we're all supportive about it, but it's really demand that chewed of what has been included in that will way beyond that notion and what we learned with RDR and it's just an absent fact that there are more on advised individuals because of RDR right now and they're probably the individuals that need advice the most and the totality of the costs have gone up. And I think that's a really bad outcome. And I think there is a lot of -- you could see that happening here. That said, so whether the lessons learned from that? Be aware that we also see that's also why we went down to Jemstep route, it is something that we know we can help our clients with tools like this make get advice more accessible for those that could be hurt frankly, from this rule. And again, that's not the intent of the rules that we think is impossible. And also important the how we position the firm. And I think this is being what's missing the conversation what money managers are going to do well and who might be challenged. If you're index over active management, I'd say you're in trouble. If you have high conviction fundamental and factor-based capabilities like we do, I think your positioned very, very well. And if again you look at the work that we've done when you look at high conviction actives, you do get that the returns through market cycles, but it's not just excess return. You have better downside capture. We also have better risk-adjusted returns and they think that's really the value position that collectively we need to make clear. It has been a beta run with since '09, largely with lots of government intervention. And you start to look at quarters like this where all of a sudden, you're seeing active managers outperform the S&P by 300, 350 basis points. So that's pretty impressive. So I think you have very, very strongly meeting positions us very well and as you can say come out of the lessons learned, lessons on the U.K. It's a bit long-winded but.

It is gaining momentum, it is the diversified set of smart beta offerings and we are gaining share in smart date the year-to-date. So we feel very confident about our ability to continue to grow that business.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think we will begin to see recovery of the net revenue yield and particularly as we get to the tap review versus the first half, day count stuff that just happens normally and we always have that benefit of the last half having more days than th
componenttext: Yes. So I think we will begin to see recovery of the net revenue yield and particularly as we get to the tap review versus the first half, day count stuff that just happens normally and we always have that benefit of the last half having more days than the first half. So I just want to make people aware of that. It's no secret. In terms of the mix. Obviously, we're having some reduced performance fee expectations coming into Q2 versus what we realize in Q1. Some of that's going to be offset however by higher -- hopefully higher other revenues, which will help move the fee rate up. And I think we also will see a success of our ETF business, the success of our fixed income business. A lot of that is in the pipeline. They lower fee rate so they will be probably some degree of a little bit against the higher fee. The flows that are -- that we have been getting into EMEA and U.S. retail, have been a little bit more subdued. And so that was the -- that can be a driver of fee rate mix. So I'd say that's going to be a little bit of a question mark particularly as we get through all the budget thing and happened in the U.K. that may have some impact it doesn't have any impact on flows per say that we could identify, but it could have some impact on flows. Based on our modeling and our thinking, we expect to see the fee rate drive up through the quarter as you move through the course of the year. And so again I think the positive aliment generally around mix I would say on the institutional pipeline, even despite what I said around fixed income coming in, this -- over all, the fee rate on the products that are coming in far exceeds the fee rate on the products that would be leaving. So again, positive aliment on the fee rate. That's actually also have a big impact to -- I think we saw a pretty big impact on FX in the quarter, 0.7 basis points. And so that's was with the U.K., down 5% quarter-over-quarter of the pound. So again just to understand that they do not mix are probably one of the biggest drivers of fee rates issues. And hopefully that does recover and we get stabilization of the pound.

componenttextpreview: I mean I think it will grow, certainly off of what we view as a pretty low base in Q1. As I mentioned it should pick up. Generally, our real state business has been growing well. And so that will, as a team, help allow that line item to grow. And I'd say
componenttext: I mean I think it will grow, certainly off of what we view as a pretty low base in Q1. As I mentioned it should pick up. Generally, our real state business has been growing well. And so that will, as a team, help allow that line item to grow. And I'd say particularly as being success in Europe and Asia, that's where a lot of the funds actually do have transaction fees and that the work in the U.S. some of the products that are managed by our real estate team don't actually aren't able to generate transaction fees. And so that is going to be a sort of U.S., non-U.S. makes. We think outside the U.S. there's a huge opportunity for the U.S. business and still has a lot of opportunity to grow at a faster rate even in the U.S. side. The UIT business you would hope to see that growth. It's been a very competitive market. And particularly in -- for us it somewhat transactional when people decide to roll their UIT if they do get volatility they're just going to wait and see. So we would want to see sort of a market stabilization which would allow our ability to roll that thing more rapidly or generate more active revenues as well. But we think that the UTI business has a lot of opportunity to grow. And so we would expect to see between those elements of that other line item grow again on an organic basis, we should be able to grow in that 3% to 5% level that we talked about before.

Its outperforming some of its competitors. So it's really been a success for us, and the other thing that I would also say, I know your question is just on EMEA. headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great question, so in terms of where we are in terms of the third quarter we had total cash of $1.455 million [ph], what is tied -- $1.45 billion. What's tied up in the U.K. subgroup, as we talked about from a regulatory perspective is $651 million. And s
componenttext: Great question, so in terms of where we are in terms of the third quarter we had total cash of $1.455 million [ph], what is tied -- $1.45 billion. What's tied up in the U.K. subgroup, as we talked about from a regulatory perspective is $651 million. And so sort of the free and clear is that 8 0 4. Q1 is always a very cash need quarter because of taxes and bonus payments. And so we fell below sort of our self-imposed targeting $1 billion, but we're not concerned about that. We're going to continue to be targeting a very healthy capital return in terms of dividends and buybacks as a percentage of our operating cash flow to shareholders. So in terms of our Q1 buyback, which we talked about, that was up 63% versus what we did in Q1 2015. So quite a bit of step up, $125 million but down a little bit versus the fourth quarter due to just generally, the lower operating cash that we are generating now because our asset levels are more affected by what happens in the market. But in terms of the percentage payout, we're sort of in line with what we were thinking about in terms of last year as a percentage of cash flow. But because our overall operating levels have been impacted by markets, the total levels may be somewhat smaller. So again, I think if you look at what we paid out, we'd probably be more in line with $1 million [ph] quarter run rate, which gets us at the same path rate that we have. But with that said, we're going to continue to be very opportunistic as we further impact on stock price at which we think is unwarranted if we get through some of the end understand some of the dynamics there. We feel more able to commit more capital. So again, it's one of those things that we feel very well positioned to return capital, but we are being a little bit cautious just given the volatility in the market right now.

I mean, how do you beside it's obviously, a huge unknown if it happens or what happens after it happens. So how do you -- and what can you prepare for that? I know it's may be a less than our products are registered, but operationally, what are some of the things that you try to put in place?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's a good question, needless to say, we've seen a few people working on it, just in case that happens. And the good news just as you're pointing to, is the way we have our product range is set up right now we're in a very, very fine shape. And a
componenttext: Yes. So it's a good question, needless to say, we've seen a few people working on it, just in case that happens. And the good news just as you're pointing to, is the way we have our product range is set up right now we're in a very, very fine shape. And also the way that we have our operations is also set up in a way that we will not be impacted negatively. There's a small exposure as we sort of extrapolate I think it's a couple of $1 billion of some assets that we think could sort of get caught up in the crosshairs. But again, there's a scenario planning so the exposures are high. So from that point of view, we're very well-placed. The issue is if it is an out, it is going to be -- the state of time is mid-'18 [ph] it will be part of the EU I would say most people that are involved in this would tell you the likelihood of trade agreements and the likelihood takes longer than that. It's just hard to assess what the psychological impact on investors would be. That said, we just think relatively, we're very well-placed to deal with it as it goes through. And I think really just getting past the reference positive regardless of what the outcome is.

componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then just a follow-up on operating leverage, you kind of expenses nicely about 9% or so year-on-year in the quarter. But revenues fell about 11.5% or so, so just curious, are you think about operating leverage here? headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: So again, we've said that when you get no market benefits. So if we stayed flat to where we are on an average asset bases, second quarter to first quarter that organic growth would allow us to see revenues improve. And so we would be able to get incremental margins at sort of 50%. And if we have market that's helping us to grow and FX as well incremental margins would be much higher to 65%. So we would hope to see, as Marty had talked about, our operating leverage begin to work in our favor as opposed to work against us as assets are recovering. And we absolutely will see that happening particularly as you managed to maintain a fairly tight control on the expense side. So that would be our hope is to get ourselves back to that 40%. And hopefully this year, just through organic growth and through expense management. If we have market on top of that, we should be able to do better than that. So there's nothing that stopped us from generating very strong operating leverage on the plus side if we have positive markets, it's plus FX plus organic growth working in our favor.

componenttext: Great that's helpful. And then just Marty, I guess, a little bit bigger picture on Department of Labor. It sounds like you've got a very good sort of offensive game plan with the Jemstep product and the open architecture model and being able to use your very wide product range, including the ETFs. But if you think about the sort of the defense of nature a lot of the asset managers will be going through high concentration of active product, is there any type of plan to work with the advisors in terms of the pricing class structures of the shares that you have now? And I guess, if you can sort of comment on how you think adviser behavior will turn out post the overall rule? And I'm sorry if I missed the assets and mutual funds in IRAs and 401(k), I'm just not sure if you can just.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's a good question. And I think the reality is, we've got to -- the lead is going to be taken by the distributors and how they're going to want to be addressing the rule. And that said, like we are and I'm sure everybody else is want me to be in
componenttext: Yes. So it's a good question. And I think the reality is, we've got to -- the lead is going to be taken by the distributors and how they're going to want to be addressing the rule. And that said, like we are and I'm sure everybody else is want me to be incredibly helpful to distributors as they work through the issues. That said, what I believe strongly in is that there is a very, very important role for advisors. We believe that's the best way to get outcomes for clients and also believe strongly that high conviction fundamental capabilities and factor base capabilities are what advisors want to do because they know how that's they can get a better value proposition for their clients. And just mechanically, there's -- the industry is pretty close already through their range of share classes that will be available if the vast majority they're going to be in adviser base plans. And these are stripped-down, shared classes are really what's going to be use. And so I'd say the money managers, I'm sure most everybody is well placed in that area. So -- but again, it's a little bit of a -- it's time to take the lead working with distributors on it. It is really complex actually, the rule. But the high-level assumptions that we've all made are probably still in place.

That said, the other element is, we have Invesco consulting, which has been a really, really important part of the value proposition we provide to advisors to help them work through all these different topics. And that, and the thought leadership in combination are going to be we think are very, very strong forces and us, being in a position to be strongly in place to help our distribution partners to do what they need to do.

componenttext: So good news is, state of our mandate is not in this number. It does not include that, and so the record number, I mean we're up 50% [ph] versus prior year.
