componenttextpreview: Okay. That sounds very strong I want to come back to one question that was asked earlier, and that's regarding your long-term targets, 3% to 5% I'm not sure if you guys had really thought about it this way. But when you guys were thinking about that growt
componenttext: Okay. That sounds very strong I want to come back to one question that was asked earlier, and that's regarding your long-term targets, 3% to 5% I'm not sure if you guys had really thought about it this way. But when you guys were thinking about that growth rate, what kind of level of growth were you thinking you'd need in active equity in order to get there? In other words, can active equity sort of be flattish or negative? And if Invesco could still potentially hit that 3% to 5% target?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think absolutely. It's across every single market that we're looking at. And I think the point of that is we're looking at consistency. We're not going to be the fastest grower in the industry because that's going to mean you got the one product that ev
componenttext: I think absolutely. It's across every single market that we're looking at. And I think the point of that is we're looking at consistency. We're not going to be the fastest grower in the industry because that's going to mean you got the one product that everyone wants in that one market and that's because we have a very diversified set of offering. Some are entirely active and others are on the more passive side, and so depending on the market that we're in, we should be able to grow at a more I think modest rate, but still very good rate at 3% of 5%. And it could be in certain of those market scenarios where active is an outflow and we're winning on the passive. That's not going to be every market, but it certainly been our current market where we're seeing the interest in passive being in the higher level than some of the active offerings. But I guess, you've seen our active and passive, both actually succeeding in this environment.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I want to reiterate a point that Loren made earlier to. I mean, we feel strongly that, that is -- the 3% to 5% is very, very achievable. And that's really -- we have not been in for a good number of years, a market that's inclined to active equity inv
componenttext: And I want to reiterate a point that Loren made earlier to. I mean, we feel strongly that, that is -- the 3% to 5% is very, very achievable. And that's really -- we have not been in for a good number of years, a market that's inclined to active equity investing. And I do believe that, that is going to change. I know there's a lot of doubters, but it's -- it can't persist this way. When that happens, I think you're going to beat the high-end of the range.

componenttextpreview: Its gross sales picking up, right? So typically what happens in those downturns, first thing that happens is people stop buying and that's where you get that -- and that's what generates the net. So you're actually starting to see growth flows -- gross sa
componenttext: Its gross sales picking up, right? So typically what happens in those downturns, first thing that happens is people stop buying and that's where you get that -- and that's what generates the net. So you're actually starting to see growth flows -- gross sales pickup, which is a very important indicator, I would say its sort of sentiment. Then with regards to the various SEC proposals, my view is the indications, I would say is that the SEC actually wants to get them done. They actually also want to get them right. If they are much more willing and capable of working with the industry to get the right answers, and so again, we'll have to see one by one, so I would say they're going to come, but I would hopefully get to places that are workable and we'll get to a relatively good spot. I will say again though, back to some of the earlier conversations, this does continue to put pressure on -- drive up compliance costs and in a difficult market, it's just very difficult for institutions to -- these are not optional expenses, right? And so if you do compliance costs in cyber, I think that's just being a larger money manager, you're much more -- better placed to be able to deal with those. So again, that can be a continued dynamic, I would say in the industry.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. This is Marty Flanagan, and thank you for joining us today. On the call with me today is Loren Starr, Invesco's CFO, and we'll be speaking from the presentation that's available on the website if you're so inclined to follow. Today, I'll review
componenttext:
Thank you. This is Marty Flanagan, and thank you for joining us today. On the call with me today is Loren Starr, Invesco's CFO, and we'll be speaking from the presentation that's available on the website if you're so inclined to follow. Today, I'll review the business results for the first quarter. Loren will go into greater details of the financials, and we'll open it up to questions. But let me begin by highlighting the firm's operating results for the first quarter, which you'll find on Slide 3. 
Long-term investment performance remained strong during the quarter, 72% and 76% of active managed assets were ahead of peers on a 3 to 5-year basis, respectively. Strong investment performance and our continued focus on meeting client needs were not enough to offset the impact of the volatile markets, particularly in January and February. Strong institutional and active demand were offset by volatility among retail and passive capabilities, which led to long-term net outflows of $1.3 billion during the quarter. Market volatility and net outflows put pressure on the operating margin during the quarter, which was 37.5%. During the quarter, we've returned $238 million to shareholders through dividends and stock buybacks. 
In addition, reflecting continued confidence in the fundamentals of our business over the long-term, we are raising our quarterly dividend to $0.28 per share, up 4% from the prior year. Assets under management were $771 billion at the end of the first quarter, down slightly from $775 billion at the end of last year. More indicative of the results during the quarter were the average assets under management, which are down $36 billion during the first quarter as compared to $738 billion at year-end. Operating income was $307 million in the quarter versus $356 million in the prior quarter. Earnings per share was $0.49 versus $0.58 in the prior quarter. And as noted earlier, we increased the dividend $0.28 per share. We also purchased $125 million of stock during the quarter. 
Before Loren goes into detail on the company financials, let me take a moment to review the investment performance and flows during the quarter. Turning to Slide 6 now. You'll note investment performance is strong in the quarter with 72% of assets in the top half on a 3-year basis and 76% were in the top half on a 5-year basis. One-year results partially reflect the underperformance of energy and financial sectors earlier in the year, which impacted some of our value portfolios. We've seen both of these sectors beginning to recover somewhat in March and April and consequently, positively impacted the performance year-to-date. In fact, some very strong performance.
On Page 7, you'll see positive active flows we're experienced during the quarter were not [indiscernible] passive capabilities. Active flows were driven primarily by alternative capabilities as we saw strong growth in real estate, including both direct and REITs and Global Targeted Return. Those in the passive capabilities declined during the market volatility in January and February, they were covered in March but not enough to return to positive territory for the quarter. It's important to note that although passive flows were negative, they were reduced by $1.5 billion of deleveraging from Invesco Mortgage Capital. As a reminder, there's no revenue impact related to those flows. 
Again, we saw strong institutional flows during the quarter in spite of the volatility, which continues a series of positive institutional flows going back nearly 2 years. Client demand demand trends remained consistent, with particular strong interest in fixed income, real estate and GTR. Retail flows were impacted by the macro environment as investors weighed their options during the volatile quarter. Despite seeing outflows in many equity mutual funds in the U.S. and EMEA, we saw continued strength in retail alternative capabilities, specifically GTR real estate securities. As noted, our Global Targeted Return capability continues to attract strong flows globally, achieving $2.3 billion in net flows during the quarter across EMEA institutional and cross-border. It's the U.K. retail, Asia Pacific and North America. 
Despite some challenges in the first 2 months of the year, we feel good about the momentum of our business. Flows in March were much better than January and February, and we're experiencing solid flows in April. We continue to see strength across our global business and in particular within Asia Pacific and EMEA. 
Before I hand the call over to Loren, let me say a few words about the new fiduciary rule released by the U.S. Department of Labor in early April. Ultimately, we believe the fiduciary rule is good for investors. That said, we continue to be concerned about the potential for unintended consequences of the rule that proposes such dramatic changes within the industry. It's well known that many investors aren't saving enough to maintain the standard of living during retirement. The DOL's rule is intended to ensure the retirement savers get better advice by expanding the types of retirement investment advice covered by the fiduciary protections. We said all along investors are best served by using advisers who can help them assist -- help them assess their risk tolerance, savings horizons and other factors to develop a portfolio that help them achieve their investment objectives. The key outcome of the new rule could be greater confidence in the advice investors are receiving. Investors have been through a lot in the last 7 years since the financial crisis. Anything that builds confidence could encourage them to save more for retirement and seek advice that helps them achieve their investment objectives. 
That's good for investors and will also benefit the industry as well. The DOL rule is long and complex. The rule and its related documents are more than 1,000 pages. We're working to understand how our distributor partners are intending -- how our partners are interpreting the rule, which will help us support and assist them. We believe the recent acquisition of Jemstep, a market-leading provider of adviser-focused digital solutions opens up further opportunities to provide meaningful support to our clients as we engage with our clients and seek to understand how they will approach adopting the new rules. We'll look for opportunities for Jemstep to assist our distribution partners. We believe Invesco is very well positioned to help our clients as the DOL rule is implemented, because Invesco puts our clients first in everything we do and has tremendous experience in addressing regulatory topics. We review this as an opportunity to further deepen our relationship, provide new capabilities and enhance our business. I'd like to turn it over to Loren to review the financials in more detail.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty. So quarter-over-quarter, our total AUM decreased $4.1 million or 0.5% and that was driven by dispositions of $3.6 billion, negative market returns of $3 billion, outflows from the QQQs [ph] of $2.6 billion and long-term net outflows of $1.3
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty. So quarter-over-quarter, our total AUM decreased $4.1 million or 0.5% and that was driven by dispositions of $3.6 billion, negative market returns of $3 billion, outflows from the QQQs [ph] of $2.6 billion and long-term net outflows of $1.3 billion. These were partially offset by inflows from the money market of $3.8 million and positive FX translation of $2.6 billion. Our average AUM for the first quarter was $747.5 billion, which was down 4.6% versus the fourth quarter. Our net revenue yield came in at 43.8 basis points and that was a decrease of 1.4 basis points versus Q4. Currency mix reduced the yield by 0.7 basis points, 1 less day in the period reduced the yield by 0.4 basis points. A decrease in performance fees and other revenues together accounted for the remainder of 0.3 basis points. Now I'm going to turn to the operating results. Our net revenues declined by $68 million or 7.7% quarter-over-quarter to $818.1 million, which includes the negative FX rate impact of $12.6 million. Within the net revenue number, you'll see the investment management fees fell by $78.5 million or 7.8% to $930.3 million. This reflects the lower average AUM, the changes in the AUM product and currency mix and 1 less day during the quarter. FX reduced fourth quarter management fees by $16.1 million. 
Service and distribution revenues declined by $9.9 million or 4.8%, reflecting lower average AUM during the quarter. FX decreased service and distribution revenues by $0.2 million. Performance fees came in at $15.5 million in Q1 and they were earned from a variety of different investment capabilities, including $9.1 million from U.K. equities. Foreign exchange reduced performance fees by $0.6 million. Other revenues in the first quarter were $24 million. That was a drop of $5 million lower due to lower transaction fees from real estate as well as a decline in UIT rollovers. Foreign exchange decreased revenues by $0.1 million. Third-party distribution, service and advisory expense which we net against gross revenues fell by $28.7 million or 7.6% and this movement was in line with lower revenues derived from retail AUM. Foreign exchange decreased these expenses by $4.4 million.
Moving on down the slide, you'll see that our adjusted operating expenses at $511 million, decreased by $19.4 million or 3.7% relative to the prior quarter. Foreign exchange decreased operating expenses by $6.5 million during the quarter. Employee compensation came in at $340.3 million, an increase of $1.5 million or 0.4%. This is driven by a normal seasonal increase in payroll taxes, which was largely offset by a reduction in variable compensation. FX reduced compensation by $4.3 million. Marketing expense decreased $9.2 million or 26.2% to $25.4 million. The drop was due to a lower level of advertising, literature, travel and client events during the quarter. These expenditures were deferred in light of the volatile market conditions that we're in. Foreign exchange reduced marketing expense by $0.2 million in the quarter. Property office and technology expenses came in at $81.1 million in the quarter, that was an increase of $0.7 million over the fourth quarter, driven by additional outsource administrative expenses. FX decreased these expenses by $0.9 million. 
General and administrative expenses at $64.2 million, decreased $12.4 million or 16.2%. This decline was a result of focused expense management during the quarter as nonessential professional services and other nonessential discretionary spending was reduced or postponed. FX decreased G&A by $1.1 million. Continuing on down the slide. You'll see that nonoperating income decreased $2.9 million compared to the fourth quarter. Included in the first quarter were noncash negative marks to March markets on intercompany loans of $7.1 million and $1.4 million on trading investments. These were slightly offset by a $3.4 million gain, which is realized on our pound sterling-U.S. dollar hedge. 
Just to remind people, as we've said in the past, we haven't placed a hedge through the end of Q1 2017 with a strike price of USD 1.4355. This was the pound hedge that we put in place. The firm's effective tax rate on pretax adjusted net income in Q1 was 26.5%. That was down from 26.6% in the prior quarter, which then brings us to our adjusted EPS of $0.49 and adjusted net operating margin of 37.5%. 
Before turning things back to over to Marty, I just want to provide a quick update on the business optimization work that we began to implement in Q4 last year. As a reminder, we -- as we stated, we expect to incur up to $85 million in expenses during 2016 related to these activities with an expected run rate savings, however, of $30 million to $45 million through -- at the beginning of 2017. 
In the first quarter, we incurred $6.8 million of the $85 million optimization costs. That was primarily in the form of staff severance cost and as previously discussed, these expenses do impact our U.S. GAAP P&L, but they are being excluded from our non-GAAP results. And also just to finalize the point, we did generate a profit of approximately $2 million in permanent run rate savings in Q1 as a result of the optimization efforts to date, which was in line with our plan. 
And so with that, I'm going to turn it back over to Marty.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Craig. Good follow-up question. So that was my point. Actually, if you look at the value portfolios they have had quite a bit of exposure to energy and financials in particular. And year-to-date performance actually has been quite stunning, and that's really started in the last couple of weeks here where things like comp stock is 90 percentile; growth in income, 4 percentile; American value, 3 percentile; so really, really very strong. So strong teams really do a good job with their philosophies and it is a high conviction approach, and the numbers are coming in really strong.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just a follow-up question for Loren. And Loren, I know there's a lot of moving pieces here and it's always tough to anticipate data, but the operating margin is always depressed in the first quarter due to a few items that we all know abo
componenttext: Got it. And then just a follow-up question for Loren. And Loren, I know there's a lot of moving pieces here and it's always tough to anticipate data, but the operating margin is always depressed in the first quarter due to a few items that we all know about. But AUM finished the quarter much stronger and you have this initiatives in place. So I'm wondering, do we have a shot of getting the margin back to the 40% range with stable markets here?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, great question. I mean we certainly would hope to see margins improve through the course of the year. Obviously, there is a lot of moving parts, lot of volatility. We got the pound and currency topics, which can -- have been bouncing around a little
componenttext: Yes, great question. I mean we certainly would hope to see margins improve through the course of the year. Obviously, there is a lot of moving parts, lot of volatility. We got the pound and currency topics, which can -- have been bouncing around a little bit. So I'm not going to put out a number in terms of what I think margins could be. Obviously, the inherent strength of the business is there. And as markets stabilize, currency stabilizes. We should continue to see the very positive trend of incremental margins working in our favor to pull up our overall rate of, sort of, margin overall. But it will depend ultimately on what the markets do for the rest of the year. We are, as you know, still at the level of assets below where we were on average for last year. And so I'd say we're still catching up to where we were last year in terms of overall margin potential.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I may just add a little bit of weight. There is absolutely nothing in the way of us exceeding 40% margins where they were again. And I think that the issue is -- it's a timing issue more than anything else with the markets. But I think also very import
componenttext: So I may just add a little bit of weight. There is absolutely nothing in the way of us exceeding 40% margins where they were again. And I think that the issue is -- it's a timing issue more than anything else with the markets. But I think also very importantly, regardless even though the market has come back some and those are picking up again, we continue with the optimization programs and we're going to finish those. And again, we'll just be net better of because of all those activities.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and just to remind people, I mean these optimization -- the optimization program is operating through the course of 2016, and we don't really get to the full run rate benefit until we get to the end of the year, which we talked about that $30 million
componenttext: Yes, and just to remind people, I mean these optimization -- the optimization program is operating through the course of 2016, and we don't really get to the full run rate benefit until we get to the end of the year, which we talked about that $30 million to $45 million potential. We are going to see some continued benefit through the course of this year. But again, sort of $2 million here, $3.5 million, $4.5 million, it's going to again to scale through the course of the year. But it's still not at a level, I'd say, that's going to be able to dramatically move the margin picture.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Glenn of Evercore.
componenttext: Next question is from Glenn of Evercore.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A 2-parter on a follow-up there, with ending AUM over 3%, better than average and April positive end-year, positive comments on outflows. I look at the revenue decline in the quarter, year-on-year and half of that was performance fees. So first question i
componenttext: A 2-parter on a follow-up there, with ending AUM over 3%, better than average and April positive end-year, positive comments on outflows. I look at the revenue decline in the quarter, year-on-year and half of that was performance fees. So first question is, if you could talk through what we should expect from here over the progression of the year on performance is another tough to predict, but it was half the decline in revenues in the quarter, so I think that might have a big influence on the margin question.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So you get to one of my favorite topics, Glenn, and predicting performance fees, which again, I will continue to profess, I'm not very able to do that. Generally, our performance fees are lighter through the last half of the year. They're the heavies
componenttext: Yes. So you get to one of my favorite topics, Glenn, and predicting performance fees, which again, I will continue to profess, I'm not very able to do that. Generally, our performance fees are lighter through the last half of the year. They're the heaviest in the first quarter and so you've sort of see the heavy performance fee quarter already. So my expectation of performance fees through the remainder of the year, as I often said, is sort of place marked, earmarked when we're thinking about our planning somewhere around that $5 million a quarter, which is an estimate that assumes a lot of different things kicking in across the globe, but no 1 thing driving it. So I'd say that's one thing. I mean we would hope to see the other revenue line improved somewhat because the volatility in the first quarter was pretty extreme. And then so, as I mentioned, the transaction fees in real estate rollovers in the UIT business were really slowed down by that degree of volatility. If we get to a more stable, and that's a big if, if we get to a more stable market environment, that line item should be closer to $30 million to $35 million number through each quarter.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on the expense side, if you look at, I think at comp marketing and G&A oil declines, in line with nonperformance fees revenues or better. How much of that, I know that's a softy question, but how much of that is response to the weak revenue envi
componenttext: Okay. And on the expense side, if you look at, I think at comp marketing and G&A oil declines, in line with nonperformance fees revenues or better. How much of that, I know that's a softy question, but how much of that is response to the weak revenue environment in 1Q versus more run rate-ish type levels?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the optimization work is what's going to drive a permanent reduction. And so that stuff is, I don't want to say real. But it certainly -- I mean, there's work that we can do and we have done in the first quarter and we're going to continue to do t
componenttext: Yes. So the optimization work is what's going to drive a permanent reduction. And so that stuff is, I don't want to say real. But it certainly -- I mean, there's work that we can do and we have done in the first quarter and we're going to continue to do through the rest of the year in terms of trying to manage our discretionary expenses to lower levels. Some of that you can defer for a reasonable period of time. Some of that you can't defer for forever. And so we do have some seasonal cost related to marketing that will be little bit heavier in the first and the fourth quarters as they always are. And so I think it's just good to know that we want to continue to be present and continue to be able to work with our clients and have client events as we've always had. That's important. It helps the business. It helps the growth of the business. And we don't want to defer those expenses for a year, for example. So I think the other thing that we see in the second quarter versus the first quarter would be some of the impacts around salary increases and deferred compensation, which are typically -- you get a differential of about 2 months worth of impact in the second quarter versus the first quarter and between those 2 items that's probably somewhere around an increase of $5 million to $6 million. So again, there are some things that we're going to manage and we're going to continue to apply very thoughtful and disciplined approach to our hiring and to our discretionary expense management. But I don't want to sort of give guidance explicitly quarter-over-quarter also because just given the volatility of markets and FX, it really becomes quite difficult for us to use for information.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Bill of Citi.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to come back to Jemstep for a moment. One of your peers is out there as well with their own platform. They've actually signed up a few third-party distributors to, I think, accelerate the opportunity there. Can you talk a little bit about how
componenttext: I just want to come back to Jemstep for a moment. One of your peers is out there as well with their own platform. They've actually signed up a few third-party distributors to, I think, accelerate the opportunity there. Can you talk a little bit about how you plan to leverage the platform and maybe synthesize that with your comments of the DOL?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we think -- obviously, we're very excited about it, and we look at it differently than the other, you want to call it technologies or verbals out there. It was actually developed for the advisers themselves. And it's an open platform. And it can u
componenttext: Yes. So we think -- obviously, we're very excited about it, and we look at it differently than the other, you want to call it technologies or verbals out there. It was actually developed for the advisers themselves. And it's an open platform. And it can use everything, all vehicles from ETFs to mutual funds. And those are limitations to some of the others. And ours is to be supportive of the advisers not to compete with them. And so there is no direct-to-consumer element to it and that was by design. And so we're able to just have a much deeper relationship with our clients all the thought leadership that we have is an element also delivering our solutions capabilities to various different clients through that, so another very good venue there. And also again, the combination of the high conviction fundamental and factor based capabilities, whether the mutual funds, ETFs, UITs. So we think it's also going to broaden our channel and our exposure in the RIA market. And that's been sort of a early indicator and quite frankly, the level of interest has been quite surprising. And I think that's frankly somewhat driven by the DOL also because they are looking for technologies to help serve their clients. And it's a market that really needs tools like this.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And this follow-up for Loren. On just margins over all, I think you talked about -- maybe it was in the press release or maybe it was your prepared comments that G&A was a bit on the softer side as you delayed some items. How do you think about that
componenttext: Okay. And this follow-up for Loren. On just margins over all, I think you talked about -- maybe it was in the press release or maybe it was your prepared comments that G&A was a bit on the softer side as you delayed some items. How do you think about that on a go-forward basis? And then stepping back, pretty wide rage on the optimization between, I guess, $30 million and $45 million, what would define the higher end of that range in terms of things to be done from here incrementally?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So great question. So on G&A, I mean, that's the line item that we probably in some ways are best able to manage. It has to do with travel and entertainment and use of professional services. And so those are the things that are easier for us to slow down
componenttext: So great question. So on G&A, I mean, that's the line item that we probably in some ways are best able to manage. It has to do with travel and entertainment and use of professional services. And so those are the things that are easier for us to slow down since they tend to be not as business critical as some of the other things around marketing for example. So we would hope to see continued success in terms of managing that line item. Although I would say there may be some things around some of the regulatory side that could drive certain needs and that could drive some cost in the G&A around sort of risk management and other compliance efforts.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cyber.
componenttext: Cyber.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cyber is another. Right. So that -- but I still think that is an area we're going to -- we're putting a lot of focus on to manage and maintain sort of somewhere around a run rate level that is in Q1. In terms of the broad range of the $30 million to $45 m
componenttext: Cyber is another. Right. So that -- but I still think that is an area we're going to -- we're putting a lot of focus on to manage and maintain sort of somewhere around a run rate level that is in Q1. In terms of the broad range of the $30 million to $45 million, there's still several of these initiatives that are going through the finalization of their planning phases. And so we don't have a clear line of sight of the ultimate impact. And so that's really what's driving that spread. Again, I think we are hopeful we're going to get to the higher end of that range. But we want to be thoughtful and not sort of commit to it until we're more certain which will begin to get more certain as we get through the course of this year and we'll provide that feedback to you as soon as know.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Just first Marty, you mentioned -- I think you said solid flows in April. First, just want to be clear. Does that imply solid net inflows? And then I'm also assuming that refers to kind of the firmwide total. So any just color on maybe magnitude or some of the underlying drivers behind that.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're a good skeptic. So thank you for the question. So yes, I meant inflows. So it's -- total net inflows is about $3.7 billion right now and about $1.9 billion is our long-term flows. And the institutional pipeline again, you're going to tired of he
componenttext: So you're a good skeptic. So thank you for the question. So yes, I meant inflows. So it's -- total net inflows is about $3.7 billion right now and about $1.9 billion is our long-term flows. And the institutional pipeline again, you're going to tired of hearing it, but it is good new story. It is an all-time high again and so that's another area of ongoing strength for us. I will say we are in that season where -- that's today what the flows are. This is a month where there is all that rebalancing throughout the industry. So we don't have line of sight -- who knows what happens between now and the rest of the week, right? So it could be a little noiseful, but I will tell you that the quarter, if it stays on this path, will be a good quarter. But it could look a little noisy month-to-month just because of all the industry sort of rebalancing, which is pretty typical and will not be unique to us. But it's very different environment I'd say right now than just where we're January and February.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in terms of what's really been quite successful right now, Michael, we're seeing sort of continued things around real estate, fixed income alternatives, global asset allocation, multi-asset products that quant are all highly featured in our institutio
componenttext: And in terms of what's really been quite successful right now, Michael, we're seeing sort of continued things around real estate, fixed income alternatives, global asset allocation, multi-asset products that quant are all highly featured in our institutional pipeline. And then the other regionally, we continue to see strong -- really strong flow momentum both on the retail and the institutional side in Asia, Asia Pac in particular. And then another note just in terms of ETFs, ETFs are positive in every single region that we're operating and in terms of positive flows and so we continue to see the interest in that capability being at a high level.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then maybe 1 for you Loren, sorry for kind of the narrowness of the questions here. But you called out some expenses that were sort of deferred or postponed or maybe some nonessential cost that maybe fell by the wayside. Just s
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then maybe 1 for you Loren, sorry for kind of the narrowness of the questions here. But you called out some expenses that were sort of deferred or postponed or maybe some nonessential cost that maybe fell by the wayside. Just so I'm clear, are those items part of the business optimization plan? Or are they incremental to sort of the $30 million to $45 million of savings you've identified?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's incremental. So the -- what you're seeing in the first quarter, the expense reduction has only $2 million of that has to do with business optimization. As I mentioned, everything else is just related to us just managing expenses in a fairly di
componenttext: Yes. That's incremental. So the -- what you're seeing in the first quarter, the expense reduction has only $2 million of that has to do with business optimization. As I mentioned, everything else is just related to us just managing expenses in a fairly disciplined way and trying to defer where we can defer. We're going to continue to do that as I mentioned through the course of the year. The business optimization is going to continue to roll and help on top of that activity to improve our overall sort of expense management.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next is from Brennan of UBS.
componenttext: Next is from Brennan of UBS.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: To my first, I guess, would be on regulation, and Marty, you referenced unintended consequences,which is certainly fair as a risk here. But maybe could you -- do you have an estimate that you could size of how much of your AUM is in retirement accounts cu
componenttext: To my first, I guess, would be on regulation, and Marty, you referenced unintended consequences,which is certainly fair as a risk here. But maybe could you -- do you have an estimate that you could size of how much of your AUM is in retirement accounts currently in therefore, at least at this stage, given what we know, the most clearly impacted by this DOL final rule? And then, based on what you saw happened in the U.K. that just went through, RDR, what lessons did you learn by going through that? And I'm guessing that had something to do with the unintended consequence comment, and how does that put you in a position to be better prepared for this rule here in the U.S.?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So very good questions and really right on the mark. So look, we are all in the advice business. And being good fiduciaries is a critical thing and putting clients first is actually essential. And being the industry of trust matters a lot. And so at
componenttext: Yes. So very good questions and really right on the mark. So look, we are all in the advice business. And being good fiduciaries is a critical thing and putting clients first is actually essential. And being the industry of trust matters a lot. And so at that level, the notion of fiduciary rule and having better outcomes for end clients, that's a great thing. I think we're all supportive of it, but it's really the magnitude of what has been included in the rule way beyond that notion. And what we learned with RDR, and it's just an absolute fact, there are more on advised individuals because of RDR right now and probably the individuals that need advice the most and the totality of the costs have gone up. And I think that's a really bad outcome. And I think there is a lot of -- you could see that happening here. That said, what are the lessons learned that we had from that is, be aware of that. We also see that's also why we went down to Jemstep route. It is something that we know we can help our clients with tools like this, make it -- advice more accessible for those that could be hurt frankly from this rule. And again, that's not the intent of the rules that's what we think is possible and also very importantly how we position the firm. And I think this is what's being missed in the conversation. What money managers are going to do well and who might be challenged? If you're an index hugger, active management, I'd say you're in trouble. If you have high conviction fundamental and factor-based capabilities like we do, I think you're positioned very, very well. And if -- again, if you look at the work that we've done, when you look at high conviction actives, you do get better returns through market cycles, but it's not just excess return. You have better downside capture. You also have better risk-adjusted returns and I think that's really the value proposition that collectively we need to make clear. It has been a beta run with since '09, largely with lots of government intervention. And you start to look at quarters like where all of a sudden, you're seeing active managers outperform the S&P by 300, 350 basis points, that's pretty impressive. So again, I think you have to have high conviction fundamental, and the factor base, we believe very, very strongly in the combination thereof. We think positions us very well and much of that would, as you'd say, come out of some lessons learned, we learned out of the U.K. Sorry, it's a bit long-winded but.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I appreciate the thorough response, Marty. Thank you. And then follow-up. Just sort of a little bit more ticky-tacky. I think you'd said that the ETF flows were positive across regions. Were you talking about 1Q? And it looked like passive redemptions
componenttext: No, I appreciate the thorough response, Marty. Thank you. And then follow-up. Just sort of a little bit more ticky-tacky. I think you'd said that the ETF flows were positive across regions. Were you talking about 1Q? And it looked like passive redemptions have been accelerating here over the last several quarters. So is that U.K. driven? And what's driving that? Can you help us unpack and square those 2 statements a bit?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I'll answer that because it was my statement I think. So I was referring positive in every region and that's April. So I was really referring to the April numbers. However, I would say, in the first quarter, the first 2 months were not great mont
componenttext: Okay. So I'll answer that because it was my statement I think. So I was referring positive in every region and that's April. So I was really referring to the April numbers. However, I would say, in the first quarter, the first 2 months were not great months are passive for whatever ETF offerings. But I'd say March was a record in terms of our sales. So it really came back strongly. And as I indicated, it's continuing strong into April. The positive category that we show, Marty mentioned it, I mean got very much affected by the deleveraging of IVR. So it really is not [indiscernible] noise in our numbers because the deleveraging has no impact on revenues and even though we accounted it as an outflow. It's just really part of how they're managing that [indiscernible]. So I wouldn't read too much into the first quarter passive outflow story. Really just understanding that, we do believe that our ETF's business is very well positioned. It is gaining momentum. It is the most diversified set of smart beta offerings, and we are gaining share in smart beta year-to-date. So we feel very confident about our ability to continue to grow that business.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next is from Ken of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Next is from Ken of JPMorgan.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple for Loren. Maybe first, when we think about the management fee rate for active and passive funds, both were down a lot for the quarter, I think may be largely expected, maybe the magnitude was off a bit. Maybe can you first talk about how the fee r
componenttext: Couple for Loren. Maybe first, when we think about the management fee rate for active and passive funds, both were down a lot for the quarter, I think may be largely expected, maybe the magnitude was off a bit. Maybe can you first talk about how the fee rate should recover given the bounce back in equity market, foreign markets, various currencies? Have we -- should we recover a lot of the way or part of the way or all of the way, any color there would be great? And then if you could maybe flesh out better for us places where the mix change in 1Q that maybe had the most pronounced impact on the fee rate decline this quarter?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think we will begin to see recovery of the net revenue yield and particularly as we get into the last half of the year versus the first half, there is some day count stuff that just happens normally. And we always have that benefit of the last h
componenttext: Yes. So I think we will begin to see recovery of the net revenue yield and particularly as we get into the last half of the year versus the first half, there is some day count stuff that just happens normally. And we always have that benefit of the last half having more days than the first half. So I just want to make people aware of that. It's no secret. In terms of the mix, obviously, we're having some reduced performance fee expectations coming into Q2 versus what we realized in Q1. Some of that's going to be offset, however, by higher -- hopefully higher other revenues, which will help move the fee rate up. And I think we also will see a success of our ETF business, success of our fixed income business. A lot of that is in the pipeline. They tend to have lower fee rate so there will be probably some degree of mix issue that's working a little bit against the higher fee. The flows that are -- that we have been getting into EMEA and U.S. retail, have been a little bit more subdued, and so that was -- it can be a driver of fee rate mix and so I'd say that's going to be a little bit of a question mark, particularly as we get through the whole Brexit thing and understanding what happened in the U.K. that may have some impact we don't know. It hasn't had any impact on flows per se that we could identify yet, but it could have some impact on flows. Based on our modeling and our thinking, we expect to see the fee rate drive up further each quarter as we move through the course of the year. And so again, I think the positive element's generally around mix still exists and I would say that on the institutional pipeline, even despite what I said around fixed income coming in, overall, the fee rate on the products that are coming in far exceeds the fee rate on the products that would be leaving. So again, a positive element on the fee rate. FX will also have a big impact too and I think we saw a pretty big impact on FX in the quarter, 0.7 basis points. And so that's was with U.K. down 5% quarter-over-quarter, the pound. So again just to understand that those dynamics are probably one of the big drivers of fee rates issues. And hopefully, that does recover as we get to Brexit and we get stabilization of the pound.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then on the other revenue, obviously, down a bunch for the quarter. Can you maybe help us on an outlook for this? So there's a number of components, real estate and UITs are one. How should this line be growing over time? And maybe, how should
componenttext: Great. And then on the other revenue, obviously, down a bunch for the quarter. Can you maybe help us on an outlook for this? So there's a number of components, real estate and UITs are one. How should this line be growing over time? And maybe, how should it be growing compared to something like the management fee line? So obviously, both are going to move up or down depending on market conditions but should the other revenue be growing faster or slower over time? And then maybe more near-term in terms of an outlook based on your guys' views on kind of real estate activity and maybe what you're seeing more idiosyncratically in the UIT markets. How should we think about that line item, maybe for the rest of the year?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think it will grow, certainly off of what we view as a pretty low base in Q1, as I mentioned, it should pick up. Generally, our real state business has been growing well and so that will, as a team, help allow that line item to grow. And I'd say
componenttext: I mean, I think it will grow, certainly off of what we view as a pretty low base in Q1, as I mentioned, it should pick up. Generally, our real state business has been growing well and so that will, as a team, help allow that line item to grow. And I'd say particularly as being a success in Europe and Asia, that's where a lot of the funds actually do have transaction fees and that work in the U.S., some of the products that are managed by our real estate team don't, actually aren't able to generate transaction fees. And so that is going to be sort of a U.S., non-U.S. mix. So we think outside the U.S. is a huge opportunity for the real estate business and still has a lot of opportunity to grow at a faster rate, even in the U.S. side. The UIT business, we would hope to see that grow. It's been a very competitive market and particularly in -- because it's somewhat transactional, when people decide to roll their UITs, if you do get volatility, they're just going to wait and see. And so we would want to see sort of a market stabilization which would allow our ability to roll those things more rapidly and generate more other revenues as well. But I mean, we think that the UIT business has a lot of opportunity to grow, and so we would expect to see between those elements, that other line item grow. Again, on an organic growth basis, we should be able to grow in that 3% to 5% level that we talked about before.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next is from Chris of William Blair.
componenttext: Next is from Chris of William Blair.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think early last year, there was a really good story around cross-border, some of the European products are flowing very well. It seemed like performance there has softened a little bit on a couple of products, others are still very good. The environmen
componenttext: I think early last year, there was a really good story around cross-border, some of the European products are flowing very well. It seemed like performance there has softened a little bit on a couple of products, others are still very good. The environment has clearly gotten tougher. So maybe just talk about how you're feeling about cross-border, that product range and the growth outlook for the remainder of the year.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we still feel -- a very important part of our business, we still look at it as an engine of growth over the next few years as the magnitude of change and the impact to the company has been very positive the last few years. Clearly, with the market
componenttext: Yes. So we still feel -- a very important part of our business, we still look at it as an engine of growth over the next few years as the magnitude of change and the impact to the company has been very positive the last few years. Clearly, with the market uncertainty and then you do some of the macro environment there, whether it be price that you -- some of the concerns on the continent. It's definitely slowed down the quarter. That as -- we just feel very well positioned as we look to continue to gain market share. With regard to the performance, somewhat of a similar story that some of the U.S. portfolios I mentioned, there's some of the exposure in some of the European portfolios who are in financials and some energy. And so there was that little bit of a drag for PERE. But again, they're very, very good managers, excellent and highly regarded. And I would classify it more as market uncertainty than lack of confidence in the investment team. So [indiscernible] it will never go away. I think we'll be back on that growing path.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll also just add, I mean, our product range in Europe, still more than half of the assets are in first quartile, so it's very strong. And when you look at the second quartile on a 5-year basis, it's more than 90% of the assets are beating peers on a 5-y
componenttext: I'll also just add, I mean, our product range in Europe, still more than half of the assets are in first quartile, so it's very strong. And when you look at the second quartile on a 5-year basis, it's more than 90% of the assets are beating peers on a 5-year basis. So we think that there's plenty of opportunity for us to be able to satisfy our client's needs with the products that we have. You're right, some have softened a little bit relative to end of the year but it's still overall exceedingly strong.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just add one more thing. So not just retail, but again, EMEA in particular is another area where the growth prospects for the institutional business is very, very strong. Early days of success from what we're anticipating over the next couple of year
componenttext: I'll just add one more thing. So not just retail, but again, EMEA in particular is another area where the growth prospects for the institutional business is very, very strong. Early days of success from what we're anticipating over the next couple of years.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one other one on PowerShares. There was some talk last year I think, of going through a bit of a -- I don't know what to call it, a repositioning or rebranding type of exercise, much of it around factors. I know you've done some stuff there
componenttext: Okay. And then one other one on PowerShares. There was some talk last year I think, of going through a bit of a -- I don't know what to call it, a repositioning or rebranding type of exercise, much of it around factors. I know you've done some stuff there, rolled out some new product but it's been, I think, fairly targeted to date. So I guess, the question is just do you feel like you need to be more aggressive there in making changes to that business? I guess, it looks like if you exclude the Qs over the last year through March, the flows have been fairly minimal relative to a pretty favorable factor up for the industry as a whole.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question. I'd answer it 2 different ways. It is one of the areas that we have invested in quite strongly over the last number of years because we anticipated, as Loren talked about, is the factor base element of it. It's a growing part of the industr
componenttext: Good question. I'd answer it 2 different ways. It is one of the areas that we have invested in quite strongly over the last number of years because we anticipated, as Loren talked about, is the factor base element of it. It's a growing part of the industry and we are a leader there. We have a very broad, long-dated back record, and so the investments have been meaningful. With regard to the flows, I think what you have to look at is how narrow the flows were within the factor base ETFs. And probably from September through the end of February, it's about as narrow as you've ever seen. And what we're now seeing, as Loren was talking about, why are the flows picking up the way that they are. We're seeing a broadening of interest in the range of capabilities that we have. So we look at it as an important subset of that whole factor base that we have as an organization and we feel we're absolutely on top of it. And I think you'll start to see it again in the flows here as we move through the year.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Dan of Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question is from Dan of Jefferies.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, first on EMEA or Asia, you continue to have great flows there, the $3.6 billion or so, the only region of inflows. Can you talk about concentration I guess, within those flows, either through like the distribution areas or products or how the --
componenttext: I guess, first on EMEA or Asia, you continue to have great flows there, the $3.6 billion or so, the only region of inflows. Can you talk about concentration I guess, within those flows, either through like the distribution areas or products or how the -- I guess, or how diversified those flows are?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think it's a good question. I mean, in EMEA generally, we've seen huge success with our GTR product, both institutionally and on the retail side. And that's been, I'd say, probably our primarily driver of inflows in the region. So it has been probabl
componenttext: So I think it's a good question. I mean, in EMEA generally, we've seen huge success with our GTR product, both institutionally and on the retail side. And that's been, I'd say, probably our primarily driver of inflows in the region. So it has been probably a little bit concentrated to your point in that capability. I mean, we still think there's some very, very strong capabilities like our quant capability for example. I think it's called structured equity, doing very well. But this current environment in the first quarter was an anomaly for everyone in terms of what behavior you'd expect. And so I do think hopefully, we'll begin to see more take on and a broader sales picture than just GTR. But GTR by the way, I just wanted to not minimize it, that plan is doing very, very well. It's outperforming some of its competitors, so it's really been a success for us. And the other thing I would also say and on your question just on EMEA, again, I can't say how happy we are that our Asia Pac business has been really, really strong. So the outside the U.S. which is both Asia Pac and EMEA, has been very diverse in Asia Pac in terms of what's being taken on through equities, alternatives and fixed income.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just add that again, its not a concern about GTR's success. We think it's up and positive. And again, Loren made a point before, if you look at the range of capabilities in EMEA and a very, very strong performance in the reputation of the team
componenttext: And I would just add that again, its not a concern about GTR's success. We think it's up and positive. And again, Loren made a point before, if you look at the range of capabilities in EMEA and a very, very strong performance in the reputation of the teams, it's not a concern as far as I'm concerned.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then I guess, just a follow-up on the optimization. I think you said $2 million was realize this quarter. Can you give us a kind of run rate or path through the year to think about how the rest of that is going to flow through or the pace of th
componenttext: Great. And then I guess, just a follow-up on the optimization. I think you said $2 million was realize this quarter. Can you give us a kind of run rate or path through the year to think about how the rest of that is going to flow through or the pace of that benefit?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's going to step up each quarter. And as I said, the $2 million would probably get to more like a $3.5 million then $4.5 million, $5.5 million as we work through the course of year. Those are sort of rough numbers and some timing could be a litt
componenttext: Yes. So it's going to step up each quarter. And as I said, the $2 million would probably get to more like a $3.5 million then $4.5 million, $5.5 million as we work through the course of year. Those are sort of rough numbers and some timing could be a little bit off. But that would get us ultimately, as we get into 2017, in that run rate of 30 to 45 which we feel very confident in. Whether we get to 45, we'll let you know as I mentioned, as we get through the course of the year.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Eric of Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: Next question is from Eric of Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Kenneth Lee on for Eric. Just had a question of, there was previously, a mentioned that there tend to be a share repurchase that perhaps elevated rates this year. Just want to get a better handle on potential mindset that you guys could maybe thin
componenttext: This is Kenneth Lee on for Eric. Just had a question of, there was previously, a mentioned that there tend to be a share repurchase that perhaps elevated rates this year. Just want to get a better handle on potential mindset that you guys could maybe think about, whether you have any kind of restriction in terms of the cash balance that you guys have on hand, which could either be onshore or offshore. Just wanted to get a better handle on how to think about that.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great question, so in terms of where we are at the end the quarter, we had total cash of $1.455 million. What is tied -- I'm sorry, billion so $1.45 billion. What's tied up in the U.K. subgroup as we've talked about from a regulatory perspective is the $6
componenttext: Great question, so in terms of where we are at the end the quarter, we had total cash of $1.455 million. What is tied -- I'm sorry, billion so $1.45 billion. What's tied up in the U.K. subgroup as we've talked about from a regulatory perspective is the $651 million. And so sort of the free and clear is that 8 0 4. Q1 is always a very heavy cash need quarter because of taxes and bonus payments, so we fell below sort of our self-imposed sort of target of $1 billion, but we're not concerned about that. We're still going to continue to be targeting a very healthy capital return in terms of dividends and buybacks as a percentage of our operating cash flow to shareholders. So in terms of our Q1 buyback, which we talked, I mean, that was up 63% versus what we did in Q1 in 2015, so quite a bit of step up, $125 million. But down a little bit versus the fourth quarter due to just generally, the lower operating cash that we are generating now because our asset levels are more affected by what happens in the market. But in terms of the percentage payout, we're sort of in line with what we were thinking about in terms of last year as a percentage of cash flow. But because our overall operating levels have been impacted by markets, the total levels may be somewhat smaller. So again, I think if you look at what we paid out, I mean, it's probably more in line with an $18 million [ph] quarter run rate which gets us at that same payout rate that we didn't have. But with that said, we're going to continue to be very opportunistic as we see further impact on stock price which we think is unwarranted. If we get through some of the Brexit and understanding dynamics there. We may feel more able to commit more capital. So again, it's one of these things that we feel very well positioned to return capital, but we are being a little bit cautious, just given the volatility in the market right now.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Robert of KBW.
componenttext: The next question is from Robert of KBW.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You didn't think you were going to get through a call without a Brexit question.
componenttext: You didn't think you were going to get through a call without a Brexit question.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: What's that?
componenttext: What's that?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I guess, I'll ask one. So aside from the currency hedge and whatnot, just kind of maybe update us on how you think about contingency planning forward? I mean, how do you -- besides these obviously huge unknowns, if it happens or what happens afte
componenttext: Okay. So I guess, I'll ask one. So aside from the currency hedge and whatnot, just kind of maybe update us on how you think about contingency planning forward? I mean, how do you -- besides these obviously huge unknowns, if it happens or what happens after it happens, so how do you and what can you prepare for that? I know it's maybe less about where products are registered but operationally, what are some of the things that you try to put in place?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's a good question and needless to say, we have a team of people that have been working on it, just in case that happens. And the good news just as you're pointing to, the way that we have our product ranges set up right now, we're in a very, ve
componenttext: Yes. So it's a good question and needless to say, we have a team of people that have been working on it, just in case that happens. And the good news just as you're pointing to, the way that we have our product ranges set up right now, we're in a very, very fine shape. And also the way that we have our operations is also set up in a way that we will not be impacted negatively. There's a small exposure as we sort of extrapolate. I think it's a couple billion dollars of some assets that we think could sort of get caught up in the crosshairs. But again, it's just a scenario planning, so the exposures are high. So from that point of view, we're very well-placed. The issue is if it is an outvote, it is going to be -- the stated time is until mid-'18 that's the -- it will be part of the EU. I'd say most people that are very involved in this would tell you the likelihood of trade agreements and the likelihood it takes longer than that. It's just hard to assess what the psychological impact on investors would be. That said, we just think relatively, we're very well-placed to deal with it as it goes through. And I think really, just getting past the referendum is going to be just positive regardless of what the outcome is.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certain things[ph].
componenttext: Certain things[ph].

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just kind of, I guess maybe this is a presentation question or whatnot, but can you maybe give us a sense, in the path of AUM, what proportion of that is not fee-generating or management fee-generating? I mean, clearly last quarter, there
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just kind of, I guess maybe this is a presentation question or whatnot, but can you maybe give us a sense, in the path of AUM, what proportion of that is not fee-generating or management fee-generating? I mean, clearly last quarter, there was noise and flows around deleveraging of basically non-fee assets and clearly, you break out the QQQ flows which don't generate management fees but you're not in the UIT's and other things, so if we're really trying to look at kind of a pure asset base there that's generating the management fee revenues, what would that be today? And maybe just one request that may be a helpful metric to think about providing going forward.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I think when you look at it, the Qs, that's about $38 billion, the IVR leverage is somewhere around $20 billion and then the UIT business which does generate revenue when they get rolled up, once they've been sort of put in place, they don't, tha
componenttext: Okay. So I think when you look at it, the Qs, that's about $38 billion, the IVR leverage is somewhere around $20 billion and then the UIT business which does generate revenue when they get rolled up, once they've been sort of put in place, they don't, that's about $18 billion. So those are the big chunks that you'd have to add up to figure out [indiscernible] revenue-generating.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. That's helpful. And then maybe just one last modeling question. I mean, understanding there's a lot of moving pieces in comp and whatnot. If you think of the first quarter here, was there anything in there? I mean obviously, there's always so
componenttext: Okay, great. That's helpful. And then maybe just one last modeling question. I mean, understanding there's a lot of moving pieces in comp and whatnot. If you think of the first quarter here, was there anything in there? I mean obviously, there's always some seasonality in the U.S. but beyond maybe some modest seasonality there, is there anything in there that we should think of maybe falls away next quarter outside of the expense initiatives that are in place? Or should we be thinking that all else equal is kind of a reasonable run rate?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I mean, in terms of sort of Q2 to Q1 impacts, you've got obviously, payroll taxes sort of falling away, so that's a benefit of some sort of $15 million, $20 million but then you got some offset as I mentioned, in terms of salary increases and [ind
componenttext: Yes, so I mean, in terms of sort of Q2 to Q1 impacts, you've got obviously, payroll taxes sort of falling away, so that's a benefit of some sort of $15 million, $20 million but then you got some offset as I mentioned, in terms of salary increases and [indiscernible] compensation and sort of plus $6 million. We obviously are beginning to work through some of those optimization things and so you'll get some continued run rate benefit going, probably a benefit of $3.5 million to $2 million, if that does translate to another $1.5 million benefit. Some of that might get offset if we actually have a higher levels of assets and revenues, some of our incentive compensation will scale up with our operating income as it always does. So again, all those things together, again, I'm not going to give you too much a number here. Probably, hopefully, comp will actually be flat-to-up with the benefit of higher asset levels, end markets driving incentive compensation ahead.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Michael of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next question is from Michael of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious under what conditions you think Invesco can grow organically. Your business closely resembles another in the industry. Yet, they grow consistently off a higher base and I know you're targeting 3% to 5% organically to grow and flows sound like
componenttext: Just curious under what conditions you think Invesco can grow organically. Your business closely resembles another in the industry. Yet, they grow consistently off a higher base and I know you're targeting 3% to 5% organically to grow and flows sound like they're pretty strong in April, but I'm just curious under what condition can we see Invesco grow consistently from here?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, look, I think if you look historically, we've been one of the most absolutely consistent growers throughout all the different market scenarios. I think what we've learned, if you look at the last quarter again, when you're in a January, Febru
componenttext: Yes, I mean, look, I think if you look historically, we've been one of the most absolutely consistent growers throughout all the different market scenarios. I think what we've learned, if you look at the last quarter again, when you're in a January, February environment, it is just very difficult. You get more to an environment that we're in now, where yes, there's still plenty of world uncertainties. A firm like us, you'll grow and you'll see it both institutionally in retail and again, as both Loren and I have brought out, you can see looking at different parts of the world right now, again, each region is actually growing. So you don't need a lot, it's just when you have that massive uncertainty that is it is very difficult.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think you said in the past Marty too, but when you get to an equity-led market which I don't know if you're going to see that anytime soon. But if we did get an equity-led market, we will probably be able to grow much more quickly than you've se
componenttext: I mean, I think you said in the past Marty too, but when you get to an equity-led market which I don't know if you're going to see that anytime soon. But if we did get an equity-led market, we will probably be able to grow much more quickly than you've seen us do in the past because a large percentage of our AUM is equity. And so again, that would be converse of what we've been in the fray. I mean, [indiscernible] volatility.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then just a follow-up. Operating leverage, your kind of expense is nicely about 9% or so year-on-year in the quarter, but revenues fell about 11.5% or so. So just curious, are you thinking about operating leverage here? And wha
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then just a follow-up. Operating leverage, your kind of expense is nicely about 9% or so year-on-year in the quarter, but revenues fell about 11.5% or so. So just curious, are you thinking about operating leverage here? And what level of market returns say, AUM growth do we need to see in order to see positive operating leverage? And can you improve margins at flat AUM levels?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again, we've said that when you get no market benefits, so if we stayed flat to where we are on an average asset basis, the second quarter to first quarter, that organic growth would allow us to see revenues improve, and so we would be able to get incr
componenttext: So again, we've said that when you get no market benefits, so if we stayed flat to where we are on an average asset basis, the second quarter to first quarter, that organic growth would allow us to see revenues improve, and so we would be able to get incremental margins at sort of 50%. And if we have markets that's helping us to grow and FX I would say as well, incremental margins could be much higher to 65%. So we would hope to see, as Marty had talked about, our operating leverage begin to work in our favor as opposed to work against us as assets are recovering. And we absolutely will see that happening, particularly as we've managed to maintain a fairly tight control on the expense side. So that would be our hope, is to get ourselves back to that 40%. And hopefully this year, just through organic growth and expense management. If we have market on top of that, we should be able to do better than that. So there's nothing that stopped us from generating very strong operating leverage on the plus side if we have positive markets, plus FX, plus organic growth working in our favor.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Great, that's helpful. And just Marty, I guess, a little bigger picture on Department of Labor. It sounds like you've got a very good sort of offensive game plan with the Jemstep product and the open architecture model and being able to maybe use your very wide product range, including the factor-based ETFs. But if you think about the sort of the defensive nature that a lot of the asset managers will be going through that have high concentrations of active product, is there any type of plan to work with the advisers in terms of pricing class structures of the shares that you have now? And I guess, if you could sort of comment on how you think adviser behavior will turn out post the overall rule? And then I'm sorry if I missed the assets in mutual funds in IRAs and 401(k), I'm just not sure if you can just...

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it's a good question. And I think the reality is, we've got to -- the lead is going to be taken by the distributors and how they're going to want to be addressing the rule. And that said, like we are and I'm sure everybody else is, want me to be i
componenttext: Yes. So it's a good question. And I think the reality is, we've got to -- the lead is going to be taken by the distributors and how they're going to want to be addressing the rule. And that said, like we are and I'm sure everybody else is, want me to be incredibly helpful to distributors as they work through the issues. That said, what I believe strongly in is that there is a very, very important role for advisers. We believe that's the best way to get outcomes for clients and also believe strongly that high conviction fundamental capabilities and factor-based capabilities are what advisers want to do because they know that's how they can get a better value proposition for their clients. And just mechanically, the industry is pretty close already through the range of share classes that will be available if -- because the vast majorities are going to be in adviser-based plans. And these are stripped-down, shared classes are really what's going to be used. And so I'd say the money managers are -- I'm sure most everybody is well placed in that area, so -- but again, it's a little bit of a -- it's a time wait to take the lead working with the distributors on it. It is really complex, actually, the rules. But the high-level assumptions that we've all made are probably still in place.

componenttext: So let me answer it this way. So we have -- again, we've talked about the range of capabilities. We think that is very important. Jemstep is open architecture which is very important. That's the only way we can be credible in helping our distribution partners. And if it's important to them, it's important to us. That said, the other element is we have Invesco consulting which has been a really, really important part of the value proposition we provide to advisers to help them work through all these different topics. And that and the thought leadership in combination are going to be, we think, very, very strong forces. And us being in a position to be strongly in place to help our distribution partners to do what they need to do.

componenttext: So good news is the state of Rhode Island mandate is not in this number. This does not include that and so the record number, I mean we're up 50% versus prior year, we're up about 5% versus prior quarter.
