headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Invesco's Second Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions]Now I would like to turn the call over to your speakers for today, Marty Flanagan, President and CEO of Inv
componenttext:
Welcome to Invesco's Second Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions]
Now I would like to turn the call over to your speakers for today, Marty Flanagan, President and CEO of Invesco; and Loren Starr, Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Flanagan, you may begin.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, and thank you for joining us. And as was just Loren Starr, Invesco's CFO is on call with me, and we'll be speaking to the presentation that's available on our website if you're some client to follow along. And as we typically do, I'll
componenttext:
Thank you very much, and thank you for joining us. And as was just Loren Starr, Invesco's CFO is on call with me, and we'll be speaking to the presentation that's available on our website if you're some client to follow along. And as we typically do, I'll give an overview of the business results for the second quarter. Loren will go into greater detail on the financials and then, importantly, we'll open up to Q&A.
So let me begin by highlighting the firm's operating results for the quarter, which you'll find on Slide 4 of the deck. Long-term investment performance remain stronger in the quarter. 68% to 73% of actively managed assets were ahead of peers on a 3- and 5-year -- 3 and 5 years, respectively. Strong investment performance from our continued progress in meeting client needs overcame the impact of volatile markets during the quarter. Strong client demand help drive passive and institutional close, which led to long-term inflows of $4.5 billion during the quarter.
The adjusted operating margin was 38.6%, an improvement over the prior quarter. And during the quarter, we've returned $318 million to shareholders through dividends and stock buybacks.
Assets under management were $779 billion [ph] at the end of the second quarter, up from $771 billion [ph] in the first quarter. Adjusted operating income was $330 million in the quarter, up considerably from $307 million in the prior quarter.
Adjusted diluted earnings per share was $0.56 versus $0.49 in the prior quarter. Also noted the during the quarter, we've raised our quarterly dividend to $0.28 per share, and we also repurchased $200 million of stock during the quarter.
Before I go through the details on the company's financials, let me take a few minutes to talk about the investment performance during the quarter.
Turning to Slide 7 now. Our commitment to investment excellence and our work to build and maintain so investment quarter helped us deliver solid long-term investment performance across the enterprise during the quarter.
Looking at the firm as whole, 68% of assets were in the top half on a 3-year basis and 73% on a top half on a 5-year basis.
On Page 8, you'll see the flows into Passive capabilities were quite strong, while close into active capabilities were flat with $4.5 billion in although long-term inflows. Flows into Passive capabilities were driven by strong demand from Invesco's PowerShares capabilities. This was the second best quarter in Invesco PowerShares history with roughly $3.8 billion in net new assets and the strong flows are helping us to continue to gain ETF market share. This reflects longevity of the breadth of the PowerShares operating as well as our continued focus on meeting client needs. We are well positioned in the current market environment to our low volatility suite, commodity suite, Fixed Income and bank loan ETF's. As you're probably aware, smart beta strategies are going to nearly twice the pace of the overall ETF market. Although this prompted a wave of fund launches by competitors, our expertise at smart beta, in fact, are investing and continue to differentiate us in the market and help us gain share. Although, long-term flows are flat on the active side, we saw solid demand for our alternatives, including real estate, multi-asset capabilities as well as Fixed Income.
Asia Pacific demonstrated continued strength across retail and institutional, with tremendous momentum continuing into the third quarter. A continued focus on delivering strong investment performance and bringing our broad range of capabilities to clients contribute to the very positive results in the region.
Globally, we also saw strong institutional flows during the quarter, which reflects our continued focus on this channel and results in a series of positive institutional flows going back 2 years. 
Client demand trends remain consistent with particularly strong interest in Fixed Income, multi-asset, real estate and our institutional pipeline remains very strong. So at the end of June, the one but not funded pipeline is up 15% on assets under management versus the prior quarter and the prior year.
Retail flows were flat this quarter as investors weigh their options during some of the late quarter volatility. That said, we continue to see strength in Fixed Income, U.S. dividend strategies as well as retail alternative capabilities, specifically GTR and real estate.
Now let me take a moment and highlight the business in EMEA. Our number one position, UK's retail, our strong cross-border retail business and our robust it is a solid pipeline across EMEA, all positions us extremely well ahead of a potential Brexit. We position our business over many years to serve clients who are located in a variety of countries across the region. Our people, in summary, organize to meet those global needs. We are well diversified across channels with the U.K. retailer, cross-border and institutional, each comprising roughly 1/3 of our businesses in the region. We're also diversified across asset class with assets spread across equity bonds and multi-asset capabilities. Lastly, with more than 1,300 people in the region, we are well placed across the region with strong business in both the U.K. and on the continent. Now level diversification and our construct positions us extremely well to deliver for our clients in EMEA.
Investors across Europe, we acted thoughtfully to the market volatility that occurred at the time around vote. Since then, clients have taken advantage of the market movements by utilizing the full range of Invesco's comprehensive fund range to achieve their long-term investment objectives. As an example, we have seen strong movement in the capabilities such as our highly-regarded Global Targeted Returns fund as client seek to manage risk in their portfolios.
With regard to flows, our business in EMEA has demonstrated good resiliency through the Brexit topic. Close to proving more compared to the prior quarter, pre the announcement of the results of the U.K. referendum on June 23. For the month of June, up to the date of the Brexit vote, we saw daily average outflows approximately $78 million. Since the referendum, those outflows have subsided to a daily average of $13 million. Although it's still early days, we feel good about the momentum in our EMEA business. Going forward, we're focused on same clients, managing our core business and executing our strategy while adopting to any changes that might be brought about by Brexit.
Before I hand the call over the Loren, let me say a few words about the new deal of our fiduciary group. We're actively engaged with clients as they work to understand the impact of deal on their business. Now for the past couple of years, our discussions with clients have intensified moving from clarification, interpretations to practical application. We are in discussions with them regarding product applications, share those possibilities, how best to leverage global solutions such as Jemstep.
Based on our early discussions, we continue to believe our comprehensive range of capabilities positions us very well to help our clients as the DOL rule is implemented. Additionally, given Invesco's tremendous expertise and experience partnering with clients to address regularly topics, for example, our work on RDR in the U.K., we view this as an opportunity to further deepen our relationships, provide new capabilities to enhance our business overall.
With that, I will now turn it over to Loren to review the financials in more detail

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty. Okay. So quarter-over-quarter, you saw our total AUM increased by $8.1 billion or 1% Erika this was driven by positive market returns of $10.7 billion. We also saw a long-term net inflows of $4.5 billion. I should note, of this $4.5 billion
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty. Okay. So quarter-over-quarter, you saw our total AUM increased by $8.1 billion or 1% Erika this was driven by positive market returns of $10.7 billion. We also saw a long-term net inflows of $4.5 billion. I should note, of this $4.5 billion, $0.9 billion came from IDR leverage, which is called [indiscernible] our institutional Passive Fixed Income. We also saw the acquisition of our India joint venture gets completed, and that brought in $2.4 billion. We saw inflows from money market of $2 billion. These factors are offset by negative FX translation of $7.7 billion, and we also saw outflows from Q2 Q's [ph] of $3.8 billion.
Our average AUM for the second quarter was $784.5 billion, that was up 4.9% versus Q1. Our net revenue yields came in at 43.7 basis points, which is 0.1 basis point lower than the prior quarter. Although this was a small change, there were a variety of factors, which impacted our yield in Q2. These included AUM mix and lower performance fees, which reduced the yield by 0.7 basis points and 0.4 basis points, respectively. These factors were offset by 1 more day in the period, which increased the yield by 0.4 basis points. In addition, currency mix and the increase in other revenue, each cultivated 0.3 basis points to a net revenue yield in the quarter.
Next, let's turn to the operating results, Page 13. Before I begin, I'd like to point out that we've evaluated and taken on board the SEC's new guidance on non-GAAP financial measures. Accordingly, you have already noticed the changes that we have made in the format of our second quarter earnings press release, which now focuses primarily on the U.S. GAAP results. In addition, the U.S. GAAP period-over-period variances are now set out in detail in our earnings release. Both our earnings release and this investment presentation contains details of reconciliations between our U.S. GAAP and non-GAAP and importantly, there's no change to how we calculated our non-GAAP measures relative to prior quarters. And since we've already provided the U.S. GAAP [indiscernible] our earnings press release, my comments today, consistent with the past practice, will focus exclusively on the variances related to our non-GAAP adjusted measures.
So actually, let's turn to the next page entitled non-GAAP operating results. You'll see net revenues increased by $38.5 million or 4.7% quarter-over-quarter to $856.6 million, which included a positive FX rate impact of $6.4 million. Within the net revenue number, you'll see that adjusted investment management fees increased by $32.6 million or 3.5% to $962.9 million, this reflects higher average AUM for the quarter, foreign exchange increase adjusted investment management fees by $7.7 million. Our adjusted service and distribution revenues increased by $5.7 million or 2.9%, reflecting higher average AUM for retail products.
Foreign exchange increased adjusted service and distribution revenue by $0.5 million. Adjusted performance fees came in at $9.3 million in Q2 and were earned from a variety of different investment capabilities, including $5.5 million from our bank loan products. Foreign exchange increased these fees by $0.1 million.
Our adjusted other revenues in the first quarter were $31.7 million, and that was an increase of $7.7 million from the prior quarter, and that was a result of increased transaction fees from real estate. Foreign exchange increased its revenues by $0.4 million.Third-party distribution, service and advisory expense, which we net against gross revenues, increased $1.3 million or 0.4%. This movement was in line with the higher revenues derived from our retail AUM and FX increase, these expenses by $2.3 million.
Moving further on down the slide, You'll see that adjusted operating expenses at $526.2 million, increased by $15.2 million, or 3% relative to Q1. Foreign exchange increase adjusted operating expenses by $4.1 million during the quarter.
Our adjusted employee compensation came in at $347.9 million, an increase of $7.6 million or 2.2%. This increase was driven by higher sales commissions and variable compensation costs, a full quarter of higher base salaries effective from March 1, and an increase in deferred compensation expenses for the awards granted in the first quarter. This was offset by a decline in the seasonal payroll taxes. FX increased our adjusted compensation by $2.8 million in the quarter.
Adjusted marketing expenses increased by $3.6 million or 14.2% to $29 million, reflecting the seasonal increase in client events. FX increased adjusted marketing expense by $0.3 million in the quarter.
Our adjusted property office and technology expenses were $82.8 million in the quarter, an increase of $1.7 million versus Q1, driven by higher technology costs. FX increased these expenses by $0.5 million.
Adjusted G&A expense at $66.5 million, increased $2.3 million or 3.6%, and this was driven by professional services expenses when compared to the prior quarter and FX increased G&A by $0.5 billion.
Going on for that on the page, you'll see that adjusted nonoperating income increased $15 million compared to Q1, and this difference was largely driven by higher equity and earnings from unconsolidated affiliates in the second quarter but also, the $7.1 million FX loss recognized in the prior quarter.
In terms of effective tax rate on pretax adjusted net income in Q2, was consistent with the prior quarter at 26.5%, which brings us to our adjusted EPS of $0.56, and adjusted net operating margin of 38.6%.
And so finally, before I turn things over to Marty, I just want to provide a quick update on our capital management activities in the quarter. As you'll recall from our recent announcement, in addition to our ongoing share repurchase activity during the quarter, we entered into a $150 million accelerated share repurchase program on June 30. And as a result of this, our end-of-period share Canada declined by approximately 1.7% quarter-over-quarter to $413.1 million shares.
And with that, turn it back to Marty

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Loren. Let me just make a couple of summary comments before we get to Q&A. We believe our ability to produce strong long-term net loss this quarter to flex the fundamental strength of our firm. Our expertise across the broad range of fundamenta
componenttext:
Thank you, Loren. Let me just make a couple of summary comments before we get to Q&A. We believe our ability to produce strong long-term net loss this quarter to flex the fundamental strength of our firm. Our expertise across the broad range of fundamental and factor-based capabilities and our focus on helping retail and institutional clients achieve their investment objectives. We feel good about the momentum in our business, which shows a strong across the quarter as we help clients manage through the volatility we saw in June.
Strong flows have continued into July with more than $8 billion of long-term net inflows across a variety of capabilities and regions. This $8 billion include $6.5 billion of net as related to the 5 29 mandate, which was recently funded. As noted during our Investor Day event earlier this year, we were very well-positioned to help clients to be successful, which in turn will enhance our market relevance, drive growth and strengthen shareholder value over the long term.
And with that, Loren and I would like to take any questions you all have.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Craig Siegenthaler from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Craig Siegenthaler from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll make a comment, and Loren can talk more specifically. Maybe -- as I just mentioned here, we just continue to see really strong flows. And I think importantly, you're seeing -- as I said, long-term flows away from the 5 29 plan, we saw more than
componenttext: Maybe I'll make a comment, and Loren can talk more specifically. Maybe -- as I just mentioned here, we just continue to see really strong flows. And I think importantly, you're seeing -- as I said, long-term flows away from the 5 29 plan, we saw more than $1.5 billion already. The pipeline continues to be very, very strong. And the other element that we're seeing is again, the PowerShares, smart beta capabilities, the breath and longevity of the range, it's really kicking in. And so, as we are right now, it looks like it's going to continue quite strongly through the border.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, generally, the growth in our Fixed Income is being driven by our U.S. investment grade capability, which is pretty much, I think, also in our institutional pipeline, showing up as a large contributor. I just want to remind people that in the fl
componenttext: Obviously, generally, the growth in our Fixed Income is being driven by our U.S. investment grade capability, which is pretty much, I think, also in our institutional pipeline, showing up as a large contributor. I just want to remind people that in the flows, this quarter, there was about $0.9 billion related to IVR leverage which shows up in the Fixed Income column. But we also are seeing a lot of interest even in PowerShares, Fixed Income, emerging markets, sovereign debt, Chinese Fixed Income, so a variety of other Fixed Income capabilities factored into that. We just roughly $0.5 billion in [indiscernible] significant in their own way.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on Brexit. I think the client reaction is significantly more muted than anyone was thinking about 30 days ago. But how are clients reacting in both the U.K. and Continental Europe today's following the vote? And have you seen a lot of that initia
componenttext: And then on Brexit. I think the client reaction is significantly more muted than anyone was thinking about 30 days ago. But how are clients reacting in both the U.K. and Continental Europe today's following the vote? And have you seen a lot of that initial reactive activity going down?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And like us, like by others, we are very engaged with clients. I mean, what was really interesting was we saw in our numbers, our June, that was probably the peak of uncertainty. And you saw it in the flows as being the most negative year-to-date. In
componenttext: Yes. And like us, like by others, we are very engaged with clients. I mean, what was really interesting was we saw in our numbers, our June, that was probably the peak of uncertainty. And you saw it in the flows as being the most negative year-to-date. Interesting, a number of institutional clients were waiting until after the vote, and what it really did was start to remind the clarity and the institutional mandate started to fund. [indiscernible] past that. And we are also seeing retail investors making decisions on where to put their assets. And again, we point out, GTR has been a real beneficiary of that. So people are looking to just relook at their asset allocation capabilities. The good news is the breath of our capabilities put us in a position that where we can be helpful to them in any, which way. So it is early days but everything we see, I -- we think it's all going to be an opportunity for a firm like us. We are positioned very strongly, structurally, for a Brexit. So that means we're not distracted by trying to having a revamp product lines or anything along that way and we can just be really, really focus on. Clients, and again, it was a total overreaction in light of, if you look at the Invesco share price. And again, I think the results are making that point quite clear.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing that's kind of worth mentioning, I mean, our team have been really good in terms being elevated and creating new products in advance of client demand until we would expect to see other, I think, very interesting products hit the U.K. marke
componenttext: The other thing that's kind of worth mentioning, I mean, our team have been really good in terms being elevated and creating new products in advance of client demand until we would expect to see other, I think, very interesting products hit the U.K. market this year towards the beginning of next year. I think there's an income oriented, sort of GTR type of product that we looked at as well as some enhance index capabilities and factor capabilities too? So I think all of those are going to really help us even if we see continued sort of levels of uncertainty around Brexit.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Kenneth Worthington from JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question is from Kenneth Worthington from JPMorgan.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, in terms of, maybe a couple of questions of excess cash. What was the balance at the end of the quarter? And I recall that consolidation was a conceptual focus when that pool was being built. But I think product development and capital return have
componenttext: First, in terms of, maybe a couple of questions of excess cash. What was the balance at the end of the quarter? And I recall that consolidation was a conceptual focus when that pool was being built. But I think product development and capital return have been higher priorities more recently. So how do you see that excess cash level evolving, in its $1 billion to a number you want to migrate towards over time?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, total cash at the end of the quarter was $1.45 billion. And so, the regulatory requirement element of that was about $660 million, leaving us roughly $800 million-ish of sort of capital. I mean, we're certainly within sort of tolerance around that bi
componenttext:
Ken, total cash at the end of the quarter was $1.45 billion. And so, the regulatory requirement element of that was about $660 million, leaving us roughly $800 million-ish of sort of capital. I mean, we're certainly within sort of tolerance around that billion. And so again, I won't get fixated on that billion being sort of like this bright line that we have to sort of hit. And clearly, we've been very opportunistic and we'll continue to be very opportunistic with respect to returning capital to the extent that we see our stock being valued in a way that we think is not [indiscernible] with our true value.
So I would say, look to our past sort of practices to evaluate how we're going to operate going forward. It will be very consistent.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And 2 little questions. Maybe 1 other Rhode Island plan. How's the transitioning going? And how much money actually came over when it was first announced, and it was about $7 billion? Was that about what eventually moved over?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And 2 little questions. Maybe 1 other Rhode Island plan. How's the transitioning going? And how much money actually came over when it was first announced, and it was about $7 billion? Was that about what eventually moved over?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what came over $6.5 billion, and so that was a combination of market impact and with the transition, it is now completed the transitions in plays, and everybody's very, very focused on expanding the capabilities through the retail channel. We think it'
componenttext: So what came over $6.5 billion, and so that was a combination of market impact and with the transition, it is now completed the transitions in plays, and everybody's very, very focused on expanding the capabilities through the retail channel. We think it's going to -- it's a great plan and we think that we can help make it even more successful. So we're executing as we speak.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Excellent. Then just lastly, active equity net outflows were pretty large this quarter. Obviously, it was a big risk off quarter, there was Brexit and other things. Maybe any observations you have on sort of the nature, either the lack of money comi
componenttext: Okay. Excellent. Then just lastly, active equity net outflows were pretty large this quarter. Obviously, it was a big risk off quarter, there was Brexit and other things. Maybe any observations you have on sort of the nature, either the lack of money coming in or the more money coming out that kind of drove that big net outflows number this quarter.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, the one thing I would just mention is about 2.8 related to International Growth, that was sort of the thing that I think we have people understand that there were 1 client who turned out there was a parting of ways. But that International Growth capa
componenttext: Ken, the one thing I would just mention is about 2.8 related to International Growth, that was sort of the thing that I think we have people understand that there were 1 client who turned out there was a parting of ways. But that International Growth capability is performing extremely well. It's been a close capability and it's one that I think is going to get filled up pretty quickly to the course of this year. So if you guys, a little bit one-off-ish with respect to kind of the equity, active equity  outflow. The other elements are sort of somewhat consistent with the past, what you've seen in the past. I don't think there's anything that sort of accelerating outflow relative to that category other than that 1 element.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Alex Blostein of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Next question is from Alex Blostein of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of quick questions. I guess, first, around the margins. Obviously, you saw the adjusted margin improved sequentially, given better revenue environment, but still down pretty meaningfully over year. So if we see more range-bound market which, obviou
componenttext: Couple of quick questions. I guess, first, around the margins. Obviously, you saw the adjusted margin improved sequentially, given better revenue environment, but still down pretty meaningfully over year. So if we see more range-bound market which, obviously, feel like a big if right now. But under that scenario, how should we think about the trajectory of the margin for the rest of the year? And then is there's anything else you guys are targeting on the expense front to help drive margins higher in today's environment.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, I'll take that. So I think our expectation, even with markets being flat, which is the way we normally forecast anyway, and even with the pound being down where it is for the last half of the year, we would expect margins to be on an upward trajecto
componenttext: Alex, I'll take that. So I think our expectation, even with markets being flat, which is the way we normally forecast anyway, and even with the pound being down where it is for the last half of the year, we would expect margins to be on an upward trajectory as we continue to grow organically and continue to work hard on the optimization work around cost. So the firm has done, I think, a really great job of creating capacity for investment without having to add to costs, really true, using, as we talked about in the past. Greater use of our shared service centers, being able to leverage technology more effectively, streamlining, simplifying a lot about processes. So that work is now going on as you know and so we're on track with respect to the optimization, which we discussed provide some expensive release of roughly $30 million to $45 million by the end of the year. And so that run rate, which is actually a beginning to flow through our numbers is something that's been very helpful. And just remind people, we handled acquisition that came on board, Jemstep and Melgar, and those expenses are being offset through this optimization whereas the revenues are showing up in the revenue line items. So we do think that that's going to help further drive margin expansion. Our mental margin continues to be at a very high level. And with that sort of 50% to -- 55% to 60% incrementally margin and our fee rate, because of the mix that's coming and particularly, around institutional social being the higher fee rate than what's going out, will continue to benefit from that. So I think all those factors to us say that we can continue to see margins increase and get up to the levels that we've seen in the past without too much stretching. Clearly, it's a factor of the market, of course, and what [indiscernible].

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I might add a quick, too. I would say, from my perspective, where we're really going to see the margin expansion is really on the organic growth. We continue to be very disciplined on expenses as we always have, and as Loren just described. That's,
componenttext: Sure. I might add a quick, too. I would say, from my perspective, where we're really going to see the margin expansion is really on the organic growth. We continue to be very disciplined on expenses as we always have, and as Loren just described. That's, I'd tell you, for 11 years I've been here, I don't know that I know a time when I've seen so many of our initiatives sitting in front of us to have such an impact. You're starting to see an institutional factor base smart beta solutions. And so our debate internally is, what is the wise move of investing in these to get the returns versus being very cautious. And again, it's something we do all the time. But it's really that market relevance expansion in the business that's sitting right in front of us. And it's a very exciting time, quite frankly, for us.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: I mean, just generally, because I know people are curious. I mean in terms of guidance around expenses, generally, we would see expenses being sort of roughly flat from the current levels through the course of the year based on sort of flat markets in FX. So that provides a nice backdrop as we continue to grow the revenue line item.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's very helpful. Second question on the DOL. I understand it's still pretty early, but it seems like there's a lot of moving pieces already happening on the distribution side of things and different kind of messages from various distribution p
componenttext: Got it. That's very helpful. Second question on the DOL. I understand it's still pretty early, but it seems like there's a lot of moving pieces already happening on the distribution side of things and different kind of messages from various distribution partners. What do you guys hear from some of the larger distributors out there whether it's warehouses or some of the more regional platforms. And specifically, as it relates to essentially payment for shelf space and how those conversations are evolving?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say from my perspective, which is probably naïve, I thought there was going to likely be a uniform response but in reality, what's happened is each of those distributors are different, their businesses are positioned differently. And so there are
componenttext: I would say from my perspective, which is probably naïve, I thought there was going to likely be a uniform response but in reality, what's happened is each of those distributors are different, their businesses are positioned differently. And so there are variations on the theme, and that makes sense, quite frankly. Also, it's -- there are ways to continue to be supportive of the brokerage business but knowing that the movement is towards their advisory businesses. And so they're putting in DOL in place along those lines. And again, that place well to an organization such as ours where we have such a range of high conviction fundamental capabilities on the factor base investing. And so it will be too early for us to be very specific on what the outcomes are. But as I said, it looks like you could see some changes to share classes. You could see some different changes in the use of focus on asset classes and the like. So that's what we know right now. But again, I would be getting ahead of our clients if I.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing that we also [indiscernible] maybe as a payment and use of fewer providers. And so it's the ones who were probably have the broadest set of capabilities, good performance who will probably fare better if 2 [indiscernible] assets in motion
componenttext: The other thing that we also [indiscernible] maybe as a payment and use of fewer providers. And so it's the ones who were probably have the broadest set of capabilities, good performance who will probably fare better if 2 [indiscernible] assets in motion as a result of DOL. I think we're probably as well positioned as one can be in that environment.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Bren Hawken of TBS.
componenttext: Next question is from Bren Hawken of TBS.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question on the fee rate here. And we saw the management fee rate decline quarter-over-quarter. I know that you guys often speak to the revenue yield, but just hoping if it's possible to ask a question, cutting out some of the other noise and just s
componenttext: Quick question on the fee rate here. And we saw the management fee rate decline quarter-over-quarter. I know that you guys often speak to the revenue yield, but just hoping if it's possible to ask a question, cutting out some of the other noise and just speaking specifically to be investment management fees divided by AUM. What drove that? Was it mix? And if so, should we think about that as being sustainable? And I think last quarter, you are given some indication, saying that you expect the fee rates to improve throughout the year, and is that still your expectation?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So, obviously, the management fee rate does have -- is impacted by FX and [indiscernible] some factors there as well as overall equity component versus non-equity. And so in the market declines going to see some of that change. There is another eleva
componenttext: Yes. So, obviously, the management fee rate does have -- is impacted by FX and [indiscernible] some factors there as well as overall equity component versus non-equity. And so in the market declines going to see some of that change. There is another elevator on our growth management fee rate, which people should be aware of, it's the RDR impact. As we could have continued to bleed out the old fee rate and replace it with a net fee rate, that has an impact on the gross management deals. And so that is sort of permanent and sustained as we go forward. But doesn't have an impact on the net revenue yield because commensurately, our -- what we're paying away goes away, too. So that's why it is -- you almost have to look at that net number to really understand the dynamic of that shifting mix. But in terms of the trends around what's driving our management fee, so feel that it's quite stable. Maybe, I mean, to the extent that Europe is a little bit slower than it's been in the past, it's 1 engine that was driving that fee rate, which is probably not something you will necessarily look to be driving forward, but we are seeing continued engines around Asia alternatives which is helping us continue to see that fee rate increase as well as institutional mix generally being better. So I'd say the net revenue yield x-performance fees quarter, next quarter going forward, is kind of flattish for this quarter. And so that would be -- if I'm even with FX, so I think with FX down, obviously, like the negative impact but because of mix, it's positive, it's probably offsetting it. So fully that's helpful in terms of the modeling on the fee rate. A lot of dynamics underneath clearly, have had some impact but generally, we expect to see that trend in terms of improving fee rate to continue to maybe get a somewhat slower [indiscernible]

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. That's helpful. And then I know that it's probably pretty hard to be, maybe hard might even be understating it, to be anything close to precise. But given how important the U.K. is to you all. Is there a way that you could help us understand
componenttext: Okay. Got it. That's helpful. And then I know that it's probably pretty hard to be, maybe hard might even be understating it, to be anything close to precise. But given how important the U.K. is to you all. Is there a way that you could help us understand how you're thinking about the different things that might happen to your expense base and to your business based upon the handful of likely outcomes that have been thrown out there from a post-article-50 world?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So again, take this reality is no one knows exactly so let's do the more likely than not. The more likely than not is Brexit is going to happen, and that you're going to end up with trade agreements between the continent and the U.K. that are mutual
componenttext: Sure. So again, take this reality is no one knows exactly so let's do the more likely than not. The more likely than not is Brexit is going to happen, and that you're going to end up with trade agreements between the continent and the U.K. that are mutually beneficial. It's going to take time to get there. That said, let's get down to our business. Our business, as I was trying to highlight, we are already structured for a post-Brexit environment. Very strong U.K. business, very strong continental business, and we don't see any changes there for all the major reasons. And the impact on the business is going to be largely driven by the economic environment. And there is a scenario where it's less negative than everything that you have heard. I mean, with the pound depreciating, that's actually the x-quarters in the U.K. are actually doing very, very well. So I think the reality is going to be very hard at a political level but I would say, our business is a business that is structured for the change and there is a need for asset management services and we just really don't see this industry being hurt to a degree that some other businesses might be [indiscernible] going to have to move people to different parts of -- out of the U.K., out of the continent and vice versa. It is just not part of what's going to happen to us as asset managers. Now there are some asset management firms that are not structured like we are and make, they're going to have to do some work to get positioned to be successful. But again, we're trying very hard to point out, looking at the elements we talked about earlier. It's a huge part of the world. It's a strong part of the world [indiscernible] go into some changes. But I think it's a total mistake to think that the region will not continue to be important and that -- it will not continue to be an important part of our business.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just 1 more follow-up, Loren, if I could. The -- in the prepared remarks, you mentioned a bunch of things that are, I wouldn't call turning the corner, but are just things that are just doing well in general outside of maybe active equity or pa
componenttext: Great. And just 1 more follow-up, Loren, if I could. The -- in the prepared remarks, you mentioned a bunch of things that are, I wouldn't call turning the corner, but are just things that are just doing well in general outside of maybe active equity or parts of active equity. So is the 3% or 5% organic growth rate still cool? Can it happen without U.S. equities? It looks like you can, given everything else that's worth, I just want to get that straight.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we think it's -- I mean, that 3% to 5%, obviously, is what we think we can do over time. It's been sort of more of a benchmark. I think for this year, we would like to see of us at least, enter that range. But given, obviously, what's going on in
componenttext: I mean, we think it's -- I mean, that 3% to 5%, obviously, is what we think we can do over time. It's been sort of more of a benchmark. I think for this year, we would like to see of us at least, enter that range. But given, obviously, what's going on in Europe, it's been a little bit of an unusual situation. So I don't want to promise for us because it's only -- it's probably even harder than performance in performance fees. But we -- everything that we see in terms of the institutional pipeline growing, the fact that we have certain parts of our business, [indiscernible] Asia, is absolutely strong both on the retail and institutional side, reaching PowerShares, hitting new records or close to records on flows. I think it's certainly reasonable for us to think that we consider get close to that 3% at the minimum.

componenttext: This actually Andrew Nicholls, filling in for Chris. My first question is on GTR. Obviously, you've had exceptional performance there across all time periods, particularly on year-to-date basis and with respect to some of the strategies largest peers. I'm just curious if you could provide some color on how the pipeline is looking and that asset class as a whole?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the GDR pipeline is certainly featuring a lot of the growth in our pipeline generally. That's the one that is probably up more than 20% quarter-over-quarter. So it's just one that continues to be seen. I think also, with respect to some of the com
componenttext: I think the GDR pipeline is certainly featuring a lot of the growth in our pipeline generally. That's the one that is probably up more than 20% quarter-over-quarter. So it's just one that continues to be seen. I think also, with respect to some of the competing products, it's sort of even further relative to other products. So we have the ability to grow far beyond this current level, we would expect. And certainly, and we looked at, I think, again, view the U.S. by consolidating taking on as well. So that important component of getting that completed for us to really fulfill, ultimately, I think, what could be a full potential as well as on the retail side in the U.S. where I think it's about $0.5 billion or [indiscernible] less than $300 million or something like that. But it hasn't really been launched, probably it hasn't hit its 2-year track record yet. And so [indiscernible] that I think it's going to have an opportunity to do a whole lot more than in the U.S.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful color. And then on the DOL rule. I think the general expectations are that the rule would drive first to products that either have lower fees, very strong relative performance  and/or a combination of both. I'm just wondering if you
componenttext: Great. That's helpful color. And then on the DOL rule. I think the general expectations are that the rule would drive first to products that either have lower fees, very strong relative performance  and/or a combination of both. I'm just wondering if you have any thoughts on which of those 2 factors will play a bigger role in driving flows in a post DOL world? And now you think your product suite is positioned to compete on each front?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our view is this, is that -- it's quite less simple than your perspective. What are financial advisors trying to do? they're trying to generate excess returns, risk-adjusted returns, over time and you cannot get there with cap-weighted indexes. And so
componenttext: So our view is this, is that -- it's quite less simple than your perspective. What are financial advisors trying to do? they're trying to generate excess returns, risk-adjusted returns, over time and you cannot get there with cap-weighted indexes. And so it really is a combination of [indiscernible] fundamental and good performing active, as you're describing, in combination with Passive and where we think the combination is, is in smart beta. And when you combine those together, you get an overall growth. The total cost is less. And so, that's why this element of being strong in solutions really, really matters for an organization. So we just locked at the position of the firm and having the whole range of capabilities and the ability to help with solutions, and that's at a retail level, we think we are positioned very well. I think the firms that are disadvantaged are those that are very, very narrow in scope and clearly, if you're a high cost [indiscernible] moderately performing organization, you're in trouble.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question is from Chris Harris of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Next question is from Chris Harris of Wells Fargo.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a few quick questions on your U.K. pound hedge, obviously, this position is significantly in the money. Regarding the accounting of that, is that a mark-to-market methodology or are we going to see gains as you start exercising that position. And then
componenttext: So a few quick questions on your U.K. pound hedge, obviously, this position is significantly in the money. Regarding the accounting of that, is that a mark-to-market methodology or are we going to see gains as you start exercising that position. And then part 2, the question is, given where the pound is today, how big of a step down in income can we expect when you have the roll that hedge?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I mean, in terms of the U.S. GAAP, it's mark-to-market. And that's -- you're going to see that flowing through the P&L and you're seeing it U.S. GAAP P&L, currently. In terms of our non-GAAP disclosure. What we've done is we backed out that mark-to-mar
componenttext: So I mean, in terms of the U.S. GAAP, it's mark-to-market. And that's -- you're going to see that flowing through the P&L and you're seeing it U.S. GAAP P&L, currently. In terms of our non-GAAP disclosure. What we've done is we backed out that mark-to-market and we are only bringing in what has been actually realized. And so this quarter, that was a very small amount of money in terms of the  volume of the impact for next couple of quarters just based on current rate, that's probably close to $0.01 in EPS for each of the quarters going forward. So in terms of what we would do if we were going to roll it because we have it out through to Q1, I think we're going to be patient and think about what do we need to or want to but obviously, you have to look at the cost for us to sort of lock in right now at current rates or discount to current rates because we've been using [indiscernible] I'm not sure if anybody is too excited about an edge, 1.25 or something like that. So it is something that we're going to continue to look at and evaluate to whether we continue to roll this thing. But certainly, we're going to hold on to what we've got right now and continue to benefit, at least from a cash flow and EPS perspective from the protections provided.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: I appreciate the -- all the color from Brexit and the kind of commentary around flow thus far. I guess, is there any kind of negative fallout that you're seeing institutionally or certain regions whether you actually are seeing maybe some changes more to the negative that might be longer-term? Or is it generally been kind of consistent across the board?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, it really has been consistent. As I said, we're going to make sure this is in response to [indiscernible] Brexit. I mean -- no, I mean, it really did unleash, in particular, in the U.K. and on the continent, people decided to move forward with the
componenttext: I mean, it really has been consistent. As I said, we're going to make sure this is in response to [indiscernible] Brexit. I mean -- no, I mean, it really did unleash, in particular, in the U.K. and on the continent, people decided to move forward with the -- their intention to fund different institutional capabilities. And then if you -- as Lawrence said, if you go to Asia-Pac right now, which is very, very strong for us. And so there's really -- there's not that many impact that you could tie to that event or other uncertainty in the world. In fact, for us, much differently than that, it just the pipeline, as we keep saying, it just keeps getting stronger and stronger. And so we've not seen that yet.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: The only thing I would say is probably you around the DOL, there's probably more question mark just generally. And I think it was sort of the comment that was made, there are people, certain clients, is going to gravitate to using exclusively low fee products as opposed to active products. And so whether it shows companies or others may choose to do something like that in the future on clear, but if it happens, it happened, obviously, to industrywide type of impact. As we said, I think we're well-positioned operating that world because we do have low fee type of product..

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes. And so Active is here to stay. And if you're a good investor, you're going to do well.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And I guess, I'm wondering if there has been any benefit from the Rhode Island win that you can talk about. There's no question, its raise the profile and it is helping very, very much. And as I said, we're actually -- it's at 2 different levels, we have the solution element, it's starting to kick in. Frankly, you would imagine but at the retail level and also in Asia-Pac, there's actually EMEA and China, in particular, just really growing opportunity. So again, we'd say it's early days for us in that area. But again, we feel we have a very, very strong capability and awful lot of activity around it.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: I guess my first question is, just may be any update you may have or thoughts you have around the, obviously, the SEC has proposed different liquidity rules on [ph] 40 act products and some of that impact ETFs. And I know you've talk about this in the past, Marty, but current thoughts as maybe you've been part of any interaction with the SEC on kind of what's likely. And given the explosive growth in smart beta, ETF products and other products, do you think there's any risk that kind of inhibit some of the strategies that you're running out there?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So how is smart beta inhibiting some of the strategies can you help me?
componenttext: So how is smart beta inhibiting some of the strategies can you help me?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well I meant to say, if you have different liquidity or derivative requirements and different strategies that's proposed, is that going to inhibit how you run things?
componenttext: Well I meant to say, if you have different liquidity or derivative requirements and different strategies that's proposed, is that going to inhibit how you run things?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So we've said in the past, I mean, we are -- and I think we all just saw, anticipate something coming out the liquidity rule. The involvement that the industry has had is that we think there's just going to be a common cyclical outcome, which woul
componenttext: Got it. So we've said in the past, I mean, we are -- and I think we all just saw, anticipate something coming out the liquidity rule. The involvement that the industry has had is that we think there's just going to be a common cyclical outcome, which would be a good thing. And if that is the case, it's going to be quite frankly, an awful a lot of work. But if something is very manageable for the industry. The derivatives will again, it's -- is, I would say, the first notion of it was it would've gotten the way of a number of products for the industry in particular, for us. At a retail level, GTR, probably would have been very, very challenge in the proposed rules. We're sensing that we're going to end up with a better outcome, which will not get in the way of a number of our products. I don't want to be so definitive yet because it's not there. But I'd say very good progress in being very thoughtful on really trying to help the SEC get to what they need. And so the dialogue has been constructive. And so again, you will see ultimate comes out, but at the moment, I'd say it's trending to commonsensical, good outcomes on both levels.

componenttext: Good question. So we look at smart beta as a subset of factor investing. And again, I think very importantly, I'm repeating myself but one of very, very few firms that have factor base capability that benefits its 35 years and the fundamental investing that we have. And so the combination of those around the world for us that put us in a unique position. So factor investing outside of the United States is much more an institutional business. And it's growing in demand, [indiscernible] continent. Loren mentioned that if we're looking to do some things in the U.K. at the retail level, there in AsiaPac, it's actually growing the demand. In the United States, it tends to be a retail focus and express the smart beta through ETFs. And where we look at our strategic positioning, i think very importantly, differently than a mutual fund where you can have 200 of the same XYZ funds completing is very hard to see beyond, really 3 ETF are sort of the same color to be successful just because of the nature of the ETF with market makers and the like. So first mover advantage matters a lot. The other thing that really matters to is the longevity of I think length of track record. And if you look at the PowerShares lineup of smart beta, any number of funds are 10 years old. And we are so -- when people are looking to invest or looking at the length of capability, also looking at the liquidity within it. And so those are very different dynamics that we could have on the mutual fund. So the good news is people are coming in sort of, it confirms the attractiveness of smart beta. That said, it's going to -- it's a very, very competitive space to enter into, to say nothing of how do you work in conjunction with active management within your organization. So we think we're in a pretty [indiscernible]

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I've not been in the industry for quite a long time and it's been consolidated for every 5 years, it seems, it really hasn't for various reasons as we all know. I would be in a camp consistent with others that it does seem very different this time. And
componenttext: So I've not been in the industry for quite a long time and it's been consolidated for every 5 years, it seems, it really hasn't for various reasons as we all know. I would be in a camp consistent with others that it does seem very different this time. And I -- one of if you look at it as a maturing industry, but when you talk about active management, my view is you go in cycles and we've had this beta run from '09 on with intervention, which align the stars with cap weighted indexes, that's not sustainable. So I think that's been over done. That said, it's here to stay. I think you're going to see greater growth of factor investing, as we said. But active management, you'll actually able to thrive, I think those individuals calling [indiscernible] debt asset class making a mistake. So that said, I think the other element that's really driving the ocean of consolidation, it's the regulatory landscape. It is so costly to keep up with all of these to say nothing in cyberspace. So it's rising cost competitive environment. And I think those are the dynamics that are going to also be changing to drive consolidation. And luckily, we're fortunate enough to be positioned extremely well, as just we've been talk about on this call. I would say, the business here has never been stronger, seemingly getting all engines are kicking in quite nicely and matched against the trends that are in place. And I think the people that try to catch up with the trends, it's going to be very hard [indiscernible] neither have started and 3 years ago, 5 years ago, 7 years ago, honestly. That said, we don't see a lot of gaps but we will continue to pay attention to the marketplace. And as we have in the past, selectively as things if you can become a very -- stronger organization by teaming up with another organization, we'll continue to that. That said, that's not our focus right now.

componenttextpreview: So we're one of the first firms to have accepted really for active ETFs and we launched them, I'm are going to say, in 2007, 2 of them. And I think what's basically our C capital. So there's a lot of conversation about active ETFs. They just really have n
componenttext: So we're one of the first firms to have accepted really for active ETFs and we launched them, I'm are going to say, in 2007, 2 of them. And I think what's basically our C capital. So there's a lot of conversation about active ETFs. They just really have not taken off. So we have the capability to do it, we keep analyzing, we're just not seeing that a big a lot of demand for it. Now if you read the papers, you would think that's all anybody cares about. So that's been our experience of maybe we just, but that's our experience. With regard to different wrappers, if you look at next shares, it's interesting but it could be 100% achieved by a share class in the mutual fund. And if you use our 6 share class, you get the exact outcome, via with the challenge of a different vehicle trying to get launched within a channel. And although it's creative I think that's really been the headwind for it. So it could ultimately be successful. But again, I think there's an easier way to get there. And we really need to do with your clients i.e. think distribution partners. So things will continue to evolve. I personally think that the area that will continue to grow the most for probably the most additive is a smart beta because it is, you get better outcomes with smart beta than you do with cap weighted indexes. So that's really going to be where the gravitational pull is when you look at these ranges of capabilities that you just highlighted. So that's our view, we could be wrong, but that's what you're thinking right now.

componenttext: Yes. Look, the reality is we're still in an uncertain market, if you just play back the year. If you look within our flows, we have tremendous flows in U.S. dividend stocks, which is consistent with this sort of, I want yield, I want some growth, but I'm somewhat concerned about the environment. If you look at the value capabilities, I feel really, really good about the teams and how they're managing. What tends to be in those our energy and financials, which have been hurt here again in the volatility. So my basic view is that we continue to ensure that we have quality teams that can deliver over a market cycle and I think that's really the important thing you can't look quarter-to-quarter, year by year, calendar market cycles matter and you're going to get excess returns rated strong asset management. And I think when the psychological environment moves, I think that's where going to really see the growth, the net flows actually pick up in those active capabilities. So again, I think you have the segment them to different styles I think that's really what's driving it right now.
