headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Invesco's Third Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] .Now I'd to turn the call over to your speakers for today, Marty Flanagan, President and CEO of Invesco; an
componenttext:
Welcome to Invesco's Third Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] .
Now I'd to turn the call over to your speakers for today, Marty Flanagan, President and CEO of Invesco; and Loren Starr, Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Flanagan, you may begin.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, and thank you for joining us on our third quarter call. As is our practice, I will review the business results for the third quarter and then Loren will go into greater details about the financials and then we'll open up to Q&A after
componenttext:
Thank you very much, and thank you for joining us on our third quarter call. As is our practice, I will review the business results for the third quarter and then Loren will go into greater details about the financials and then we'll open up to Q&A after that. 
So let me begin by highlighting the firm's operating results for the quarter, and you'll find this on Slide 4, if you happen to be following the presentation, which is available on our website. 
Long-term investment performance remained -- continue to be very strong. 68% to 79% of actively managed assets were ahead of peers on a 3 and 5-year basis, respectively. 
Our continued focus on leveraging overbroad investment capabilities provide meaningful solutions to clients contributed solid operating results during the quarter and what I think all of us would describe as a difficult business environment for money managers. 
Growing investment funds helped drive robust long-term net flows of $1.2 billion during the quarter, reflecting solid retail and institutional demand across both active and passive capabilities, and total flows during the quarter were just over $19 billion. 
The adjusted operating margin was 39.7%, an improvement over the prior quarter that reflects our continued focus on running a disciplined business. 
We also returned $176 million to shareholders through dividends and stock buybacks during the quarter. 
Assets under management were $820 billion at the end of the quarter, up from $779 billion in the second quarter. Adjusted operating income was $339 billion in the quarter, up from $330 million in the prior quarter. 
Adjusted diluted EPS was $0.60 this quarter versus $0.56 in the prior quarter. 
And as noted earlier in the year, we raised our quarterly dividend to $0.28 per share nearly 4% prior year. We also continued out stock program during the quarter. 
And before Loren goes into detail on the financials, let me take a moment to review the investment performance inflows for the quarter. 
Turning to Slide 7 now. Our commitment to investment excellence and our work to build and maintain strong -- a strong investment culture helped us to deliver strong solid long-term investment performance across the enterprise during the quarter. 
Looking at the firm as a whole, 68% of assets were in the top half on a 3-year basis, 79% were in the top half on a 5-year basis. 
On Page 8, you'll see the quarterly long-term flows of $12.2 billion were quite strong across both active and passive capabilities. Flows from the passive capabilities were driven by strong demand from Invesco PowerShares capability, which has an all weather lineup that was well-positioned to meet client demand in any type of market. This was the second best quarter for in Invesco PowerShares in its history, with roughly $4 billion in net flows, and strong flows are helping us continue to gain ETF market share. 
As we noted during our recent Investor Day, strong passing flows reflected our longevity in the ETF market. Our deep experience are comprehensive range of factor in smart beta capabilities and our significant track record of innovation. 
Results on the active side were equally as impressive, with solid demand and multi-asset, dividend income capabilities, Fixed Income and other capabilities such as real estate. 
Our focus on delivering strong investment performance and bringing our broad range of capabilities to clients contribute positive results in Asia Pacific, with strengths across both retail and institutional channels. 
Globally, we saw institutional flows during the quarter, which continues a series of positive institutional flows going back more than 2 years now. 
Client demand trends remain consistent with particular interest in Fixed Income, multi-asset, real estate and are won but not funded and qualified opportunities are in all-time high. 
Retail flows also were strong as gross sales rebounded nicely and redemptions moderated during the quarter. This includes a $6.5 billion Rhode Island 529 mandate. 
Before I hand the call over to Loren, let me say a few words about how Invesco's positioned against the changes being brought by the DOL fudiciary rule. We're actively engaged with clients that work to align the platforms to the demands of the fiduciary rule. As we've made clear since the rule's approval, the key decisions reside with the discretion platforms, but we are actively supportive them. The market has gotten an early from Edward Jones, Merrill Lynch and [indiscernible] Morgan Stanley, but I believe we are still in a very dynamic period with regard to how it will play out. 
It's clear each distributor has a different business mix and will implement the rule in a manner that will be meet its clients' needs. 
Based on the discussions we're having with clients, we could be to believe there are comprehensive range of capabilities are distribution expertise and market leadership all positions us extremely well to help our clients, adjusted business with the provisions of the DOL rule. 
If the ship [indiscernible] passive as some believe, our decade of ETF experience or comprehensive of range of factors smart beta capabilities are scale are significant track record of innovation, all put us in a very competitive position. 
As we mentioned during the Investor Day, there are no barriers to entry, but very high hurdles to success in the ETF business that will make it difficult for late comers to do well. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Loren to review the financials.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Marty. Quarter-over-quarter, our total assets under management increased $40.6 [ph] billion or 5.2%. This was driven by positive market returns of $23.6 billion. We also saw long-term net inflows of $12.2 billion, which included, as yo
componenttext:
Thanks very much, Marty. 
Quarter-over-quarter, our total assets under management increased $40.6 [ph] billion or 5.2%. This was driven by positive market returns of $23.6 billion. We also saw long-term net inflows of $12.2 billion, which included, as you know, $6.5 billion related to Invesco's Rhode Island 529 plan win. 
We also saw inflows from money market in QQQs of $5.9 billion and $1.1 billion, respectively. These were offset by negative FX translation, which amounted to $2.2 billion. 
Our average AUM for the third quarter was $814.1 billion. That was up 3.8% versus the second quarter. Our annualized long-term growth rate in Q3 was 7.1%, and that was up from 2.6% in second quarter. This measure represents our long-term flows in the quarter divided by the beginning of period long-term AUM, which excludes the institutional money market assets and the QQQ assets. 
Our net revenue yield came in at 42 basis points, which was 1.7 basis points lower than the prior quarter. The change in mix, largely driven by currency, reduced the yield by 1.1 basis points. This was primarily resulted the declining pound sterling rate, which was 8.4% lower on average during the third quarter compared to the second quarter. 
Also, we saw a decrease in other revenues, which reduced the yield by 0.7 basis points and lower performance fees in the quarter further depressed the yield by 0.3 basis points. These factors were offset by one more day in the period, which increased the yield by 0.4 basis points. 
A little bit of guidance here. Looking forward to the fourth quarter, we would expect our net revenue yield to be roughly in line with the third quarter levels at 42 basis points, assuming consistent markets and FX levels in line with today. 
So moving on to Slide 12. As we've done before, we provide a U.S. GAAP operating results for the quarter. My comments today, however, will focus exclusively on the variances related to our non-GAAP adjusted measures, which can be found on Slide 13. 
Slide 13, you'll see net revenues decreased by $1.9 million or 0.2% quarter-over-quarter to $854.7 million, which includes a negative FX rate impact of $18.5 million. 
Within the net revenue number, you'll see that adjusted investment management fees increased by $19.8 million or 2.1% to $982.7 million. This reflects higher average AUM for the quarter, partially offset by the impact of currency on our AUM mix. 
FX decreased adjusted investment management fees by $23 million. 
Adjusted service and distribution revenues increased by $10 million or 4.9%, reflecting higher average AUM for retail products. FX decreased adjusted service and distribution revenues by $0.1 million. 
Adjusted performance fees came in at $3.8 million in Q3 and were earned from a variety of different investment capabilities, including $2.3 million from bank loan products. Foreign exchange decreased these fees by $0.1 million. 
Again, some guidance here. In Q4, we'd expect performance fee to be in line with our historical guidance at $5 million in the quarter. 
Adjusted other revenues in the third quarter were $19.3 million, and that was a decrease of $12.4 million from the prior quarter, primarily due to an decrease of $7.3 million in transaction fees from real estate and a $2 million decrease in transactional sales charges from our UIT products. 
Foreign exchange decreased these revenues by $0.1 million. 
The guidance here, looking forward to Q4, we would expect to see this number increase in the range of $23 million to $25 million. 
Third-party distribution services and advisory expense, which we net against gross revenues, increased by $13.8 [ph] million or 3.9%, and this movement was in line with higher revenues derived from our retail assets under management. FX decrease these expenses by $4.8 million. 
Moving on down the slide, you'll see that adjusted operating expenses at $515.4 [ph] million decreased by $10.8 million or 2.1%. Relative to the second quarter, foreign exchange reduced adjusted operating expenses by $8.2 million during the quarter. 
Our adjusted employee compensation came in at $339.1 million, a drop of $8.8 million or 2.5%, and this was due to lower variable compensation on performance fees. 
Foreign exchange decreased adjusted compensation by $5.1 million. Adjusted marketing expenses fell by $2.2 million or 7.6%, $26.8 million reflecting fewer client events held in the quarter, FX decreased adjusted marketing expense by $0.3 million in the quarter. 
Our adjusted property office and tech expenses were $82.1 million in the quarter, a decrease of $0.7 million over the second quarter, and FX decreased these expenses by $1.2 million. 
And then adjusted G&A expenses at $67.4 [ph] million increased $0.9 million or 1.4%, and this was driven by costs associated with several new product introductions, foreign exchange decreased adjusted G&A by $1.6 million. 
Again, some guidance for Q4. We would expect to see these expense line items roughly flat with the third quarter other than marketing. We expect marketing to -- marketing spend to increase in the range of $32 million to $35 million, which is seasonally consistent with prior years. 
Continuing on down the page, you'll see that our adjusted nonoperating income increased $9 million compared to the second quarter. This was primarily driven by a $4.9 million gain realized on our pound sterling U.S. dollar hedge as well as due to mark-to-market gains on our seed money investments in the third quarter. 
Firm's effective tax rate on pretax adjusted net income in Q3 came in at 26.5%, consistent with the prior quarter. The guidance here looking forward to the fourth quarter, we believe our tax rate will increase slightly to 27%, largely due to the currency impact on the mix of our earnings. 
And this brings us our adjusted EPS of $0.60 [ph] and adjusted net operating margin of 39.7%. 
I would say just generally as you probably would expect that foreign exchange has had a real impact on our operating results as reported in U.S. dollars, just to quantify that for you. When we look at our Q3 versus Q2 results, EPS was -- our operating EPS was resulted 1.8 cents lower as a result of foreign exchange as well as our margin being impacted by 0.3%. 
Looking at year-over-year, Q3 to Q3, the numbers are larger, obviously. EPS is down 3.4 cents due to currency and our margin is down 0.7% as a result of FX only. 
So with that, before I turn it over to Marty, I'd also like to provide a quick update on the business optimization work that we implemented in Q4 of last year. We made very good progress on our optimization efforts and have generated approximately $14 [ph] million in annual run rate savings by the end of the third quarter. Some of the bigger opportunities are ahead of us, however, but we are confident that we'll be able to achieve the targeted run rate savings number, as we discussed, of $30 million to $45 million in 2017. 
And with that, I'd like to turn it back to Marty.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Operator, could you open it up for questions, please?

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Robert Lee with KBW.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Marty, can you maybe breakdown, give us a little bit more color on kind of retail flow trend. I know you  I think you mentioned Asia PAC, but kind of give us some sense of what you're seeing Asia, U.S. versus EMEA and then maybe if you're getting any sens
componenttext: Marty, can you maybe breakdown, give us a little bit more color on kind of retail flow trend. I know you  I think you mentioned Asia PAC, but kind of give us some sense of what you're seeing Asia, U.S. versus EMEA and then maybe if you're getting any sense that ahead of DOL implementation that's starting to -- at this point started to change kind of investor behavior or activity levels in the U.S.?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good questions. I'll make some comments and ask Loren to come with was some of the more specifics. So Asia Pacific in particular is having a tremendous year, both retail and institutional, and is also very broad-based there. EMEA continues to be strong fo
componenttext: Good questions. I'll make some comments and ask Loren to come with was some of the more specifics. So Asia Pacific in particular is having a tremendous year, both retail and institutional, and is also very broad-based there. EMEA continues to be strong for us. You had that the Brexit [indiscernible] and some of the challenges on the challenges on the [indiscernible] generally, and it's lower than what we had seen previously. But the U.K. has really come back from that sort of the Brexit low. But again, nothing robust. That inflow as we saw a year ago. But again, I think we feel we're on track. In the States, with regard to the DOL rule, it's hard to point to the behavior with anything to do with the DOL. I think it's still more the active, passive debate that's probably driving the behavior more than anything right now is will it going forward? It will definitely put an awful lot of money in motion in the U.S. retail channel [indiscernible] my mind as people never changes from brokers to advisory and as brokers narrow the platforms of money managers. And so with that said, there will be definitely be winners and losers. And again, I think those firms with the breadth capabilities, both active and passive capabilities are going to be the ones that do well out of it. [indiscernible].

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and just a little bit more color. In Asia PAC, we're seeing significant flows coming in, particularly into Japan [indiscernible] has been a big winner there. We're also seeing China mutual fund flows and our joint venture providing good lift, and tha
componenttext: Yes, and just a little bit more color. In Asia PAC, we're seeing significant flows coming in, particularly into Japan [indiscernible] has been a big winner there. We're also seeing China mutual fund flows and our joint venture providing good lift, and that's been pretty consistent. In Continental Europe, net flows continue to really be a little bit mixed, but our GTR product in particular just every quarter continues to grow both in the U.K. and in Continental Europe. So that's a continued trend and we're very excited about some of the new product introductions, FYI, in terms of the income-oriented product that is similar to the GTR product. In the U.S., it's been sort of a mix of things. We're seeing very strong take on on products like our diversified dividend product. Our core bond plus fund is doing very well. And then certainly ETFs very strong flows into senior loan products and other fixed income products. I think we're deferred most successful ETF provider and Fixed Income year-to-date in the U.S. So that's a trend. And then some of that in the U.S. there have been some outflows in some of the other products that are more value-oriented that have seen performance tick down a little bit. Hopefully, that gives you some good color.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then maybe just a quick follow-up and sticking maybe with the DOL theme. I mean, obviously, there've been all this focus whether it's due to the mutual fund business and brokerage versus advisory. Can -- I would expect that if more money moves to
componenttext: Yes. And then maybe just a quick follow-up and sticking maybe with the DOL theme. I mean, obviously, there've been all this focus whether it's due to the mutual fund business and brokerage versus advisory. Can -- I would expect that if more money moves to advisory, as I think broadly expected, that benefits the SMA business. So can you maybe update us on kind of how you feel about your positioning in the SMA business? Is that a part of the business that you've -- how big is that for you and do you feel like you have the right offerings there and you need to invest in that -- in those strategies?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so good questions. So we have an SMA capability for a long, long, long time, like many people. So again, it's not limited to -- at all limitation for us. So we would look at it just another vehicle offering to deliver our investment capabilities. And
componenttext: Yes, so good questions. So we have an SMA capability for a long, long, long time, like many people. So again, it's not limited to -- at all limitation for us. So we would look at it just another vehicle offering to deliver our investment capabilities. And again, that would be -- I agree with you, it's a need that firms are going to have if they don't have it.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Craig Siegenthaler with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from Craig Siegenthaler with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will follow up on the DOL rule and I'm assuming, I'm probably won't be the last one in this call either. But I'm just wondering, are you actually seeing brokers strength in numbers partners they work with just yet? And I'm also wondering, what key compo
componenttext: I will follow up on the DOL rule and I'm assuming, I'm probably won't be the last one in this call either. But I'm just wondering, are you actually seeing brokers strength in numbers partners they work with just yet? And I'm also wondering, what key components of Invesco's platform do you think the firm -- do you think will help the firm remain large at the main U.S. brokers, and in some cases, you think you'll actually be able to increase your share?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again, I don't want to get ahead of what announcements have been made and not been made because I'm not sure what's public and what's not. It does seem -- and it's going to be different firm by firm. So I think that's the first point. I think so often
componenttext: So again, I don't want to get ahead of what announcements have been made and not been made because I'm not sure what's public and what's not. It does seem -- and it's going to be different firm by firm. So I think that's the first point. I think so often when we have these conversations, we think it's going to be a generic outcome and it's not. And as I said, if you just look at where Merrill Lynch is going, where Edward Jones seems to be going and where now Morgan Stanley seems to be going, with all the public information now, you can see that they're taking different approaches to it. That said, the firms that are going to do well, which we've been suspecting and again seems that we're getting early confirmation are those firms with broad ranges of capabilities that are strongly performing, they're going to -- they'll do fine in this. We will put ourselves in that category. Those firms have actually had EPFs, a long track record of ETFs. They'll also do well. Those are capabilities that at need. And I put the third element into it, where again is different firm by firm, but those firms can take the capabilities, will it be a mutual fund or an ETF vehicle and help create solutions for clients, and this is even at the broker level, are going to do well. The other element that people are talking about, I think, and I think we have to all get in the right context, the price sensitivity, it is real. The way the financial advisers gonna to meet that need is really a combination of active and passive capabilities that will drive down the overall effective CIP rate for the plans, which is a good thing. And again, I think specifically vehicle by vehicle, you need to be competitively priced. If you are selling at a -- if you're at a premium price and if you have very strong performance, you probably hopefully can keep it there, but there's going to be real pressure there. If you're at a premium price, you're not performing or you're in a lot of trouble. So -- and we do believe that the platforms, they will be narrowed and again, each firms would be different. And we look at ourselves as being at the right side of those outcomes.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Bill Katz with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question is from Bill Katz with Citigroup.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On DOL, can you give us a sense on what percentage it, if you have it, I know it's tough given the Omnibus relationships that you have with your distributors. What generally, if you have it, what percentage of your retail's bucket into the brokerage-orien
componenttext: On DOL, can you give us a sense on what percentage it, if you have it, I know it's tough given the Omnibus relationships that you have with your distributors. What generally, if you have it, what percentage of your retail's bucket into the brokerage-oriented qualified accounts versus advisory?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I don't have that right now. But -- and again, I'd still come back to -- the point that you're probably making is if you're in brokerage, it's going to go away. It's going to go all go advisory and you're going to be looser and I don't think you c
componenttext: Yes, so I don't have that right now. But -- and again, I'd still come back to -- the point that you're probably making is if you're in brokerage, it's going to go away. It's going to go all go advisory and you're going to be looser and I don't think you can make that brought that conclusion from what we're seeing. Again, just look at the Morgan Stanley and [indiscernible] today, they're going to keep advisory and brokerage both open. And again, I think it doesn't really matter how our capability is there, whether it's in the brokerage channel or in the advisory channel, if you have good capability, you're going to continue to be there. So again, I know I won't get into the specific number you're talking about. I just don't have it handy. So...

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I appreciate that. Stepping back, there seems to be a bit of a pickup of M&A discussion. You've seen it in some of your markets, right, with [indiscernible] with no premium merger of equals. What's your sense of how the industry deals with this conu
componenttext: Okay. I appreciate that. Stepping back, there seems to be a bit of a pickup of M&A discussion. You've seen it in some of your markets, right, with [indiscernible] with no premium merger of equals. What's your sense of how the industry deals with this conundrum of sort of excess capacity, your muted active flows and some of the regulatory changes. Would you anticipate a big wave of consolidation and how -- what kind of [indiscernible] do you think it takes and what's Invesco's role in that?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question, Paul. Look, you've been around in the industry a long time. And so by now, there's been this declaration of massive consolidation for a couple of decades. I would say the reality is the the environment we're in now would support that notion
componenttext: Good question, Paul. Look, you've been around in the industry a long time. And so by now, there's been this declaration of massive consolidation for a couple of decades. I would say the reality is the the environment we're in now would support that notion more than ever before. And I'd say much has been driven by the regulatory environment principally and just the ever-increasing costs. You then add things like cybersecurities, there is -- we'll spend a lot of money where we never did before. And then the extended period of the active, passive movement, which, again, I would also say it's -- when you read about in the paper every day, it's probably gone too far, right? It's not going back to where it was, but it will moderate. And I do believe there will be a very strong place for active capabilities, too. And again, we're in a position of the think the answer is active and passive. So we're well placed regardless. So I think what you're going to have happen on the M&A front is if you were a firm without scale, I think you're going to need to do something. And so I think you're going to see the likelihood of combinations of undersized firms that's probably higher than it's ever been before. And the other point, though, is somebody has to be willing buyer and not everybody is going to be a willing buyer of some of those firms. So I think what you'll see is organic growth coming from firms that really in a [indiscernible] position in this environment.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Michael Carrier with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is from Michael Carrier with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Loren, maybe just a couple for you on some of the guidance that you gave. So one, just on the other revenues. I think the rate or the level that you gave is a little bit lower than where expectations have been. So just -- is that just fourth quarter or he
componenttext: Loren, maybe just a couple for you on some of the guidance that you gave. So one, just on the other revenues. I think the rate or the level that you gave is a little bit lower than where expectations have been. So just -- is that just fourth quarter or heading into '17? I know it's lumpy and hard to predict, but just wanted to gauge kind of what's was driving that. And then I think on the expense side, you gave a lot of color on FX in terms of how that's impacting the revenues, the expenses and then the hedge and then the non-op. And I know you've got the efficiency program in place to lower the run rate. But if we were continue to be in this environment, is there any other levers you can pull on the expense side or how much can be offset by FX pulling that down just to try to manage through this volatile FX backdrop?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So good questions. So on the other revenues, that was explicitly just for Q4 guidance. We don't think it's really a trend. Obviously, it moves around. It's hard to predict. And we've seen that line can be somewhat volatile based on timing. Just in terms o
componenttext: So good questions. So on the other revenues, that was explicitly just for Q4 guidance. We don't think it's really a trend. Obviously, it moves around. It's hard to predict. And we've seen that line can be somewhat volatile based on timing. Just in terms of transactions happening, they can lump up in a particular quarter or be a little bit absent in the quarter. And then certainly, when there is more volatility, uncertainty in the markets, you can see that, that number either [indiscernible] up or slow down. There's the component of our UIT sales that have slowed down just in line or in respect to the DOL uncertainties. And so I think that is something that should hopefully begin to be more clear as to whether that's a true run rate or whether it can come back. But I think for right now, we're looking quarter-to-quarter on that line item. So that's it. In terms of expenses, is there more to be done? I mean, there's always more to be done. We're continuing to look beyond some of the things that we identified in the optimization to see if there are other sort of larger opportunities that can be realized into 2017. As we all know, when we get into our -- looking out 3 years and understanding the need for our incremental margins to be where we want them to be, we have to continue to look and find ways to organize ourselves in a way that would provide those net outcomes. So I would say there is more to come on that to the extent that we can identify them. But certainly, in the near-term in terms of the optimization, we're eagerly going after those opportunities.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Marty, maybe just as a follow-up in the question on M&A and the industry, I guess, has anything changed for you guys? Meaning it seems like you've done things in the past that kind of created the business mix that you have. You've been mor
componenttext: Okay. And then, Marty, maybe just as a follow-up in the question on M&A and the industry, I guess, has anything changed for you guys? Meaning it seems like you've done things in the past that kind of created the business mix that you have. You've been more focused on either launching products, small things on the side and then capital management, whether it's the dividends or the buybacks. Is there anything that you see shifting in the industry that would cause a firm like you -- like that has scale to think that you need to become bigger or do something that's maybe not -- that hasn't been the default over the past couple of years?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'd say, like always, we continue to pay attention to what's available in the marketplace, and the way that we look at it really has not changed. Is it feeling in the skilled up for us or a a region those types of obvious things, we'll continue to do t
componenttext: So I'd say, like always, we continue to pay attention to what's available in the marketplace, and the way that we look at it really has not changed. Is it feeling in the skilled up for us or a a region those types of obvious things, we'll continue to do that. There are fewer gaps know than we've ever had. I mean I think us back to the comment of those question others DOL. We think we've put the firm at the position where client demand is, right, whether it be alternatives, passive capabilities through factor investing ETFs, et cetera. The institutional business continues to be a huge opportunity for us and the like. That said, we'll continue to pay attention to what's going out there. I think it's -- again, just my opinion, those firms, they are narrowly focused, are going to be dramatically more challenged than those firms that have their global in the retail market, the institutional market and have a broad range of high conviction fundamental factor-based capabilities. So -- but again, we'll continue to pay attention to that.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, maybe one more point because I know your question is legitimate. But I think we're spending more time honestly thinking about where we're going to grow revenues as opposed to we're going to be in a position where we're having to cut, cut, cut cos
componenttext: Michael, maybe one more point because I know your question is legitimate. But I think we're spending more time honestly thinking about where we're going to grow revenues as opposed to we're going to be in a position where we're having to cut, cut, cut costs. So we'll continue to invest around new product introductions, continue to strengthen our capabilities. As Marty mentioned, I mean, we think we're well positioned to actually succeed in this environment. And so that's really been our focus and being able to grow organically in that 3% to 5% range, I think, should provide us with the ability to continue to spend margins going forward. And we are not sort of looking defensively to protect ourselves. We're , I think, thinking about the opportunities to grow in this market.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me stay on that because I think this is what is different today than prior challenging times when there's a pullback. I mean, the traditional playbook was market pullback focus on cutting expenses where we can do that with an eye to making sure tha
componenttext: So let me stay on that because I think this is what is different today than prior challenging times when there's a pullback. I mean, the traditional playbook was market pullback focus on cutting expenses where we can do that with an eye to making sure that you don't disadvantage the firm. That was really more an environment, we thought it was competitive 5 years ago and 10 years ago, but it's nothing like today. And that's not just competitive by the market shift. So we feel, again, we're uniquely placed with the capabilities we have that it would be stupid of us not to continue to invest and grow the ETF business or the institutional business or the solutions business. And I think to your point earlier, the most dangerous thing that you can be doing if you are in a narrowly focused firm challenged right now is to be not investing in the future, and I think that's what a lot of firms are finding themselves having to do. And I think that's you're confirming about outcomes as far as I'm concerned. But you have to be disciplined, right? And that's why we're very, very disciplined. We're always looking to be more efficient, more effective and all at the same time of investment for the future.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Dan Fannon with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is from Dan Fannon with Jefferies.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Loren, you talked about a flat fee rate for the fourth quarter. I guess, if we think about the ins and outs with regards to the products from a kind of the flows in your backlog and what you guys are seeing strengthening, can you talk about the d
componenttext: I guess, Loren, you talked about a flat fee rate for the fourth quarter. I guess, if we think about the ins and outs with regards to the products from a kind of the flows in your backlog and what you guys are seeing strengthening, can you talk about the direction of the fee rate based on that x kind of markets and currencies?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, it's all positive. So we'd continue to see the institutional pipeline at a much higher revenue yield coming in then what's coming out in terms of the mix generally of the products on the retail side, Asia, China, very positive relative to the
componenttext: Yes, I mean, it's all positive. So we'd continue to see the institutional pipeline at a much higher revenue yield coming in then what's coming out in terms of the mix generally of the products on the retail side, Asia, China, very positive relative to the overall fee rate for the firm. So that -- which would make you think why the fee rate must be going up has been offset obviously due to the FX impacts because, obviously, the pound has declined even further from where we were in the third quarter, and that's why it's in the flattish kind of range. But again, the trends that have been there for a long time are still there in terms of the types of products that we're offering more alternatives, things that it do support a higher fee rate are absolutely still there. And so we feel that it's not necessarily a situation at all where we're going to see the mix being anything but a positive for us other than the FX, which we can't control. And certainly in our operating results, you're seeing that. And so people shouldn't read too much into the U.S. dollar numbers.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And I guess, Marty, the comments around each of the brokers or the wirehouses coming up with different solutions. I guess, just from a servicing perspective and how you guys are dealing with that, it seems like that's a burden on the industry to kn
componenttext: Great. And I guess, Marty, the comments around each of the brokers or the wirehouses coming up with different solutions. I guess, just from a servicing perspective and how you guys are dealing with that, it seems like that's a burden on the industry to know have to deal with all the various different platforms in a -- not in a uniform way, and so that seems to be costs, that seems like more investment on your guide side. I guess, is that the right way to interpret that or...

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's a good question. Here's my view on it. So at one level, there's no change from the standpoint of those firms have always had brokerage business and advisory business. And their movement to advisory has been a trend and a desire of the distributors
componenttext: So it's a good question. Here's my view on it. So at one level, there's no change from the standpoint of those firms have always had brokerage business and advisory business. And their movement to advisory has been a trend and a desire of the distributors for a number of years. So the industry is already set up to serve that way. Now again, I'd come back in -- to in this environment, what are -- there's some awful a lot of work to comply with the DOL. And so it's firms like us that have the depth of capability through wholesalers and Invesco consulting that can help make the move because they are real moves that -- with the client base. So again, we have the resources, we have the capabilities and we can help them make those changes. I think the biggest concern that I think everybody has heard over more recently was real concern that there was going to be a large proliferation of share classes because each distributor wanting to serve the clients in a different way. And I know there's no great insights, but it seems to be then the industry coalescing probably on a couple of share of classes, which would be there's some costs associated with it, but I mean, that's very doable and I think it's much our outcome for both [indiscernible] clients. So again, I think what I'd do is go back to the firms that have resources and capabilities to support their clients through this change are going to be in a better position than those that don't. And again, this goes back to the prior questions about skill and M&A. I mean, if you can't support your clients beyond just an investment capability, you're at a disadvantage.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Brennan Hawken from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is from Brennan Hawken from UBS.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry to add to the extensive row of tequila shots that are the DOL questions, but I've got a couple more for you. Sorry. I'm not asking for attribution here, but thinking broadly in the dialogues that you've had with partners, and I know, obviously, they
componenttext: Sorry to add to the extensive row of tequila shots that are the DOL questions, but I've got a couple more for you. Sorry. I'm not asking for attribution here, but thinking broadly in the dialogues that you've had with partners, and I know, obviously, they're at a greater depth than we're seeing out in the press and such. Can you give us a broad sense or even a range of how much you expect that the wealth management product shelf could end up shrinking for commission accounts?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to answer that question. I would say what is a truism across-the-board, we would get the feedback that the pace to advisory account will pick up at a material being driven by the DOL. But again, I think that's consistent with the direction of tr
componenttext: It's hard to answer that question. I would say what is a truism across-the-board, we would get the feedback that the pace to advisory account will pick up at a material being driven by the DOL. But again, I think that's consistent with the direction of travel that has been in place and -- but again, you see crosscurrents from that, right? So Morgan Stanley has -- I think they're going to support both channels, right? But that said, their advisory business has been growing quite dramatically and will continue to. So it's hard to size, but I think if you look back 5 years from now, the predominance of assets will be in advisory. I think that's a fair conclusion to draw.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, okay, that's fair. Good enough. And then thinking about maybe down the line where this might lead to potential cost-cutting opportunities, and of course, understanding that this is a near-term thing, right, because you just highlighted earlier
componenttext: Okay. Well, okay, that's fair. Good enough. And then thinking about maybe down the line where this might lead to potential cost-cutting opportunities, and of course, understanding that this is a near-term thing, right, because you just highlighted earlier how you're going to need to be there to support your partners as they go through this transition. But ultimately, beyond near term, this is probably going to lead to some pretty substantial differences and distribution dynamics. You guys do tend to have a pretty large wholesaler team. And so when you think about how those -- the selling dynamics into this channel might change, what kind of expense cut opportunity could that lead to if we end up seeing a channel that is more focused on home office and less on the field? Can you help us try to frame what kind of opportunity ultimately that might lead to from an expense cutting perspective?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So interesting perspective. I think the answer is more along this line. I don't think the demand for support is going to go down. It will probably only go up. But it will be different. You'll end up -- so if you go back I think 10 years ago, if the r
componenttext: Yes. So interesting perspective. I think the answer is more along this line. I don't think the demand for support is going to go down. It will probably only go up. But it will be different. You'll end up -- so if you go back I think 10 years ago, if the role of the wholesaler was to here's a great fund and here's why you should put it in your portfolio, it's a great long-term track record, isn't that great? The nature of the support is going to be very different. And the field support, if you want call it that, will be much more of individual's focus on solutions, how the -- and is their working on their asset allocation, how do you help them build a portfolio range of different investment capabilities, range of different vehicles that would meet their needs. So it would be a very different type of support. So what you can't size right now is does it stay the same, but just different skill sets or is there a sort of size issue that you're talking about? And I'd say it's too early to conclude whether or not there are cost savings there. And my instincts would be the demand for the support is going to be both is going to be different. So cost savings opportunity might not necessarily be there, which then gets you back to the prior questions that, again, if you're not the firm with the resources and the capabilities to support the client, they're extremely disadvantaged in this environment going forward.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So sticking with the theme. So Marty, one of your earlier comments, you mentioned refocus on management fees, obviously, one of the pretty critical criteria is the shelf space [indiscernible] and people kind of rethink who stays in those [indiscernible].
componenttext: So sticking with the theme. So Marty, one of your earlier comments, you mentioned refocus on management fees, obviously, one of the pretty critical criteria is the shelf space [indiscernible] and people kind of rethink who stays in those [indiscernible]. So can we drill down a little more into that? We obviously haven't seen any aggressive fee cut reductions from the active community yet. Do you anticipate that's coming? And I guess, more importantly, thinking through Invesco's product lineup, which products could be more susceptible to fee cuts and, I guess, do you anticipate yourself making your reductions to [indiscernible] shelf space?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again, in the light of the environment and from a macro view, I think that's a good question. I think the reality is, if you look at the larger firms right now, their fees are already very, very competitive because they have the skill to have lower fee
componenttext: So again, in the light of the environment and from a macro view, I think that's a good question. I think the reality is, if you look at the larger firms right now, their fees are already very, very competitive because they have the skill to have lower fees. So I don't sense that there's going to be massive -- within those firms, I didn't think you're going to see much of a change. I think the firms that are disadvantaged are, again, back to -- if you don't have scale and your asset levels, your fees are just, by definition, higher and you're disadvantaged, you got to solve that one way or the other and there's no way to solve that. Again, specifically, and again, we do like everybody else. So [indiscernible] fees all the time, we know they're very competitive. And we also have the added benefit, too, of having the factor-based capability, so we can actually help also drive down the [indiscernible] fee rate within these -- for financial advisor. And we also have solutions capability that we can help and pull that portfolio to.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just the second question, I guess about the robust solution offering that you guys bought a couple of quarters ago. Can you talk a little bit about the opportunity, I guess, to leverage that as the distribution dynamics evolve? Not sure if there
componenttext: Okay. And just the second question, I guess about the robust solution offering that you guys bought a couple of quarters ago. Can you talk a little bit about the opportunity, I guess, to leverage that as the distribution dynamics evolve? Not sure if there's a way to expand that to more the B2B concept or is this all going to be largely targeted directly working with the client?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, so yes, early days, we're thrilled with Jemstep and it is focused on supporting our business partners. And again, I would put this in the context again of firms need more and more tools to help our clients meet their needs. And it is definitely g
componenttext: Yes. No, so yes, early days, we're thrilled with Jemstep and it is focused on supporting our business partners. And again, I would put this in the context again of firms need more and more tools to help our clients meet their needs. And it is definitely going to help us with that we see that already with the interest in it, and it's frankly additional tool that will help clients with things like onboarding in a more efficient and effectively. With their asset allocation, it is open platform. So again, it's supportive of what they're doing and we think it was important development for us.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Glenn Schorr with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question is from Glenn Schorr with Evercore ISI.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up on a lot of this. I'm curious in terms of the factor-based of ETFs specifically as the business evolves. You gave us some good stats on the importance of first mover advantage. But when you talk about quote supporting your distribut
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up on a lot of this. I'm curious in terms of the factor-based of ETFs specifically as the business evolves. You gave us some good stats on the importance of first mover advantage. But when you talk about quote supporting your distribution partners, how important is to establish 3 to 5-year track record in terms of not just being on actually getting the flows because what we're all seeing is a huge clarification of product being put up by everyone and their mother these days. But given your presence, how much is that 3 or 5-year track record advantage?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's huge. Look, I think, again, go to the macro point that we've all talked about. Don't extrapolate your knowledge on mutual fund development with ETF development, right? So there is a limit to how many ETFs there can be within if you want call it a cer
componenttext: It's huge. Look, I think, again, go to the macro point that we've all talked about. Don't extrapolate your knowledge on mutual fund development with ETF development, right? So there is a limit to how many ETFs there can be within if you want call it a certain segment and it's typically 3 that are successful and [indiscernible] that to a thicket, U.S. equity income fund, I don't know how many there are in the category. It's probably, I don't know, 400 or something. So there is inherent limitation right there. And the other thing, you're looking at real track records with these factor-based ETFs that have long track -- as opposed to extrapolating that testing type experiences and no one needs to take that risk when you have a broad range of capabilities. The other element that again we've talked about and others have talked about, it's the total cost of ownership of those ETFs and it's not just the fee, it's the liquidity. And those firms that have a presence, they're going to get the backing to create the liquidity, which is going to drive down the total cost of ownership also. So we have found it to be a realism that the breadth of product first mover advantage, but by the way, the long track records really matter a lot. And I think as we said before, the barriers to entry are very low. The barriers to success are very high.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I appreciate that. Just 1 follow-up, you mentioned in your comments on Japan the success in selling some REIT products there as they look for yield. Can you talk about you just real estate demand? In general, you got real estate business, but I didn'
componenttext: Yes, I appreciate that. Just 1 follow-up, you mentioned in your comments on Japan the success in selling some REIT products there as they look for yield. Can you talk about you just real estate demand? In general, you got real estate business, but I didn't hear too much of it in the puts or takes in terms of the current environment.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, it continues to be -- as we look forward in that sort of institutional pipeline and qualified -- it is in high demand globally. So again, I think there's one of the best teams in the business. And they continue to be doing very, very well. And we
componenttext: Yes, no, it continues to be -- as we look forward in that sort of institutional pipeline and qualified -- it is in high demand globally. So again, I think there's one of the best teams in the business. And they continue to be doing very, very well. And we don't expect that to end anytime soon.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question our last question is from Michael Cyprys with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question our last question is from Michael Cyprys with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Marty, if I could just follow up on your point earlier on the price sensitivity is real. Just curious how Invesco is planning to deal with that over the next few [ph] years, particularly as DOL goes into effect? It just seems like just more money shift
componenttext: So Marty, if I could just follow up on your point earlier on the price sensitivity is real. Just curious how Invesco is planning to deal with that over the next few [ph] years, particularly as DOL goes into effect? It just seems like just more money shifting into passive and lower fee products. Just how do you think about competitively pricing active management and the elasticity of demand? And just the second point there is just giving your scale, how do you think about the opportunity to be more aggressive?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, again, those are broad questions, hard to answer broad questions like that because it gets very specific. So how I would answer it is we look at where we are priced. Our prices are very competitive and they intend to be very competitive with, a
componenttext: Yes, look, again, those are broad questions, hard to answer broad questions like that because it gets very specific. So how I would answer it is we look at where we are priced. Our prices are very competitive and they intend to be very competitive with, again, those firms that have a certain size and have very competitively priced products. And that -- and with a solid good performance, they're going to continue pretty well. I don't know how to answer it other than that. I think what you could see probably in future is I do think that the stronger, more money is going towards those firms. With more money, more break points, fees will drop. But again, that will be a continuation of what would happen in the past. Again, I just think it's the smaller firms that are under a lot of pressure.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The bigger impact is probably going to be the shared class that gets introduced as we're seeing sort of low cost shared classes that are stripped down don't have [indiscernible] costs [indiscernible] all these things. I mean, that's going to be the bigges
componenttext: The bigger impact is probably going to be the shared class that gets introduced as we're seeing sort of low cost shared classes that are stripped down don't have [indiscernible] costs [indiscernible] all these things. I mean, that's going to be the biggest sort of near-term impact and -- but I mean, obviously, the management team is going to get looked at that as well.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Loren does bring up a very good point. I don't know how much attention has been paid on it. But part of it in this sort of low return environments, this active, passive movement that we've talked about and have seen dramatically is active managers an
componenttext: Yes, Loren does bring up a very good point. I don't know how much attention has been paid on it. But part of it in this sort of low return environments, this active, passive movement that we've talked about and have seen dramatically is active managers and packaged products have been at the real disadvantages because of the expense ratio, where, frankly, is a pass through lot of expenses, whether it be 12 B 1 sub TA and you're probably on average at a disadvantage an average fund of kind of probably about 45 basis points every year. And as these be pure share classes come out, that's going to be a benefit for active management also and the competitive returns vis-à-vis passive funds.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Just last follow-up here. DOL, you mentioned more money moving from brokerage to advisory. Can you talk about how you positioned to capture those lows and maybe you can elaborate a bit more in terms of marketing and sales efforts there that y
componenttext: Okay, great. Just last follow-up here. DOL, you mentioned more money moving from brokerage to advisory. Can you talk about how you positioned to capture those lows and maybe you can elaborate a bit more in terms of marketing and sales efforts there that you're putting in place to capture that and also vehicle delivery changes?

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I mean, it is vehicle but I -- and again, everybody's going to solve that. I don't think this could be much of a competitive advantage one way or the other. You're going to respond to your partner's need. Again, I think the thing that's going to b
componenttext: Yes. So I mean, it is vehicle but I -- and again, everybody's going to solve that. I don't think this could be much of a competitive advantage one way or the other. You're going to respond to your partner's need. Again, I think the thing that's going to be differentiating is those firms that can help their partners make a shift from where they need to from brokerage to advisory, and again, it gets to firms like ourselves that have things like investment, consulting, product, field support, thought leadership to help them work through those changes and again a broad range of capabilities. So we think we're positioned very well for that and with the money -- we like the money in motion. We think that's going to be a good thing and we think we're going to be on a net beneficiary of it by the time we get through the other side.

headline: Invesco Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, everybody, very much, and we'll talk to you next quarter. Have a good rest of the day.
componenttext: Well, thank you, everybody, very much, and we'll talk to you next quarter. Have a good rest of the day.
